PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, I present the committee's report entitled Radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: The report I have just tabled completes an inquiry by the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings into future arrangements for the radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. The context in which the inquiry has been undertaken includes the relatively poor appreciation the Australian community has of Australia's system of government, the significant investment the parliament has made in the production of broadcast quality radio and television signals of the houses and their committees, the current inadequate coverage of proceedings on the electronic media, and the emergence of new technologies which should enable an enhanced coverage of proceedings.

With this background in mind, the committee has sought in its report to make recommendations that will give the parliament a better strategic oversight of the future of parliamentary broadcasting and enhance the coverage of proceedings at every opportunity. It is recognised that these strategies may not have an immediate impact. The committee's approach is a long-term one.

To achieve a better strategic oversight of broadcasting arrangements, the committee recommends that a new act covering parliamentary broadcasting be drafted and introduced into the parliament. The new act would consolidate arrangements for electronic broadcasting of parliament and increase the role of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings. In addition to its current role, the joint committee would undertake a more strategic role on behalf of the parliament in advising on arrangements for radio and television broadcasting, regularly reviewing arrangements for radio and television broadcasting, and advising on the application of new technologies to the public dissemination of parliamentary proceedings.

The committee wishes to see an increase in the radio and television coverage of proceedings. One way to achieve this would be to have a service similar to the C-span type service in the United States established in Australia. Such a service would provide dedicated coverage of parliamentary proceedings. The committee will monitor developments in pay television with a view to obtaining channel capacity for the coverage of parliamentary proceedings at the earliest opportunity. Other approaches recommended by the committee to increase coverage of parliamentary proceedings include encouraging and funding the development of packages of parliamentary material for airing on radio and television, and investigating the provision of the audio and audiovisual feed of proceedings to not-for-profit broadcasters.

On behalf of the committee I thank David Elder, the Serjeant-at-Arms; our dedicated committee secretary, Mr Bob Morris, who provided expert input into the deliberations of the committee; and my fellow committee members. I commend the report to the House.
Ordered that the report be printed.

That the House take note of the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW BUSINESS AFTER 11.00 P.M. ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That standing order 48A (adjournment and next meeting) and standing order 103 (new business) be suspended for this sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: I foreshadowed that I would be moving this motion and the reasons for it yesterday when I think the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Reith) questioned me on what we would be doing for the rest of the day. This motion is made necessary by the fact that the Senate will be considering a range of our legislation and will be wishing to pass some of it back to us no doubt in amended form.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I am not necessarily anticipating—particularly if it becomes apparent later in the day that we will be sitting tomorrow—that we will go very late tonight, there is the possibility that we might have to. Hence we need to have this particular standing order suspended. I notice the Manager of Opposition Business looking a bit quizzical on that. We need to check with the Senate constantly to see whether or not it is necessary to have a sitting tomorrow. If it becomes patently obvious that that is the case, then I think it is probably smart to adjourn the House earlier than we might have anticipated tonight rather than try to follow the Senate down to 11 o'clock—which is when it anticipates completing its sitting time tonight. But we need the flexibility anyway. That is why I move the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just briefly refer to the matters raised by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). The opposition does not in any way stand in the way of the continuation of the parliament into tomorrow to complete the business before the House of Representatives and to ensure the completion of a number of matters which are currently with the Senate. The only matter which I wish to refer to is this: as we will be here tomorrow, in my view we ought to take the opportunity for a question time. In respect of the second motion which is about to be—

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to adjourn the second motion?

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the House for those remarks. I restate our position, which is that question time ought to be available tomorrow if the House does in fact sit. The Leader of the House rests his argument on the claim that there are no precedents for an extended sitting to also include a question time. I have had some research done on that, and that is not in fact the case.
—Surprise.

—Surprise, surprise. The data on this matter only goes back to 1988. I am told it is difficult to obtain earlier information without a lot of research. I have not sought that further research because, whatever the precedent is, it seems to me that we are quite capable of making a decision on the merits here and now as suits these particular circumstances. For the sake of completeness, in 1993 there were five extended sitting days—13, 14, 17, 18 and 21 December. On the last three there was no question time but, on the first two—13 and 14 December—there was a question time provided.

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have slipped up. I am sure that in the early 1980s we had, as a general rule, a question time on the extra sitting day when that was forced on us by dint of circumstances to complete business, but I do not rest on my own memory. I am not of a mind to seek further research at great public expense when we have one precedent. That is enough for me.

PARA.TAB: I say that we ought to have that question time tomorrow. There is a particular reason for having question time tomorrow. The current account deficit is usually released via the ABS on a Thursday which does give the parliament the opportunity, when it is sitting, to debate its implications for the Australian economy. I do not know why the figure is coming out tomorrow, on Friday, but as we are here and given the expectation that the imports figure will be much higher than had been expected—and that is one component of tomorrow's figures—it seems very odd to me that, on the day an economic indicator of great significance to the country is released, we cannot have some questions put to the government.

Australia's current account deficit now is worse than Mexico's. It really is reaching crisis proportions. The Australian public, who basically pay for it through higher interest rates on their mortgages, are entitled to know what the government's reaction is. The Labor government has been in office for 12 years. At the next election it will be seeking a mandate from the Australian people to be in office for 19 out of 26 years. That is the request it will be putting to the Australian people. They are entitled to ask, `What have you done? What results have we had in the 16 years you have been in office?'

When Australia's current account deficit is the highest in the OECD, as predicted by the independent OECD, I think some questions on that subject ought to be answered by the government. It would be nothing but political cowardice for you not to give us question time tomorrow. Now that your sole argument, which is that there is no precedent for question time, has been swept from beneath your feet, I will be very interested to see what your imagination brings forth as the reason why we are not going to have question time tomorrow.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Air traffic control facilities for Darwin International Airport

SPEECH.PARA: The existing air traffic control facilities are operationally deficient and were programmed for replacement in the 1994-95 defence medium new works program. During design the project cost estimate has been revised and the project will exceed the medium new works threshold. As a result the project requires parliamentary approval.

PARA.TAB: An audit of the air traffic control services at RAAF base Darwin identified that the replacement of radar and communication equipment is crucial to safe air traffic operations at Darwin. The report also concluded that the timing of the construction of the new ATC facilities should be advanced as far as possible to ensure no disruption to the air traffic services whilst allowing the proper introduction of the radar and communications equipment.

The new equipment will provide the required international standard of air safety at Darwin airport and should not be delayed. To avoid installation delays it is necessary to complete the ATC facilities by the end of 1996. If parliamentary approval is obtained, construction can commence in late 1995 for completion in 1996. In addition, the project will be reprogrammed with a cost cap of $8.4 million. I thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Refurbishment of Australian Embassy, Washington.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal to be referred to the committee comprises:

. the implication of a staged program of internal refurbishment providing tenancy conditions which meet the requirements of occupational health and safety, the replacement of outdated and obsolete equipment and the provision of office accommodation which meets current data and communications needs. Physical security protection will also be improved.

The original building which houses the Australian Embassy in Washington was constructed in 1969 with an extension added in 1976. It is now in need of substantial refurbishment. Subject to the normal Public Works Committee process, the government has approved expenditure of $16 million over a two-year period to undertake a comprehensive program of internal refurbishment.

The building is well located but now has many internal deficiencies. It lacks suitable fire protection and egress, major building services have reached the end of their design life and require replacement and office layouts are inefficient.

PARA.TAB: There is a need therefore for a complete refurbishment of the building to ensure the protection of the Commonwealth's investment and to provide a standard of accommodation appropriate to the function of one of Australia's most significant embassies.

The embassy in Washington services some 19 government departments and organisations, including diplomatic, defense, immigration and trade. It is also the hub of the communications network for Australia's diplomatic missions in North and South America.

Economic evaluations have been carried out on all practical options and the most cost effective solution for Australia's representative accommodation in Washington is the retention and upgrading of the current premises. In addition, the importance of Australia's bilateral relationship with the United States is better reflected in a major refurbishment rather than selling the premises and moving from a prominent location. The total cost of the proposed refurbishment is estimated at $16 million on November 1994 prices. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the following report—Report 337—Review of Auditor-General's Report, 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It gives me pleasure today to table on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the results of the committee's review of 1992-93 audit reports, titled Report 337: a focus on accountability. Report 337 reviews 37 reports of the Auditor-General which were tabled in the financial year 1992-93, and is prepared in accordance with section 8(1)(ab) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951 requiring the committee to examine all reports of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: In reviewing these reports, the committee has not canvassed in detail all of the issues raised by the Auditor-General, but instead has focused on the key recommendations in his reports. The committee's review has shown that, in the vast majority of cases, agencies have responded positively and promptly to the Auditor-General's recommendations. In some cases, however, it is clear that agencies have disagreed with the recommendations or have not taken appropriate or effective remedial action. It is these cases which are commented upon in report 337.

The report is in four parts. The first part explains the scope and nature of the committee's review. The second part considers, on a portfolio by portfolio basis, each of the audit reports tabled in 1992-93. The third part considers the various cross-portfolio audit reports presented in 1992-93. The final part gives detailed consideration to a number of the issues raised in Audit Report No. 22 1992-93, Department of Defence, New Submarine Project.

Report 337 contains 15 recommendations for further action by the government. The committee's recommendations address various matters including the need for the Department of Employment, Education and Training to take further steps to reduce the levels of debt associated with the Austudy program, which amounted to $60.3 million in early 1993-94; the need for the Health Insurance Commission to continue to develop and implement strategies aimed at identifying and discouraging Medicare fraud and overservicing, which have the potential to be a significant drain on Commonwealth resources; and, the need for the Joint Coal Board and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to clarify the method of valuing the coal board's future liability for workers compensation insurance, which is in the order of $225 million.

In reviewing the audit report on the new submarine project, the committee has taken a forward looking approach. We have not reviewed in detail the nature of the contract for the construction of the submarines, nor have we commented on the rather colourful debates that took place around the time the audit report was tabled. Instead, we have focused on some of the risks facing the project and have considered whether steps can be taken to improve the management of these risks for the remainder of the submarine project and for future defence projects.

In taking this approach the committee acknowledges that the Department of Defence has managed many of the risks successfully. For example, evidence to date indicates that the project office has taken responsible steps to ensure that submarine construction and performance standards will be satisfied. Arguably, these are among the most significant of the risks facing the project.

However, there are areas where project management improvements can be made. Some of the audit findings in relation to financial and scheduling risks, for example, warrant close attention by the department. The committee has made what I believe are a series of constructive recommendations which, if implemented, will help ensure that the submarine project and future defence projects of similar size are managed in an effective and most cost-efficient manner.

Report 337 is confirmation that the Public Accounts Committee is committed to ensuring that the reports of the Auditor-General receive close parliamentary attention. By reviewing each audit report that is tabled, the parliament signals to government agencies that the process of accountability and scrutiny is continuous and proceeds beyond the tabling of an audit report.

In concluding, and on behalf of the committee, I express our thanks to those people who have contributed to the review by preparing submissions and giving evidence at public hearings. I also take this opportunity to thank the staff of the secretariat for assisting the committee in preparing the report, in particular Laura Gillies, John Carter and Grant Harrison. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I join with the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), to comment on report 337 entitled A focus on accountability. I am sure honourable members have noted that the committee's reports now have titles. Perhaps in the near future, or possibly in the 38th parliament, the reports will be done in a more interesting colour scheme than the black and red used now.

PARA.TAB: It has been a very interesting exercise to review over recent times the Auditor-General's reports. The Auditor-General plays a very important role in watching the expenditure of public funds throughout the Commonwealth of Australia. Some of the reports that come through are fairly standard, basic reports that border on mundane, but others are sizeable and have an enormous impact on the outlays of the Commonwealth.

One such report was the Auditor-General's report on the submarine project being conducted by the Australian Submarine Corporation. The Auditor-General was not able to dig into the contractual arrangements and see how the contractor was conducting the contract, but he was certainly able to look into how the Department of Defence negotiated the contract and how it was executed. Some concerns about this project were raised in the audit report. Concerns were also raised when the committee took evidence on the subject and visited the ASC plant in Adelaide.

At the outset, the construction and purchase of six new submarines for the Royal Australian Navy represent a significant investment by the government in Australia's defence capability. The project will cost the Commonwealth nearly $5 billion. I think that figure may be closer to $6 billion.

The government hopes to acquire six state-of-the-art submarines. Its other goals are to achieve the capability in Australian industry to support them for 30 years, to achieve a major transfer of technology to Australian industry, to have local involvement in design construction, to have a major saving in expenditure overseas and to have significant export potential as the only useful submarine builder in the region. They were admirable goals that the government set out when it embarked on this project. That is why the contract that was drafted was unique in comparison to other commercial contracts. That was not only due to its size but also due to the in-built possibility of future benefit for the Commonwealth.

The jury is still out on that. We will have to wait until the project is completed and see what benefit an Australian company or a partly Australian company gets from what has been developed so far. My personal belief is that not only the Australian National Audit Office but also this parliament, through the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, should maintain a watching brief on the project as it progresses towards completion. One of the important recommendations with regard to the ASC in this report is recommendation No. 7, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In future projects of comparable size and nature, the Department of Defence should ensure that contracts contain provisions which:
(a) limit or prohibit the repatriation of dividends until the major project risks have been overcome;
(b) require careful assessments to be made of the quantum and timing of advance payments; and
(c) allow the Commonwealth to recover advance payments which have not been used in accordance with the contract.

Due to the nature of the contract and the way payments have been made in sync with the completion of parts of the contract, there is a view that at times the Commonwealth is exposed to unnecessary risk with regard to the completion of the contract and the like. That is why that particular recommendation was made.

PARA.TAB: I believe the Australian Submarine Corporation was paid too much of the contract price too soon. Some 86 per cent of the contract price had been paid by 31 December 1994. As all members would be aware, to date we have one submarine that is doing sea trials, yet 86 per cent of the contract price has already been paid out.

The shareholders in ASC have received some fairly healthy dividends. ASC has invested money in a 747, which is on lease to Qantas. On that basis, I believe the Commonwealth is bearing too much of the financial risk associated with this project. There is a bit too much exposure. On that basis, in this report we have suggested that the ANAO should maintain a watching brief. Page 167 reads:

Given the magnitude of the new submarine project, and the fact that much work remains to be done, it would be appropriate for the Australian National Audit Office to revisit the project at a later date. It is likely that any follow-up audit conducted by ANAO would be of interest to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure it will. If I and the member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who is also taking a keen interest in this particular project, are members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts at the time, we would be keen to revisit this project to see how it goes. In the lifetime of this committee of the parliament we may not see another contract like this. We should draw on the experience of what has happened—the way this project has been overseen and developed and the conduct of the contract.

PARA.TAB: In our public hearings, we were waiting to take evidence from Dr Don Williams, who was the chief executive officer of ASC. We found out a day later that he did not turn up because he had left the Australian Submarine Corporation. Many questions surrounding that surprise resignation of the ASC's chief executive were left unanswered. It raises the question: did he have concerns about the way the contract was being managed? It would be interesting to know what those concerns may have been. Was the ASC becoming too competitive in the Asia-Pacific region for its parent company, Kockums, in Sweden? Did Dr Williams fall or was he pushed?

There are some very important questions which are partly addressed in report 337. As the chairman of the committee, the member for Oxley, just said, the new submarine project makes up only a quarter of this particular report, but it is a very important element because it contains nearly $6 billion worth of expenditure by the Commonwealth. As I said, the Australian National Audit Office must continue a watching brief on that project. I believe the Joint Committee of Public Accounts should also maintain a watching brief on that project until its completion.

With those short remarks, I commend the report to the House. It has taken a lot of work, particularly by the staff at the secretariat. I thank them for their support and their consideration in dealing with the members of the committee from time to time as well. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am very pleased to speak to this report No. 337 of the Public Accounts Committee entitled A focus on accountability. The title sums up the role of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and also the role of the Auditor-General's office. It is clearly a legitimate role of the Public Accounts Committee to examine Auditor-General's reports. The Auditor-General's office plays a very important role in our democracy and our public sector but there is not much use having an Auditor-General writing lots of fancy reports unless the recommendations are implemented, unless someone takes notice of them.

PARA.TAB: I see the role of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the parliament being very important in ensuring that federal agencies and, indeed, governments take notice of recommendations made in Auditor-General's reports and in ensuring that they are implemented as far as possible or certainly considered to ensure that improvements to our administration in whatever agency are made as a result of Auditor-General's reports, which cost a lot of money to produce. The PAC has a very important role in that area.

The particular report that I am interested in is the Auditor-General's report No. 17 of 1992-93, entitled Medifraud and excessive servicing—Health Insurance Commission. I recall that report was tabled in this House in December 1992. I remember hearing about it on the radio when we were in the middle of the last election campaign. It certainly reminded me of my previous involvement in that issue, which I have spoken about many times in this House.

My introduction to the activities of the Public Accounts Committee was back in 1982, 1983 and 1984 when the PAC was conducting an inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing. That is why I was quite distressed initially to hear some of the comments in this Auditor-General's report. The report refers to the fact that in the mid-80s the Public Accounts Committee issued a number of reports dealing with fraud and overservicing by medical practitioners and they revealed a number of problems which affected the Commonwealth health budget. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: At that time, the extent of fraud and overservicing was estimated by the then Department of Health to be `. . . at least 7% of the total medical benefits expenditure by the Commonwealth and health funds'. This figure 7% represented $100m in the 1981/82 financial year . . .
Further on it says:

The pressures on the Medibudget are just as great, if not greater today with the advent of new medical procedures and the growth of entrepreneurial medicine. Today, the same estimate of fraud and overservicing could well still be appropriate. There is no evidence to believe it has changed for the better.
That was in 1992. Of even more concern to me and also to the committee, I believe, is that the report said:

Since the JCPA hearings on fraud and overservicing in the early to middle 1980s, with the exception of the last 12 months or so, there has been little if any improvement in combating fraud and overservicing.

Clearly this is a serious issue. If you base that seven per cent figure on annual Medicare benefit schedule expenditure figures in the 1990s, you are looking at something between $300 million and $400 million a year in potential abuse. The report says, and I actually have no reason to doubt what the report says, that there is no evidence that that has improved.

PARA.TAB: Since the Public Accounts Committee took some interest in this report, we did have the Health Insurance Commission at a public hearing at which we asked a lot of questions. The results of those questions appear in this report. I will read recommendations Nos 2 and 3 of this report No. 337. Recommendation No. 2 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Health Insurance Commission should continue to develop and implement strategies aimed at identifying and discouraging Medicare fraud and overservicing.
Recommendation No. 3 says:
The Australian National Audit Office should monitor the performance of the Health Insurance Commission in its efforts to combat Medicare fraud and overservicing.

They are fairly obvious recommendations to make, but they are fairly important ones. The year of 1985 came after a fairly difficult period—the introduction of Medicare and a fairly turbulent period in relationships between the Commonwealth government and the AMA. The AMA, of course, changed its position a bit after Medicare came in and after a change of government. It changed its attitude towards the issues of fraud and overservicing and other issues to do with Medicare.

PARA.TAB: It was an interesting period. We had a doctors dispute in New South Wales and major problems to overcome. One of the ways in which the government sought to overcome them was to transfer the responsibility for combating fraud and overservicing from the health department to the Health Insurance Commission. The Health Insurance Commission was given a specific mandate in 1985 to carry that out. That is why it was of particular concern that in 1992 an Auditor-General's report should say the things I quoted before—basically, that there has been no improvement.

In fairness to the Health Insurance Commission, I think it is fair to say that the legislation it has had to work with—the legislation the department of health previously had to work with—going back 20 years, was not really strong enough to enable federal agencies to effectively police or combat the abuses of the Medicare schedule or the payment of Medicare benefits. That is why I am quite pleased that the government has passed at least two relevant pieces of legislation in this term of parliament—the Professional Services Review Act 1993 and the Powers of Investigation Act 1994. There have been subsequent amendments to those acts. I am confident that both of those pieces of legislation are the best attempts yet in terms of legislation to overcome this problem, which is a major drain on the federal budget.

I have always supported Medicare. It is the finest health insurance system we have ever had in Australia and it is one of the best in the world. But, of course, it does cost money. Any responsible government, or any politically sensible government, will do whatever it can to ensure that those costs are reduced while not impeding the access and equity to medical services for all Australians. To do that, we have to ensure that the best possible attempt is made to stop abuses by professionals, by medical practitioners or specialists, of the Medicare system.

I believe that now, as a result of reports like the Public Accounts Committee report in the 1980s—a lot of those recommendations have taken a long time to implement—and the Auditor-General's report, and as a result of legislation introduced by this government in this term, we might finally be on the way to some real solutions and some real procedures put in place to overcome or to reduce the incidence of abuse of Medicare. I commend the report to the House.

The Auditor-General's report was, of course, just one of the reports the PAC report deals with. The PAC has a very important role. I will be keeping a close watch on the performance of the Health Insurance Commission in relation to this particular issue and on its progress for the rest of my time here and subsequent to that as well. I commend the report to the House.

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUSPENSION OF STANDING AND SESSIONAL ORDERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Ms McHugh)—by leave—agreed to:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent order of the day No. 24, private members' business, being called on forthwith and any adjourned debate being called on at a later hour this day.
Debate resumed from 28 June, on motion by Mr Vaile:
That this House:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)recognises the work of the Mid-Coast Area Consultative Committee in establishing a comprehensive plan to develop 1000 new jobs on Australia's Holiday Coast; and

(2)recognises the jobs program, the biggest in any region in Australia, is a part of the New Work Opportunities Program and has the full support of the business and community organisations throughout the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was interrupted last night because of the adjournment debate, I was remarking that the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) in his motion before the House had acknowledged that the new work opportunities program is a key element in ensuring that the job compact can be delivered to all eligible job seekers, particularly if they live in areas where employment opportunities are limited. As the government's Working Nation paper points out, there is no doubt that the new work opportunities program will also be the most appropriate employment option to meet the needs of some job seekers.

PARA.TAB: A crucial part of the job compact is the facility for the new work opportunities program to accommodate the concerns, needs and initiatives of local communities. It is very important that the program be regionally organised and managed. This provides an opportunity for local communities to assist the unemployed and for unemployed people to contribute to their communities, as well as business and community organisations.

There is certainly scope for innovation and flexibility in project design. New work opportunities proposals have also been developed at the national level. These proposals will include jobs to reverse environmental degradation along the lines proposed by Greening Australia, jobs in human services such as personal care of the aged and work based assistance to people with a disability, and jobs as literacy education officers in primary schools.

On this latter matter, I had the privilege several weeks ago to launch the first proposal for literacy education officers in South Australia at the South Australian Institute of Teachers. Trainees for literacy education officers, who were previously unemployed persons, have been allocated to specific primary schools, several of which are in my electorate of Port Adelaide.

It is important that these literacy officers be recognised. One of the great problems with unemployment is the lack of literacy and numeracy skills among some job seekers. Obviously, a child who lacks literacy and numeracy skills grows up to be an adult. Those problems first arise in primary schools. Hopefully, literacy education officers can play some part in addressing those issues for children who have those problems. New work opportunities projects also include specific provision for people with a disability and for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, particularly in rural and very remote communities.

In the few minutes remaining, I will briefly refer to the Accord as it relates to the labour market. As both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson, have pointed out, the Accord is much more than a labour market instrument; it is also an agent for industrial progress and a vital element of trade policy. The partners of the Accord are committed to both growth and employment as the prime objective of economic policy. The Accord has always been about wage constraint for employment and its success is reflected in two very telling statistics: two million jobs and a 40 per cent increase in household disposable income—20 per cent in per capita terms—since 1983.

One of the Accord's visions identifies the essential role of training to underwrite long-term competitiveness in addition to improving the life chances of the disadvantaged. But it importantly recognises that skill formation encourages the adoption and the adaptation of new processes and equipment, and is a principal agent of technical change, which is, in turn, a principal agent of productivity on which the nation's prosperity depends. The partners in the Accord believe unemployment represents our greatest social challenge and it is a matter of great satisfaction that the partners in the Accord have met each unemployment goal—and in this period met it nearly a year early with the addition so far of more than 600,000 jobs.

In conclusion, I again congratulate the member for Lyne, supported by the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), for bringing on this debate. It is a bit of a pity that, during their contributions, they both resorted to making negative comments like so many of their colleagues when it comes to employment, education and training matters. Nevertheless, I wish his Mid-Coast Area Consultative Committee every success in its 1,000 jobs campaign. Like our campaign in Port Adelaide, I am sure that—with goodwill, with business and with community organisations, along with the members involved—they will achieve their laudable goals.

By the actions of the member for Lyne and of the member for Cowper prior to framing that motion, both members acknowledge that the initiatives of the government's Working Nation programs are working. There is no doubt about that: you could not frame that motion unless you believed that. Importantly, Working Nation is growing in momentum not only in Australia's cities but also in important areas in regional Australia. It is, of course, a great pity that the bulk of the opposition front bench does not share this important national interest issue as do all government members and, I suspect, the member for Lyne and the member for Cowper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this motion and, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), has said, to congratulate both the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) and the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for bringing this matter to the attention of the House. I congratulate the government for allowing this motion to be brought forward so that we can debate what is a very important aspect of community life out there at the moment, and that is the employment and education of our youth and of our work force.

PARA.TAB: It used to be that once you had received your education you got employment. Today, there seems to be a great muddle. I think this reflects a lot on the education, the standards and the manner in which education is undertaken in Australia today. The two members have been able to secure the funds. Recognising that they are members of the opposition, I believe this demonstrates that they are prepared to give programs initiated by the government a chance.

It is a lie to suggest that everything the government does is automatically opposed on this side of the House. I would just bring to the attention of the House the Australia Remembers program where I would say we would have enthusiastic members on both sides of the House being involved in a manner—

TALK.START.PARA: —Unanimous.
—Yes—in which we can address a national moment like this with the dignity it deserves.
—As acknowledged by the minister.

—Yes, that is right. But we are now addressing another problem, and that is employment and education. First of all, we have to realise that this does something for the local area. I have no doubt that even though they have suggested—I do not take offence to it; it is probably a device to get the money—that the mid-north coast of New South Wales is Australia's holiday coast, I would like to suggest to them that there are other areas in Australia which regard themselves as having good Australian holiday coasts—
—Hundreds of areas.

—Well, I want to mention one in particular, and that is the Whitsunday area of North Queensland and North Queensland in general. But, fair enough, the money is there. The program allows for local involvement. It is always important for governments to understand that, by giving money, they can remove a problem. They cannot do that unless they have local involvement. I believe that partnership is absolutely essential. The credits that both the member for Lyne and the member for Cowper paid for that local involvement were to the people who have looked at it and made submissions with their assistance. I think it reflects creditably on the local population. Perhaps we ought to see more of this around Australia where local people are prepared to be involved.

PARA.TAB: Of course, there will be a profit for the area. If the tourism part of this package gels, the lasting effect will be that people will continue to visit that area and come in and out of the area. Some people, in economic terms, do not understand that if a project is successful there is a multiplier effect. If people continue to visit the area, there will be a chance for these 1,000 people not only over the 26 weeks of the program but into the future. It has a wider implication. So I congratulate those members.

In this partnership, the government—and I think it is putting the cart before the horse—is educating people after they have passed through their educational program. I understand that the program comprises educational training for six weeks out of the whole 26 weeks and the rest of the time is taken up in on-the-job training. As has been said in this debate, it has been acknowledged that, at the end of the 26 weeks, seven out of 10 people will still be unemployed. They will not be long-term unemployed; they will be short-term unemployed. However, we should look at the positive side. We should remember at all times that three out of 10 people—300 people—will get permanent jobs.

It has been mentioned that any program the government implements to absorb the unemployed has to have guidelines. There is no doubt that guidelines for past programs have been and guidelines for this program are unnecessarily restrictive and probably deny another sector of the unemployed—those who have been unemployed for less than 18 months—an opportunity to get a job even though they might have the skills for it. So, if we look at the class of participants who have been unemployed for 18 months or more, we find that it is restricted. The program does not allow for appropriate skills to be applied to the tasks that could be involved, and for that reason it is a waste—although we do recognise it as a training program. I understand that, of the 11,700 places that were to be filled nationally by this program, only 8,000 have been filled.

It is great to have programs that are attuned to assisting high unemployment in certain areas—and I understand there is above national average unemployment in this area—but we must look at the effects of programs the government implements on a day-to-day basis to see whether this program is necessary. With Australia as young and as vigorous as it is and with as much opportunity it possesses, the most frightful statistic we have is the underutilisation of our labour resource. This is what it is about—the unemployed. We have to look at the government's failure to provide the jobs that are necessary.

Before we can even embark on this, we have figures before us that nobody really understands. For instance, we talk about there being 500,000 new jobs, one million new jobs or three million new jobs, but no-one knows where those jobs are. No-one knows what those jobs replace. No-one knows what hours are involved. No-one knows whether they are full-time or part-time jobs. I believe it is fraudulent to present those figures without saying where those jobs are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hiding the unemployed.

—They are hiding the unemployed. As I understand it, a job can be classified as a job on as little as eight hours a week. In real terms, five people are being absorbed from the unemployment queues whereas only one job is being filled. I understand that, if a person is contributing two hours a week in a paid or voluntary capacity, that person is not described as an unemployed person. Surely that is masking the real problem. If we are going to solve the problem, we need to know what the real problem is.

PARA.TAB: We are not talking about people absorbed in jobs as a result of programs such as the one we have before us at the moment. Those 8,000 people who will be given a chance as a result of this program will certainly be taken off the long-term unemployed lists but will eventually be placed back on to the short-term unemployed list. Are they jobs or are they not? Are they unemployed or are they not?

From speaking to a lot of people in the education area, I know that, in relation to retention levels at school, a lot of youngsters come back to do years 11 and 12 because there is no other outlet for them. Some of them are proving to be a disruptive element for the other students in the broad spectrum of education. I come back to the point that we seem to be looking at this back to front. We should be looking at an education program where we try to teach the skills in the schools, and then after the students have finished university or other education we need to make sure there are jobs available for them to be placed in. I believe the real extent of unemployment and where the real jobs can be provided are being masked. The necessary fundamentals are not yet in place.

I would like to address my remarks to where real jobs, real labour, can be provided: small business. There are many impediments to small business. At a time of a state election in Queensland, it is not uncommon to see small businesses in my area closed. They are closed because of government impositions. For instance, the difficulty employers have today in terminating employment makes them think twice about putting on people. The state's payroll tax has long been acknowledged as an impediment to employment. The super guarantee levy and the fringe benefits tax are add-ons to the impositions on small business to employ. Small businesses have recognised there are many impediments to employing labour, such as high taxes, and they are not employing.

A farmer I spoke to the other day can himself maintain a farm which harvests 11,000 tonnes of cane a year. He contracts harvesters, but on a farm which harvests 11,000 tonnes of cane a year he is the only person who needs to be employed for all 12 months of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amazing.

—It is amazing. In my day my father had a 700-tonne to a 1,000-tonne farm. We had a permanent hand and two cane cutters—and of course dad had a tribe of kids who helped out too. Taking the example of this 11,000-tonne farm, we know society and this government have passed by the needs of small business people.

PARA.TAB: One other definite impediment to small business in Queensland providing employment will be the deregulation of shopping hours. It will cause all the little grocery stores and service stores on corners to collapse and allow big international supermarkets to blossom. They will not be good employers. They will not soak up those thrown out of current employment in small businesses. In that regard, I do not think the federal government, or the Queensland government, can claim any credit for creating jobs.

The Queensland government is closing down railways. Public Service employees on the railways are diminishing in number—not in just ones and twos but by the thousands. Government services are also being closed down—this is true for not only the Queensland government but the federal government—such as those carried out by the CPS, police and the education sector. In my area numbers of post office staff are declining.

This is diminishing the opportunities for employment in small country towns. According to the Local Government Association, these are the areas where work will be provided. Putting the Hilmer measures into effect could be the worst possible scenario for local government, particularly in country areas. We may as well close down the towns if jobs in the railways, the police force, the CPS and a whole multitude of other areas are ripped out of towns.

The lack of major works projects in Queensland also worries me. They could be great employers. At the moment we have the ridiculous situation where Queensland has a huge coal resource base and powerhouses have been built in the last six years but in the future we will be forced to buy our power from New South Wales. Just think of the job opportunities going to waste. No new dams have been constructed. No programs have been put in place except the user-pays system. Again, these are areas that could provide real labour. No more roads will be built at the public's expense. Roads are now being built in the form of tollways. Many rip through the most beautiful parts of Queensland, particularly in the south. It will be interesting to find out the reaction of Queenslanders in the coming state government election.

Could I talk about tourism because that is what the motion refers to—jobs on Australia's holiday coast. We have just completed an exercise in the banking, finance and public administration committee looking at the aspects of taxation on the tourism industry that put it at a disadvantage compared with other industries. The user-pays principle that is now coming into tourism, whether it be in regard to the use of the Barrier Reef, the use of a national park or the use of a waterway, is decimating the tourism industry. The government says that it is not putting up or introducing new taxes but there has been an abnormal increase in the aspect of how it funds its money. This is just one way. In regard to fuel tax excise the industry complains bitterly that it is not subject to a rebate because all the fuel it uses on the water is never used on a road back on the mainland.

The fringe benefits tax was a particular worry. The committee criticised the government's latest moves in that regard to try to simplify it because they had not gone far enough. Thankfully, the committee did make recommendations both on the payroll tax and the fringe benefits tax. The sales tax was a particular impediment. People in business are being asked to pay sales tax on the equipment they use on a day-to-day basis.

Employment opportunities in the health services in Queensland are being diminished day by day. The private hospital system and the private providers are being discouraged from taking up the slack. So, while I again commend the movers of this motion, the member for Lyne and the member for Cowper, on their foresight and commend the people of their region for their assistance, I say that the government ought to go back to the fundamentals and look at where these jobs are being lost. It should be honest about where the new jobs are. It should be honest about unemployment and try to form some solution. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to answer a couple of things that the member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) had to say. The difference between each side of the House can come up in these debates. The term the honourable member used was the `under-resource of our labour force', which is true. On our side of the House we believe that with unemployment comes a great deal of social cost as well. High levels of unemployment disrupt our society greatly and cause great hardship to individuals. I guess that is why the long-term unemployed have been targeted for special assistance with some of the programs this motion deals with.

PARA.TAB: The member for Dawson raised the issue of retention rates. He was missing the point. When we look at retention rates and young people staying at school and endeavouring to gain skills at that level, we find that many of the jobs that the previous generation would have been engaged in have now gone. The jobs are not there. So the best thing those young people can do is to gain further skills to enhance their entry into some of the jobs that are coming on, which require many more skills than probably a 15- or a 16-year-old would have required even in my day and even in your day, Mr Deputy Speaker. Those jobs have gone, so it is not a simple task to say that there should be another system and that those kids should not be at school, that they should be out there working. The jobs that they used to take up are not there any longer.

If you look deeper into some of the programs that are starting to come into play and some of the policies of this government to encourage school-to-work programs, then I think the honourable member would probably reach a different conclusion. The member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) moved this motion yesterday in the House. He talked about new work opportunities. He had some criticisms of the programs and labour market programs generally, but I felt he was missing the point with his criticism that we were targeting the long-term unemployed people who had been out of work for 18 months. The old argument of why we are doing that comes from statistics that show that after each recession or downturn in our economy we pick up people who have been out of work for a longer period.

The recent downturn that we have had caused a high number of people to be out of work for a long period. The problem is that, if you do not get back into the work force in the early months of unemployment, you find it even harder to get back in after you have been out of work for 18 months. Employers do not pick up people who have been out of work for 12 months or more unless those people have a special skill. Employers will pick up somebody who has been out of work for two or three months in front of somebody who has been out of work for 18 months. The government's employment policy is targeted at assisting those people who have been out of work for a long period.

The honourable member for Lyne talked about whether the employment programs were successful. In Tasmania, 38 per cent of our labour programs resulted in people getting into work. I think that is an excellent statistic, although it could be better. The programs could work towards getting more people into work—and of course they are doing that. They also get people into the working mode by giving them a six-month opportunity to get back into a job or to get a job for the first time. It enables them to get a pay packet, get into the regular habit of going to and from work and take part in the socialisation associated with that sort of activity.

There is no doubt that the Working Nation program has been one of the most successful programs in recent times in addressing the problems of the long-term unemployed. I think other countries have looked at that program as well. They are looking at our programs to see how we tackle those issues in Australia.

In my state there have been 6,000 outcomes for job compact clients—those are the people who are unemployed for 18 months and in receipt of the newstart allowance. That is an excellent start on solving the long-term unemployed problem in Tasmania. We have achieved an overall reduction of approximately five per cent in the total number of people in receipt of social security unemployment benefits—including the jobsearch and newstart allowances—and a 5.5 per cent reduction in the number of people on the job compact register in the last 12 months.

If the program had not been instigated in Tasmania, we would have had no growth in employment. These improvements have occurred in what is still a very difficult labour market, which shows that Working Nation is on track and ahead of schedule in some parts of the state. We have a state government which has not been able to boost job growth at all. All employment has been created by one or another of the federal government programs and can be attributed to the Working Nation initiative. No investment is coming into the state. Our tourist figures are down, and no jobs are being created through the policies of our state government. The only growth in employment in the state is through the new work opportunities program, Working Nation programs and labour market programs.

There has been a slight problem with the new work opportunities program in Tasmania, with some community concern that it will displace the wages and conditions of other workers. There is some resistance to training wages. I believe that these beliefs and feelings are ill-founded. There is an answer to this, and I am currently working closely with a number of the key players to try to help this program progress further.

I know of many labour market programs that have helped people into training and assisted them back into the work force. Many people in my state have achieved their goal of getting back into the work force, and I can think of several of them. When the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) was in Tasmania, Incat, the ferry maker in Hobart, helped people who had been out of work for three years develop the new skill of welding aluminium. That is a high skill and those people were as keen as mustard because they were in a new field that was going to keep their work prospects alive for many years into the future.

The programs have also given local government and communities an opportunity to bring forward works that may not have been done for some time, that were just on the list of work that could be done and really needed to be done. Some of those works included developing additional tourism structure and tidying up particular long-term problems, even down to our war memorials. We have restoration work being undertaken on some of those.

I have been particularly keen to ensure that the electorate of Lyons has been well represented in making sure that we have achieved what we can from these programs. One such program is the wetlands project, which assisted the local municipality through an innovative program to develop a series of filter ponds for the sewage, and it used jobskills to assist it to achieve its goals. This has now become a first-class tourist feature for the New Norfolk municipality, providing a great visiting and recreation spot. The bird life is establishing there, even the platypi are taking up residence within those ponds that were created through the labour market program.

Another such program was developed at Chauncy Vale, which had 15 young LEAP people working in a natural sanctuary restoring and preserving the site which was the home of one of Tasmania's great writers, Nan Chauncy. There were a few problems with this, and I think it was caused by the lack of information given to participants when they started. We have now sorted that out. I am sure it will be a very successful program.

Orielton Lagoon, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) visited recently when he was in Tasmania, also had a component of 25 LEAP participants over two stages preparing the wetlands and assisting in restoring the lagoon to get it back to its original state and in getting over some of the really bad environmental problems associated with that lagoon.

The Bridgewater High School farm had 15 jobskillers assisting in making the farm into a fine educational tool for training rural workers and also giving work experience in country skills to some of the tough young kids from the urban areas. There is nothing like grooming a cranky bull at 6 a.m. before a show to test the real mettle of some of those youngsters. It gets them to think about who is the strongest.

Queenstown has 10 jobskills people working on their weeds to wilderness project. The Lachlan River at New Norfolk also has 15 people working on weed removal and restoration of river banks in order to restore that river to some of its past glory.

As of 23 June 1995, the commencements in Lyons are 257 jobskills and 65 LEAP people. The 53 new work opportunities have been agreed to in principle, and I hope we can get them started very soon. Further places have been created and will be filled in the new financial year.

I am looking for employers who can provide access to ongoing employment once the training period has finished. There are a number of industries in the electorate of Lyons that may well help us reach this goal, including the forestry industry which, with new methods of planting and caring for young trees, requires a lot of manual assistance. It is a good place to learn the essence of the industry literally from the ground up.

People now need to have greater skills than they did in the old days. As I mentioned earlier, the timber industry is a far more precise and technical industry today than it was many years ago. You need to know what you are doing and you need to know why you are doing it. Thus job training under jobskills or NETTFORCE would ensure that young people can gain these skills on the job from the professionals while helping an industry deal with a cyclical work demand.

I think members will agree that labour market programs, such as the one mentioned in the motion moved by the member of Lyne, play a significant role in getting people back into the work force in Australia and also adding to their skill levels. I wish those from the Mid-Coast Area Consultative Committee well in their endeavour to create 1,000 jobs. I am sure that they will achieve that goal. From what the member has said, there seems to be some enthusiasm for achieving that goal.

I also wish other members well in helping people in their electorates get back to work with the help of these labour market programs. I look forward to seeing more successes with this program. I congratulate the minister for developing this program and making it work in this country. I also congratulate him for his dedicated interest and ongoing support of Working Nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have followed this debate with a great deal of interest because my electorate of Moncrieff has a very high rate of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment and long-term unemployment. I have also followed the new work opportunities program with a great deal of interest. Unfortunately, I was not able to be present when the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) visited my electorate to launch the program simply because, as usual, I got only two or three days notice that he was going to do this. Members will understand that it is almost impossible to go to public functions with that sort of notice. That is what happened in my case on that occasion. It was not that I did not want to be there.

PARA.TAB: However, whilst I have followed this program with some interest, I am now following it with some concern. I was interested to listen to the speeches other members have made in this debate on the motion moved by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), and I congratulate him on it. Since the debate started yesterday and the Hansard was available today, I was interested to check the speeches in Hansard to see what members said about programs in their electorates.

I have to say that the story I have to tell is quite different from the stories that other members have been telling in relation to their electorates. When I was acquainted yesterday with the fact that this motion, quite unexpectedly, would be brought on today, I sought to get some information on the matter so that I could make a contribution to the debate.

I had a member of my staff contact the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I gave him no guidance, so he went through a slightly tortuous process of identifying the right person. I just told him the sort of information I needed. He was referred to the regional office in control of the Gold Coast, which is at Mount Gravatt. When he contacted that DEET office he was told that the person who was responsible for that area was on the telephone and unavailable. He explained that he was seeking general background information and requested, of the staff member he spoke to, the following information, which is what I had requested: how many new work opportunities programs are operating on the Gold Coast—by that I also meant any plans that might be in hand—what industries are involved and how many people are currently, or will be, taking advantage of this scheme?

My staff member was told that the person to whom he was speaking did not know but would find out and call back. Shortly afterwards, a Geoff Green telephoned and stated that he had been advised by the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and the department that he could not provide any information. He went on to say that we would have to request this information through the minister's office and that an electoral brief had been prepared.

Later, my staff member spoke to the DEET office at Southport. Southport is the centre of my electorate and it is also where my electorate office is located. Whilst my electorate has changed a great deal since it was first established in 1984, Southport has always been the core of it. I therefore have a longstanding working relationship with federal government department agencies which are located on the Gold Coast—and most of them happen to be in Southport. There has never been any problem between me and my office and any government office within my electorate or anywhere else.

Again, the sort of information that was being sought was conveyed to a Sue Horne, who is, I believe, the manager. The same sorts of questions were asked. She indicated to my staff member that the people who had the information were in a meeting and that she would call back with it. She contacted my office shortly after 5 o'clock to say that she could not supply any information without the authority of the area office and that she would attempt to get someone to telephone me with the information required. It would seem that when the people who had the information came out of their office, they told her that this information could not be supplied to me by this office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite extraordinary.

—Yes, it is quite extraordinary when one considers I am a member of parliament trying to find out what is happening about the long-term unemployed in my own electorate and I keep being fobbed off. This morning the matter was pursued with this Sue Horne, who confirmed that someone would be contacting my office. It was stressed that I needed this fairly quickly because the debate on the subject was scheduled for this morning. A short while after that, a telephone call was received from a Rod Booth, with whom I have a very longstanding working relationship through his senior position in CES. I have always worked very closely and very cooperatively with him, and I have always found him an excellent person to work with.

PARA.TAB: In another telephone call a little later, after the sort of information that I wanted was detailed to him, he informed my staff member that he had been instructed that the only way information could be provided to me was through the minister's office. He said that he had discussed it at some length with the area manager but the ruling was firm. He did not say what his conversation was with the area manager. I would hope and trust that he indicated to the area manager—whom I do not know—that I am not an irresponsible person when it comes to these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a member of parliament.

—Yes, I am a member of parliament trying to find out about public moneys being spent within my own electorate. That is what my role is. To end that story, I can say that contact has been made with the minister's office. However, the person who has the information I have been requesting is on three weeks leave. When my staff member indicated that I really needed this information and that I had exhausted every other source, he was told that they would do their best and ring back. As at the time that I came into the chamber—11.00 a.m.—no contact had been made with my office by the minister's office.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I put my name on the speakers list for this item, hoping to talk about what is happening with taxpayers' money under government programs in my electorate, and I come almost empty-handed. Someone may ask: why did I not contact the chairman of the consultative committee? The chairman of the consultative committee from my region is a person called Peter Lawlor. I have known Peter Lawlor for about as long as I have been the member for Moncrieff. I have been in the electorate for 11 years and I have been the member nearly that long. I have no problems with him—he is a very pleasant fellow and we get on very well. However, he is the Labor candidate for Southport in the forthcoming state election. He is not a businessman—although I suppose he is in a certain sense—he is a solicitor, but he is not the sort of person that I would have expected to be chairing the consultative committee on the Gold Coast.

Some people may be aware that the Gold Coast is the small business capital of Australia. If you look at all the statistics on employment, self-employment and so on from the Bureau of Statistics, you will find that the electorates of McPherson and Moncrieff have the highest number of self-employed people, or of people employed by a very small enterprise, of all the electorates in Australia.

So when I make the claim we are the small business capital of Australia I do not do so lightly. It is an area of entrepreneurship. It is at the cutting edge of the Australian economy. Tourism, which is our major industry, is a small business industry. There are few large businesses. People tend to look at enterprises like Conrad International Hotel and Jupiters Casino, see that it is a fairly substantial employer and think that it is typical of the Gold Coast. Those sorts of concerns are absolutely atypical of the Gold Coast. We are a small business economy.

One would have expected to have had as chairman someone more in line with the sorts of people we are being told about from other tourism areas. For example, the member for Lyne, who raised this matter, mentioned in his speech that the chairman of his committee is a proprietor of McDonald's Family Restaurants in Taree and Port Macquarie. We have some very successful franchises of McDonald's restaurants on the Gold Coast. There are quite a few of them on the Gold Coast and some people have more than one McDonald's restaurant.

I noticed that when the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) spoke he indicated that the appointed chairman of his consultative committee was the chairman of a bank in Western Australia. Not too surprisingly the chairman of the committee for the electorate of Page, which is a Labor electorate, is from the North Coast Combined Unions Committee. There is nothing wrong with that. He would probably have a pretty broad experience, although I do not know what his experience of business is. The member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) told us that the chairman of his committee was a president of a football club—he is also a very prominent businessman—as chairmen of football clubs sometimes are.

I think members will understand that in an election climate I had some diffidence about contacting a Labor candidate. Peter Lawlor has been the Labor candidate for quite some months, since Christmas in fact. At the moment he is campaigning very hard to defeat a coalition member of the state parliament, Mr Mick Veivers, who is the shadow minister for tourism—and a very good, hardworking member he has been, too. In that climate alone, it is difficult for me to be contacting him. I say that by way of some explanation. I also wonder whether someone who is a candidate for an election at the time of his appointment—as far as I know—as chairman was the appropriate person for the minister to put in this position.
Generally, there is great goodwill in the community, particularly amongst business people in the community, to do something about the unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's my experience.

—Our shadow minister indicates that that is his experience. It has certainly been mine. Rotary, for example, has a very high-powered drive—and has had for some time on the Gold Coast—for combined Rotary clubs to get their members involved in getting jobs for unemployed people. They have been working very hard at it. They have thrown themselves into it with great enthusiasm and commitment. So the commitment and interest is there.

PARA.TAB: It is utterly inappropriate that there should be these political overtones attached to the chairmanship of these consultative committees. As I said a few minutes ago, I say this with some diffidence because I know and personally like Peter Lawlor, although I will not be voting for him in the state election. I am sure he does not vote for me either in federal elections—in fact, I know he does not. For this sort of program to have been put in the hands of a Labor Party candidate was not wise.

Given the experience that I have had in the last 24 hours—the obfuscation, the run-around, the blocking, the dry gullies, as my office has been trying to find out what is happening in my electorate with taxpayers' money on this—I am very much inclined to agree with the statements by the member for Goldstein, who has very recently and very properly pointed out the shortfalls in the Working Nation programs and raised the question: is this just another way of fiddling the figures prior to an election?

We all know there is a federal election very imminent. We only disagree on how imminent, whether it is a matter of weeks or months away. All of us who contested the last election remember how the unemployment figures were bodgied by transferring a whole lot of people from unemployment benefits into training programs and the government then saying that meant unemployment had fallen. What it meant was that recipients of unemployment benefits had fallen. However, they had only been transferred to another type of unemployment benefit which was called something else.

Frankly, the `don't knows' that I have had and the muddle that appears to have surrounded this particular program seems to be of a piece with the shortfalls that have already occurred in other Working Nation programs. I say that with quite a degree of sorrow. I am pleased that the member for Lyne was able to detail when speaking to his motion the type of cooperation and success that he has encountered in the efforts to reduce unemployment in his electorate. I just wish I had the information to give the House to be able to say the same in relation to Moncrieff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here today to debate a motion moved by the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), sponsored also by the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), on one of the programs under the Working Nation initiative: new work opportunities and use of the area consultative committee process in the mid-coast area. It is also an opportunity to discuss in general, as many speakers have, the question of the operation of Working Nation and the question of, I suppose, the development of initiatives on behalf of government to assist with the question of unemployment, with what can be done from a government perspective.

PARA.TAB: The role of government in a practical sense has changed significantly in the last 15 years in relation to job creation. Historically, job creation from government usually meant major public works or increased public sector employment through existing departmental channels. The attempts at assisting private sector employment through government programs were minimal and often inappropriate. As a response to the recession of the early 1980s and the continuing above average levels of unemployment that followed during the recovery—that is, above average given our postwar experience of the 1950s and 1960s—the government started to develop a range of programs and subsidy arrangements to assist people to gain skills and to assist business to employ.

The success of these initiatives was mixed for a range of reasons. Firstly, the implementation of some programs proved to be extremely costly, making the unit costs prohibitive. Departmental structures and personnel were often not well equipped to handle problems dealing with long-term unemployed people or with the private sector that would be employing them.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training and its forerunners were never really designed for the task they have faced over the last 15 years. The massive increase in unemployment levels led to increased resourcing for the department, but real difficulties have continued with respect to having the right structure to respond to the challenges faced, the ability to react quickly and with innovation to changing demands, and getting enough of the right sort of staff to perform the various roles required. For example, working with small business people and convincing them of the scope available for assistance via government programs is not a role many public servants would be comfortable with. Administrative competence comes secondary to role of advocate and salesperson on these occasions.

The private sector also had a general suspicion of government. By that I mean that many business people, particularly in small business, were unwilling to believe that the government could actually be there to help them. Visions of bureaucracy, red tape and armies of clerks and accountants were difficult to overcome in terms of convincing employers that real practical assistance was available.

Some programs just were not successful or, rather, not as successful as was hoped when dealing with diverse areas of labour market demand, both in terms of the opportunity for sustainable employment growth and also regarding the skills required. Government has found it difficult to accurately predict and anticipate regional needs and provide appropriate program delivery. The role and interaction between the three levels of government have also been problematic with respect to some programs. Parochialism and political partisanship have at times hampered practical policy outcomes.

Most of these difficulties can also be related to the problem of developing policy nationally for implementation locally. By that I mean that any employment generation policy that seeks to practically influence diverse local labour markets has to be able to not only appeal to the vagaries of a particular area but also understand the psychology of the various players involved; for example, prospective employers, the unemployed and the various bureaucrats at state, federal and local level.

The 1980s and early 1990s have seen various initiatives being tried with some being discarded and others refined. The government's white paper, Working Nation, essentially builds on the experience of the last few years. In terms of labour market programs and the role they can play in job creation, the emphasis is on subsidy support for employers to employ. This occurs via traineeships with the continuation of jobstart and also under the job compact with the new work opportunities program. The nature of these programs is to encourage employers to employ, to give them an opportunity to turn a marginal job opportunity into an ongoing position via government subsidy. The subsidy provided assists while a new employee is being trained and helps minimise the economic cost to business of employing new staff.

Attempts are also being made to assist the unemployed to establish their own businesses under the new enterprise incentive scheme, known as NEIS. Under NEIS, managing agents accredit training in small business management and planning skills. Participants also receive business advice, mentoring and an allowance during the critical first year of establishing their businesses.
