The emphasis on improved training programs and practical on-the-job training seeks to ensure potential employees have relevant skills in terms of labour market opportunities that are available. This has always been the aim with training programs. However, with better business links, improved coordination, greater flexibility around what courses are available—when they are available—and how quickly they can be developed, better outcomes are expected.

One of the most important themes in Working Nation in terms of its practical initiatives is its localism. By that, I mean the consistent approach of trying to structurally address the difficulties faced by national policy being implemented at the local level. For an employment generation policy to be successful, it has to be adaptable to local circumstances and be capable of implementation by those responsible. The government is doing this in a number of ways.

Firstly, the government is doing this through the co-option of industry and union representation at all levels. This occurs through national bodies, such as NETTFORCE; through industry related activities, such as industry training boards; and at a local level, via DEET area consultative committees and the boards of regional development organisations. The intention is to ensure that initiatives are implemented with broad support because there is broad agreement on their appropriateness. This will help to make sure that initiatives are successful and, hopefully, undermine the suspicion of government's role at the local level.

Attempts are also being made to improve the service delivery options available to government. The CES is being revamped, with an increased emphasis on outcomes through the individual case management approach for the unemployed. This should help ensure unemployed people get better, more effective advice and assistance with respect to appropriate training and job opportunities. In addition, private sector providers are also being introduced to provide case management services. This will provide an alternative to the CES and is already placing pressure on CES staff to improve their game. Area consultative committees should also assist CES management to be better in touch with the needs of the area they serve.

One initiative that I believe could be very successful is the use of CES officers to lobby local employers to put people on. Although the CES currently has business service centres whose role is to perform this task, they tend to concentrate on larger employers. By dedicating staff to knock on doors and convince employers that they can afford to employ someone, I am confident that many small employers can be convinced, and the net increase in employment could be significant.

The success of the strategy I have briefly outlined is difficult to quantify accurately, but the available information is encouraging. For example, the success of NEIS is demonstrated by the fact that 84 per cent of NEIS participants are still in employment 15 months after starting their NEIS businesses. NEIS businesses also create jobs by employing additional people. For those on traineeships, the retention rate in unsubsidised employment is 84 per cent some three months after the subsidy period is completed.

It is also possible to compare the success of labour market programs for participants with the circumstances faced by those who have not taken part in any program. Evaluations of jobstart, job clubs, jobtrain and skillshare, which accounted for about 75 per cent of all labour market program commencements in 1994, showed that they greatly improve the chances of getting a job. Participation in a training program increased the likelihood of getting a job by 50 per cent, while participation in a wage subsidy program doubled the chance of getting a job.

Importantly, the programs have had an even greater impact on the job prospects of the long-term unemployed. For example, for jobstart people who had been unemployed for 12 to 24 months, there was a 60 per cent outcome rate; but for people not in jobstart who had been unemployed for 12 to 24 months there was only a 27 per cent outcome rate. Preliminary data on former jobstart participants shows that outcome levels for the long-term unemployed are sustained for at least a year after program participation. However, I believe that the development of a comprehensive and effective system is an ongoing process—and that process is continuing.

In their speeches on this motion, the member for Lyne and the member for Cowper congratulated and recognised the work of the Mid-Coast Area Consultative Committee. The member for Lyne though was keen to make clear that his congratulations and recognition were an endorsement of the local area committee's work rather than an overall endorsement of the program. In his speech yesterday the member for Lyne said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this motion is not a ringing endorsement of this particular government program but a recognition of local people being innovative and entrepreneurial in an attempt to strengthen a major local industry . . .
He continued:
The jobs program, which this group of regional leaders has put in place, has the unqualified endorsement of business and community groups throughout the region, as the motion says.

Essentially, what has happened in the mid-coast area is what is happening all over Australia through this program. In the debate on this motion we have had the Mid-Coast ACC mentioned by the members for Lyne and Cowper; the Perth Area Consultative Committee was mentioned by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith); the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) pointed out yesterday that he thought the Gold Coast ACC was `on the right track', although there were some concerns raised about who might be the chairman; the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) talked about the Northern Rivers ACC and the work it was doing towards job creation in that area; and the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) spoke in some detail about the development of worthwhile programs in the Port Adelaide area. So examples in New South Wales, Western Australia, Queensland and South Australia were raised through the debate in this House. They are part of some 60 area committees that are in place.

PARA.TAB: You just cannot drop them on the ground and get them going. Obviously, it takes time to get them to work properly and successfully. It is occurring all over the country on a regular basis and the improvements are there in the statistics for us to see. Members of parliament from both sides are recognising that those programs are successful in their areas.

The government's overall target in Working Nation is to reduce unemployment to five per cent by the year 2000. We still have a long way to go. As someone who has been unemployed in years gone by, during the last recession, I know that it is difficult for people who are in that situation to see that there is a chance in the future. Since the release of Working Nation we have seen the rate of unemployment drop from a peak of 11.2 per cent to 8.5 per cent.

You also have to look at what Working Nation is about and what the role of area consultative committees is. It is a question not only of generating employment but also of ensuring that we do not have a situation that occurred in previous recessions where the long-term unemployed were left behind. If you look at the last recession and the recovery that came after that, you will see that with employment growth there was minor impact on the number of long-term unemployed. If, say, 430,000 people went back into employment, only 10,000 or 12,000 were long-term unemployed, because they were left behind. The circumstances resulting from this recovery are very different. Now about 25 per cent of the new jobs created have gone to the long-term unemployed. That is a major endorsement of the rationale and the strategy behind this program.
We have also seen a major drop in the number of long-term unemployed youth—an issue close to my heart—of close to 30 per cent over this period. Again, that is an area that is a key to this.

When we are debating this issue we also have to look at the coalition's record in these circumstances. The recent headland speech from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made no mention of employment, education and training. Even The Things That Matter farce that occurred some months ago had a whole chapter devoted to that, but it has now dropped off the agenda. In the last two years, we have created over 600,000 new jobs through the government's policies and through the overall economic recovery. When the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer in the coalition government, the record was 262,000 jobs created in 5 1/2 years.

A big part of it all is productivity improvement, which also has an impact on the economy in an overall sense. We have had four per cent productivity improvement in the labour force, while the best the coalition achieved when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer was 1 1/2 per cent. There are clear differences there for all to see. Although it is some years ago—and that is often the point made by the opposition—the fact is that it is the only record we have on which to judge the performance of the Leader of the Opposition, because for so many years he has been isolated from real power, even within his own party.

On the question of area consultative committees, we are also talking about the issue of regional development—that localism that I mentioned earlier—how you develop a real local identity, process and energy to develop agreements on a local basis. Yesterday the member for Page talked about the memo that was produced by the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) on the question of regional and rural development. It was very insightful of the actual process being followed by the coalition. He talked about the need to have big figures and the need to try to set an agenda which was based on statements rather than on action. He stressed the fact that, after an election, one can always back away from it. The government's policies have been endorsed by the OECD. The minister has spoken about that on a regular basis. The situation we have here is that we are doing something. It is working and it should be commended by the House. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Message received from the Senate returning the bill and acquainting the House that the Senate has agreed to the bill as amended by the House.
Debate resumed from 8 June, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to debate the topic of a republic. It is a topic more relevant to our children and the generations to follow than to us. For that matter, notwithstanding our respect for and consideration of the views of our older Australians, we must bear in mind that the decisions we make regarding the constitution will be for our younger Australians, and our decisions should be in their interests.

PARA.TAB: Despite being a young nation, Australia has a long and proud history. Since Federation in 1901, we have endured, among other things, two world wars and a depression. In spite of this, our nation has remained a united and free democracy, the envy of many nations throughout the world. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pointed out in his reply to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating):

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has been one of fewer than 10 countries that has been continuously democratic for the whole of the 20th century.

It cannot be denied that our stability is due, in part, to our stable constitution. Our constitution has rewarded our nation with continuous democracy, freedom for our people and stable government for our nation. However, I should point out that stable government does not give us honest government, and the members opposite are a testimony to that.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's statement outlined his republican agenda. He tried to give the impression that his statement was based on the recommendations of the very expensive Republic Advisory Committee, but the speech we heard from the Prime Minister was his republican agenda, and his alone. In April 1993, the government established a Republic Advisory Committee headed by Malcolm Turnbull. It was made up of an elite group chosen by the Prime Minister and, I should add, it was a group certainly not representative of mainstream Australia.

It is ironic that, when the Leader of the Opposition announced that the coalition would allow the Australian people to be involved in the process of constitutional reform and that we would hold a people's convention—the make-up of which would be 50 per cent appointed and 50 per cent elected, and 10 per cent of those appointed would be in the age bracket of 18 to 25—the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) questioned the fact that we would appoint half the membership. He questioned the fact that half the people's convention would be appointed; yet the Prime Minister's advisory committee was 100 per cent appointed, unrepresentative of mainstream Australia and lacking in representation of young people. The question must be asked: did the member for McEwen question the Prime Minister about his appointing the whole of the Republic Advisory Committee?

In his speech, the Prime Minister outlined his republican agenda. The major characteristics of the Prime Minister's plan are for Australia's head of state to be appointed by a two-thirds majority of a joint sitting of both houses of parliament; that that person is nominated by the Prime Minister after consultations with the opposition; that the head of state has the same powers as the Governor-General—however, those powers will not be codified—and, finally, that no serving or former politicians are eligible to become head of state until five years have passed since their departure from parliament.

One characteristic of the republic debate is that the Prime Minister seems to think that this debate is about whether we want an Australian as head of state. He gives the impression that anyone who supports the present constitution is a lesser Australian than he. Nothing could be further from the truth.

Many supporters of the present constitution fought for our nation, risked their lives for our nation, and if the Prime Minister is going to suggest that he is a better Australian than they simply because he wants an Australian head of state then he ought to think again. This debate is not about whether we want an Australian as a head of state. If we were writing the constitution today, it would be inevitable—probably the first point—that Australia's head of state be Australian.

The fact is, though, that we are debating a constitution that was prepared last century, we are dealing with the complexities of change that are associated with that constitution which was written all those years ago, and therefore the topic of debate is not how do we just delete any references to the Queen but, if the Australian people are not adverse to changing the constitution to deleting references to the Queen and her heirs and successors, how do we find out if that is what they want and, if it is what they want, how we do it while giving them the same or better certainty, stability and freedom that exists with our present constitution.

On that point, it should also be remembered that over the past 30 years the Governor-General has become Australia's constitutional head of state. That position has been occupied by an Australian since 1965. I cannot foresee any future government, so long as we have the Governor-General, appointing anyone other than an Australian to that position.

The government, and I note various elements of the media also, have condemned the coalition for advocating a people's convention. I take exception to their criticism. Firstly, the government's Republic Advisory Committee, on which the government's position is based, does not represent mainstream Australia. A people's convention will.

Secondly, the government Republic Advisory Committee only looked at the minimalist approach of constitutional change. It did not, as the Leader of the Opposition said, consider items such as the basis on which new states, in particular the Northern Territory, would be admitted; whether we should introduce four-year terms of the parliament; and the allocation of legislative and executive powers and functions between state and federal governments, including areas of overlap and duplication. These are issues which are pertinent to Australia becoming a republic and which were ignored by the Keating committee but which will not be ignored by a people's convention.

Finally, a people's convention will ensure that if the people want constitutional change then the constitutional changes which are proposed will be those decided by the people and not the Prime Minister, his office, the Keating committee or the Australian republican movement. The Keating committee was expensive, considering it was a smokescreen. Hundreds of thousands of dollars were expended by the government on the Keating committee, and there is little evidence from the Prime Minister's statement of him taking note of their recommendations. For all we know, the statement could have been prepared before the committee commenced any deliberations but only made by the Prime Minister afterwards. A people's convention will give the people the constitution they want, not the constitution the Prime Minister demands.

The Republic Advisory Committee is hardly a people's convention. Look at the 22 public forums it held around the nation. In a population of 18 1/2 million people, a mere 1,479 persons attended the public forums held by the Republic Advisory Committee. That is an average of 67 people per meeting—hardly representative of mainstream Australia. Because I truly want to hear the people's view, I organised a public forum within my own electorate of Stirling. We had an attendance of 200—three times the average attendance the Keating committee could manage.

A people's convention will ensure the will of the people shall prevail. The Prime Minister wants a referendum on his proposal, not the people's—and that is the only question that will be put at a Keating referendum. Looking at all the referenda held in our nation, one thing is perfectly clear: referendum proposals will only get through with bipartisan support.

The coalition will not support the Keating proposals until there has been further, more detailed consultation with the public. Our view is—and this is what we will do when we win government—that a people's convention should be held to debate the various aspects of the constitution and what changes, if any, should be made. That way, if there is a strong consensus for change, we know that the referendum question put to the people will be supported because it will be their referendum proposal, not the proposal of a megalomaniac sitting in isolated imperial renaissance splendour in the Lodge here in Canberra.

Our approach keeps the people involved at the beginning, at the middle and at the end. It lets them debate the constitution the whole way through—not after the Prime Minister has put forward his proposal at the beginning and said, `This is what I'm offering you. It is that or nothing.' If there is not general consensus from a people's convention, the various options which were preferred at a people's convention is what will be offered, including the status quo which many in the community may want. Presently, if the Prime Minister had his way and put forward his proposal and it was rejected, there would not be any constitutional debate for many years under the guise that the public have recently considered the topic and do not support another debate.

The message to the Prime Minister, therefore, is: if you really want to change our constitutional head of state, allow the people to decide the approach we take to doing this, from the beginning to the end. If you try having your way, it will be rejected. The Prime Minister does not want the proposed new head of state's powers codified. The thing is that the people might. In fact, I am sure the people would. If we take the Keating approach, the opportunity of considering codifying the head of state's powers and how that would be done will not be presented because we are having only the Prime Minister's agenda followed and not the people's.

We are debating probably the most significant and historic change to our constitution, indeed to any law, in Australia's history. The changes we are debating seek to change our constitution and, for that matter, the running of government. The great thing about our present constitution, to the credit of our forefathers who wrote it, is that changing the constitution requires the support of the majority of Australians in a majority of states. Therefore, for Australia to become a republic, we need the support of the people. That will come about only by involving them in the process of change, from the beginning to the end.

The Prime Minister's proposals are only his. A people's convention will put forward the proposals of the people for the people to vote on. It will ensure any referendum which arises from that carries bipartisan support, ensuring the referendum has maximum support and ensuring that, if we do change our constitution, it is the people's changes that are made. I will support only constitutional changes that carry the support of the majority of Australians after they have had the opportunity to consider all options throughout the whole debate, and that can be done only through a people's convention as proposed by the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the contribution by the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) to this debate. In the interests of the good order of the House, I exercised great restraint during some of the comments he made. One needs to take up a few of the points the member for Stirling and I know many of his colleagues are running in this debate. First, the member for Stirling, like all of his coalition colleagues, keeps trying to avoid the fundamental question—a question that has been asked of those opposite for quite a while now and which the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has failed to answer and continues to fail to answer: does the coalition believe that an Australian should be our head of state? That is the question opposition members must answer.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that we on this side of the House do believe that. We believe that an Australian should be our head of state, that we are an independent nation entitled to have our own head of state from our own people. That has been the essence of the debate on the republic since the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) first raised the issue in 1991, and that is the question the coalition continues to refuse to answer. No amount of obfuscation, delaying tactics and avoidance rhetoric by the member for Stirling, the Leader of the Opposition or any of their colleagues on the opposition benches will hide the fact that the people of Australia are asking for an answer to that fundamental question.

The attempt to hide from the question by saying that Australia has been selecting its own governors-general for the last 30 or 40 years and that they have been Australians—most of them have been outstanding Australians and have done the job very well—does not answer the question. The Governor-General is not our head of state; the Governor-General is the representative of our head of state. According to our constitution, the head of state is Queen Elizabeth II, and her children and grandchildren will hold the position as our head of state.

I, as a democrat, believe that we the people should choose our head of state and that no-one should have a right to be our head of state because of the family they were born to or who their parents are. I fundamentally reject the concept of a monarchy because I am a very strong democrat and I believe the people should choose our leader and our head of state. I believe fundamentally that the people of Australia, when they get the opportunity to directly participate by voting in the referendum that will be held in 1998 or 1999, will make that decision as well. They will show they believe in having an Australian as our head of state.

At the moment, whenever our head of state travels overseas, she travels as the Queen of England. She represents British industry, British commerce, British people's values. She does it very well. She is an outstanding representative for the people of Britain, but she does not represent the people of Australia. When she went to Russia or when she went to Canada or when she went to Europe, she did not go there saying, `I am the Queen of Australia. I am here to tell you that Australian goods and services are great and you should be buying up more of these things and you should come and visit Australia.' She goes there representing the people of Britain. When Bill Hayden travels overseas—

TALK.START.PARA: —As he does frequently.
—As he does frequently, and does it very well, too in all the regal pomp and splendour that the Governor-General is able to muster—
—Senator McKiernan doesn't think so.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The member for Moore might exercise some restraint. The member for Moreton is entitled to be heard in silence.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right. I did exercise great restraint during the contribution of the member for Stirling, so I think the member for Moore should do the same.
—Order! I do not think the member for Moore intends to reflect on the chair's decision.

—When the Governor-General travels overseas, most countries do not understand what his actual status is; they are quite confused about him. Is he the head of state or not the head of state? By our constitution, no, he is not. He is not the head of state. He is the representative of the head of state. It is something of great confusion. You just have to ask the Governor-General yourself and he will tell you that. When the Governor-General has travelled in Asia and in other places around the world they are unsure what his actual status is because he is not really our head of state. He is doing a great job as Governor-General. He is an outstanding Australian and I have the utmost regard for his work and the opportunities that he has advanced for Australia in his work as Governor-General, but he is not there in his own right. He is there as the Queen's representative. So that is the first question that has to be answered by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: I will be interested also to hear from our newly independent member, the member for Moore, as to whether or not he has more courage than the rest of his former coalition colleagues and whether he is prepared to stand up in this chamber and make the clear statement that he believes that an Australian should be our head of state. That is the challenge that the member for Moore has to answer, and that is the challenge for all members of the coalition, his former colleagues, who treated him in such a dastardly way by dumping him for preselection. It will be interesting to see whether he has the courage now as an independent member of this parliament to be truly independent and to say, `Yes, I agree an Australian should be our head of state.'

The Leader of the Opposition has attempted to confuse the question by pulling the stunt which he pulled out of the former opposition leader's bag of tricks called a people's convention. He is saying, `We will have this people's convention and that will be the most democratic way that we can determine the process of reforming our constitution.' Let us look at the question of the people's convention because the member for Stirling was raving on that this will be the will of the people; that this will be an expression of the views of the people. I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker, but 400 members out of a population of 18 million does not to me represent necessarily the will of the people any more than this parliament represents the will of the people.

This parliament is a far more democratic process for representation of the will of the people than the people's convention will be because the Leader of the Opposition intends to appoint half the members of the people's convention, whereas all the members in the House of Representatives and the Senate are elected by the people of Australia each three years, or each six years for the senators. So they actually do truly represent the will of the people. We are here to express the views on behalf of our constituents in our electorates. The parliament is the appropriate place to have the debate about what form the referendum should take and whether or not we should move forward with constitutional reform.

The reason we had to have people's conventions in the 1890s was that we did not have a national parliament. We did not have a properly constituted national body representing the will of the people to go through the process of debating a constitution. It did not exist. That is what the people's convention was about—creating those structures and forms to enable the democratic will of the people to be expressed continuously over the next few centuries.

We do not need a people's convention. We certainly do not need a people's convention which is half appointed by the member for Bennelong, should he become Prime Minister. That would not represent the democratic will of the people. The process would be just as exclusive as the one used to select the parliament, but it would be much less democratic because half the members of the people's convention would be appointed.

The people will have ample opportunity—and I hope they will partake of all the opportunities over the next few years—to participate in the debate on this question. This is not about Keating's republic, as the obsessionists—led by the member for Stirling—try to make out. Opposition members are absolutely obsessed with one man rather than with talking about the issue. They constantly attempt to move away from the real issues that are under consideration.

No amount of name calling or grand description of the Prime Minister in those colourful phrases that the member for Stirling uses is going to hide the fact that the question of the republic is the issue that we are on about—the question of whether or not we want an Australian as our head of state to take us forward into the 20th century as a truly independent nation. That is the issue that the people of Australia will be talking about. We will give them that opportunity through a referendum, which is the most democratic way the will of the people can be expressed.

Our constitution makes it very clear that we need a majority of Australians to express that view. It is not going to be decided by a very narrow result—such as 50 per cent plus one—because our constitution says that we need a majority of people in a majority of states to have a successful referendum. That ensures that, to decide a referendum question, a clear majority of all Australians needs to make the same decision.

I have yet to have anybody tell me why we need this people's convention. I believe that it is just a delaying tactic and an avoidance mechanism by the Leader of the Opposition, because he refuses to come clean to the people of Australia and tell us what he actually represents.

There has also been some considerable public discussion about the recommendation in the Prime Minister's statement on the republic that the president should be elected by the parliament, not by a direct election involving all the people of Australia. Some people have confused the issue by saying, `Why should politicians pick one of their own or one of their mates to be the president? We the people want to make the decision.' On the other hand, they are saying, `We certainly do not want a politician as our president. We want somebody who is a great leader, somebody who attracts widespread support across the whole spectrum of society.' We on this side of the House definitely want that.

We do not want to go through the process of having a political campaign to select the president, but that is what we will have if we have direct elections. If we had a popular election, we would have an enormously expensive campaign, with candidates barnstorming around the country in an effort to be elected president.

I can assure you that, if we have a popularly elected president, the Labor Party would put up a candidate, the National Party would probably put up a candidate, the Liberal Party would want to put up a candidate, so too would the Greens and the Democrats. We would have five, six or eight candidates running around the country spending tens of millions of dollars bombarding people in their newspapers and on their televisions, saying, `Please elect me for president.' Having that type of campaign would be the most divisive way we could ever select a president.

If we were to go down that path, it would totally undermine the fundamental structure of our parliamentary system of government. It would be totally anathema to the Westminster system that we have in this parliament—which says that the parliament is paramount, the Prime Minister and the government are accountable to the parliament, and the parliament, through the election process, represents the will of the people.

If we have a fully publicly elected president, who has his or her own mandate, barnstorming the country saying, `If I'm president, I will do this and this,' we will have a divisive campaign with people having to choose between whatever party's candidate they want for president. Once we have elected a president, we will have this individual with a mandate he or she has gained through that popular election. The Prime Minister and the government in the two chambers of the parliament will have their own mandate because they would have been elected at a different time. There would be massive confusion and conflict between those two institutions. That is not the way the Westminster system of government operates.

If we were to have a popularly elected president, it would totally change the political structures of the national government of Australia. That is why we do not want to have a popularly elected president. We want to retain for the role of president the same role as we have for Governor-General—that is, a formal role as head of state having the reserve powers that our constitution puts in place, and the conventions which are put in place, which determine that the president has the role to administer the legislative program and to supervise the operations of the parliament but does not have his or her own mandate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this debate in response to the statement on the the model for an Australian republic by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is vital that this side of the House inject some commonsense and perspective into this discussion about the future of Australia's constitution. It is equally important that the debate is not hijacked by those, such as the Prime Minister, who are pushing the republic for their own selfish, political objectives.

PARA.TAB: We must not lose sight of the real issues and how well the existing constitution has served us up until now. The overwhelming issue is what system of government will best deliver a united, stable and tolerant Australian nation. It is also about what constitutional arrangements Australians feel most comfortable with.

We on this side of the House recognise that attitudes in the Australian community are changing, and that attitudes towards the constitutional monarchy are different from those which existed 30 or 40 years ago. If change is to occur, it is important that it occurs in a united, not a divided, fashion.

It is essential that if the Australian people reject change the issue is not allowed to fester and to detract from the matters that should really concern this nation such as the economy, our standard of living and the future opportunities for the next generation of Australians. It is also important that any change occurs for the right reasons. In this context, many of the arguments put forward by the Prime Minister do not pass the credibility test. The suggestion that our Asian neighbours are less likely to respect us, or to even trade with us, because of our constitutional system, demeans our trading partners and the Prime Minister.

The problem is that the Prime Minister suffers from constitutional cringe. That is his problem, not the nation's problem. Similarly, the Prime Minister is mistaken, or just downright disingenuous, when he implies that the vast majority of Australians who want to retain the monarchy do so because they want to retain constitutional ties with Britain.

This demonstrates that the Prime Minister has no understanding of the role the monarchy has played in Australia's constitutional system and its traditions. Many generations of Australians have respected and cherished the role that the constitutional monarch has played in their daily lives and those of their ancestors. This has provided a role model for the Australian nation.

If the Prime Minister is really concerned, as he pretends, about Australia's independence, he would do something about our critical balance of payments situation. There are many people who believe that, no matter what our constitutional set-up, Australia cannot see itself as truly independent if it continues to labour under its enormous level of foreign debt, which is currently in excess of $160 billion.

We also have the outrageous situation where the Australian democracy continues to be overridden by international treaties, which automatically become part of Australian law and have been used in that manner. This is a far greater threat to our independence than the Australian constitutional monarchy, which has, in fact, helped to guarantee the freedoms that we take for granted.

The Prime Minister is also wrong in his criticism of the origins of the constitution. In July 1993, in his speech to commemorate the centenary of the Corowa conference, the Prime Minister described the constitution as `complex, legalistic and virtually impossible to relate to contemporary Australian life'. This is simply not true. The Australian constitution continues to provide the nation with an effective system of governance—a system that the Australian people are remarkably reluctant to tamper with.

If there are problems, they result from the inability of politicians to agree on solutions to problems such as the imbalance in revenue raising and spending powers and on where specific functions should lie. The Prime Minister went on to say that the constitution `was framed as a routine piece of 19th century British imperial legislation'. In July 1994, he told a group of school children that the constitution was designed by the British foreign office to look over the Australian government's shoulder. The Prime Minister is not even averse to misleading school children on this issue. What he told them is untrue.

I can do no better than to refer to the opinion of Ms Anne Twomey, the author of the Parliamentary Research Service publication The constitution: 19th century colonial office document or a people's constitution?. In this publication she wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: While the Colonial Office did exert some influence on the Constitution, it is still the case that almost all the Constitution was written in Australia, by Australians and for Australia.

We have learnt to expect no better from the Prime Minister. His knowledge of Australian history has proven time and time again to be defective. Have we ever heard him say that the constitution has served us well? I challenge those on the other side of the House to tell us when he has said that the constitution has served us well. I do not think they could find a single instance when he has said that.

PARA.TAB: Has the constitution ever failed to deliver us stable government, a safe democracy for all and a cohesive federation of states? The main test for a constitutional system is whether it promotes democracy. The Australian system passes this test with flying colours. We have witnessed 95 years of freedom, political stability, cohesion and tolerance that other countries envy.

A nation should not tamper lightly with this remarkable heritage. It is tragic that the Prime Minister has tried to use the republican debate for his own political purposes. Only he could turn a constitutional debate into a point scoring exercise. The Prime Minister has misled the Australian people about the difficulties inherent in moving to a republican system. According to him, this momentous step can be taken by changing a few words in the constitution. This is simply not the case.

Eminent constitutional lawyers of the calibre of Sir Robert Garran, H. B. Higgins, Professor Geoffrey Sawer and Professor Colin Howard have raised grave doubts about whether a referendum under section 128 of the constitution can create a republic. The constitution is itself clause 9 of an imperial enactment, the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act 1900. While clause 9—that is, the constitution—can be amended by referendum, the other clauses in this act, which envisage the continuation of the monarchy, may not be amenable to amendment in this manner. This includes the preamble to the act, which refers to the agreement of the people of the various colonies to unite in one indissoluble federal Commonwealth under the Crown. In the past, these covering clauses could probably have been amended by an act of the United Kingdom parliament. However, quite properly, this possibility was removed with the passage of the Australia Act in 1986 by the United Kingdom and the federal parliament.

The effect of this legislation appears to be that all state parliaments will be required to agree with any proposal for a republic. The difficulties of securing this agreement should not be overestimated. Another issue is the possibility that some states might choose to retain their monarchies. Each state has a separate crown, legislature and judiciary. Each state constitution is preserved by section 106 of the Australian constitution. The Australia Act preserves the monarchical system of the states.

Some state constitutions have provisions designed to make changing them very difficult. For example, Victoria requires an absolute majority in both Houses, Queensland requires a referendum, and Western Australia requires both of these. Under the Prime Minister's preferred model, it is up to each state to decide how it would appoint its head of state. The prospect that Australia might end up a federal republic with one or more of the states continuing links with the monarchy is not an outcome that would be in the overall interest of the Australian nation. Nevertheless, it is one that the Prime Minister appears comfortable with.

The Prime Minister has underestimated all of these obstacles to change. He has also taken for granted that, if we were to have a republic, Australians would support his preferred option of parliamentary election of a President. On this, like so many matters relating to the republic, his position is badly flawed. In the latest poll, 74 per cent of Australians support popular election of a head of state, while only 16 per cent support the Keating model.

Those Australians who are assessing for themselves the merit of Australia moving to a new constitutional framework are affronted at the shallowness and insincerity of many of the Prime Minister's arguments. Quite obviously, much of his rhetoric about the reasons for change are just wrong. The coalition does, however, recognise that many Australians are attracted to the idea of a republic—most of them not for the reasons put forward by the Prime Minister. To enable the issue to be addressed by the people for the people, the coalition in government will establish a people's constitutional convention.

If a consensus emerges from the convention, that consensus will be promoted by the government at a referendum. If no consensus emerges, the Australian people will be asked to vote on a series of options for constitutional change to establish which of them they desire. These options will include electing the president by popular vote or by parliamentary vote, or any other method of election that emerges from the discussion process. The option of retaining the present system would be included in any vote.

The Prime Minister's first priority in pushing the republican cause is to cement his place in history. However, the partisan and ingenuous way in which he has handled this issue will only cement his reputation as the most divisive Prime Minister in this nation's history. If the Prime Minister were really interested in fostering a national consensus on the question of the republic, he would immediately stop tampering with the symbols of our current system of government. Many of these, while the Labor Party has been in power, have been fiddled with to the direct detriment of this nation.

I am pleased to make a contribution to the statement by the Prime Minister on a republic. There is a great deal more I would like to say about the issue. Time prevents me from doing that. I am interested to hear, though, the comments of a former minister of the Crown, the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is going to follow me in this debate. Having been a former minister under the Crown, I am sure he will be an independent arbiter of the worth of the Prime Minister's statement. I hope he is. I look forward to his comments on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the member who preceded me in this debate, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak in a debate which will be one of the very significant rungs in the development of Australia's nationhood. At the end of the first century of the six colonies which made up what became known as Australia, those six colonies decided that the time, 1 January 1901, was appropriate for them to join together as the Commonwealth of Australia.

PARA.TAB: In the process of Australia developing its national character, its nationhood, Australia continued as a constitutional monarchy with the head of state the Queen of England. Subsequently, as a result of legislative changes, the Queen was identified as also being the Queen of Australia.

I believe the response on the part of the Australian people is such that there is overwhelming support for the proposition that we use the turn of the next century as a symbolic occasion to add further to the national character of the Australian Commonwealth and determine firmly that Australia, like the overwhelming majority of countries of the world, will have one of its own as its head of state.

Let me emphasise that, whatever else might be said about this question, there is one core issue which must be addressed and which must be answered. It is central. It is fundamental. That question is this: is Australia sufficiently mature, proud and independent, and does Australia have sufficient sovereignty, self-pride and dignity, to have one of its own as its head of state? Or is Australia to continue, as it has now for over 200 years, as six colonies for the first 110 years, and subsequently as the Commonwealth of Australia, to have as its symbolic head of state a person who belongs to another country?

That is the simple question. Members of the opposition have not answered that question. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) did not answer that question. Those opposite continue to avoid the question because they know that the sentiment of the Australian people is such that they believe we are sufficiently proud, we are sufficiently developed, we are sufficiently independent and we do have sufficient self-dignity to say that the Australian head of state should be one of our own. It is simply appalling, to my mind, that anyone could ever possibly assert to the contrary.

I repeat the first question. The core question we must answer is: do we want an Australian as Australia's head of state or are we so fawning as to require a person from another country to be the top symbol of Australia as a nation? Once we have answered that question in the only way we can, the next question automatically falls into place. You cannot have an Australian head of state unless you have an Australian republic. It is as simple as that.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) quite correctly said that he and the government would support a minimalist approach. That is the approach we all endorse as well. There would be no fundamental changes in the way in which Australia operates, except that we would have as our symbolic head an Australian. There would be no other fundamental changes. That is the essence of the minimalist approach.

The approach which has been suggested by the opposition would create fundamental, far-reaching and very significant changes in the way in which our parliamentary system operates. This point was made by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who spoke earlier for the government.

When we refer to that minimalist approach, we mean that the simple change that would be enacted would be that the Governor-General, in effect renamed a president, would replace the monarch as Australia's head of state. The Commonwealth of Australia would continue to be the Commonwealth of Australia. It would not even be renamed the Australian Republic. The powers and responsibilities of the head of state would remain exactly the same as they are at the present time.

There is not even any intention on the part of the government to seek a codification of the reserve powers of the Governor-General. It has been indicated that that attempt will not be made. That is an approach I endorse absolutely because of the intractable problem of codifying those powers—of defining them, of clarifying them, of making exactly clear how and in what circumstances they are to be used. There will be no change in the powers.

I emphasise a point which has not always been made. Let us be perfectly clear about it. At the present time, the Governor-General is appointed by the Prime Minister—full stop. The Prime Minister has that single exclusive right, that single exclusive power and authority, to nominate to the monarch the person who will be Governor-General in Australia.

What has the Prime Minister proposed? He has proposed that, instead of one person in Australia appointing what the opposition chooses to call our head of state, the Governor-General, the election of a president will require a two-thirds vote of the combined numbers of the House of Representatives and the Senate—people who are elected by Australian electors to represent them. That is the essence of the Prime Minister's proposal.

Obviously, the position is not, as has been suggested, that the power to appoint a president is being grabbed by politicians. In fact, the opportunity for the elected representatives of the people to participate in deciding who that head of state should be is being broadened to require election by two-thirds of the combined numbers of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The 148 members of this chamber and the 76 members of the Senate would sit together, with at least two-thirds of them being required to vote in support of who was to be president.

It is obvious that, if we are to have two-thirds of the combined numbers of the national parliament determining who the head of state should be, there would need to be discussions, negotiations and agreement between the opposition and the government. If we have agreement, we have a bipartisan decision—and we would not have a political figure becoming the president of Australia. I know that the opposition would not approve of Gough Whitlam, nor would we approve of Malcolm Fraser. But we might approve of a Ninian Stephen, a Zelman Cowen, a Lois O'Donoghue or a Dick Smith. The head of state would be bipartisan.

But if the proposal of the opposition were adopted, we would have a vote over the whole of Australia by 11 million people. In those circumstances—and let us be perfectly clear about this—the Labor Party will nominate its political candidate, the Liberal Party will nominate its political candidate, the National Party will nominate its political candidate, as will the Democrats, as will the Greens, as will any of those very rich Australians who could afford to finance their own individual campaigns. But I will tell you what: there will not be a Ninian Stephen or a Zelman Cowen among them, because neither of those two gentlemen would ever have access to the funds that would be necessary to fund a political election campaign across the whole of Australia. But we will nominate our political candidate—let us be perfectly clear about it—and the person who is elected will be a political president. That is precisely what we do not want.

What about the authority of a political president, a person who is elected by 11 million Australians? What if we were to say to that person, `Look, we want you to do for Australia what the Queen does for England and what the Governor-General has been doing for Australia; we want you to be a symbolic figurehead.' That president would say, `Hey now, listen, you just hold on a minute. I've been elected by 11 million Australians. The Prime Minister has been elected by his colleagues within the parliament and by a maximum of 80,000 people within his own electorate.' The president would say to the Prime Minister, `My mandate is a national mandate; yours is a single electoral mandate. Don't you tell me that I have no powers. My authority rests with the nation.' Perhaps the president would say to Mr Keating, `Mr Keating, your authority rests with the electors of Blaxland; my authority, Mr Keating, rests with the nation.'

If we want a fundamental change in the way in which this system of government operates, we would adopt the absurd and dangerous proposals that have been put forward by the opposition. Quite apart from the fact that they are dangerous, they are not genuine.

What have those proposals been? First of all, the Leader of the Opposition said that they would have a people's convention in order to determine the nature of a possible future republic. But he said that he would appoint 50 per cent of that people's convention and that the other 50 per cent would be elected. I am not real smart at mathematics, but I know arithmetic. If the Leader of the Opposition cannot control a convention when he appoints 50 per cent and another 50 per cent is elected, he is not even trying.

He also said that, once that convention considers all of the issues, if there is consensus, if there is general agreement, that a republic should be established, he would be prepared to pursue that. He was asked, `What does that mean—51 per cent of the people in the convention?' He said, `No, that is not enough.' When asked how many was enough, he replied, `Oh, at least 60 per cent.' So he would appoint 50 per cent of the convention and the other 50 per cent of the convention would be elected. He would control it absolutely—and he still says, `Unless there is 60 per cent supporting the proposition for a referendum, we would not proceed with it.'

He was then asked, `If the convention cannot come to a consensus about a republic, what will you do?' and he replied, `We will have a referendum.' When asked what the questions would be, he said, `We will give the people multiple-choice questions.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is democracy.

—A democracy! You will get a sheet of paper as long as this building with all the multiple-choice questions and you will have to fill in the boxes. Someone said it is a pick-a-box system of determining our system of government. The Leader of the Opposition said about his proposed convention:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it can examine a number of issues. It can examine the role of the head of state in the Australian constitution, including implications of change for the role of the states. It can examine the allocation of legislative and executive powers and functions between federal and state governments, including areas of overlap and duplication. It can examine the use of the external affairs power of the constitution. It can examine the question of whether we should introduce four-year instead of three-year terms for the federal parliament. It can examine the basis on which new states, in particular the Northern Territory, would be admitted to the federation. It can examine any other matters which the convention members would themselves determine.

That is a deliberate, appallingly cynical and fraudulent proposal because he knows as well as everyone else that such a convention would get bogged down. I do not have time to go into all of the quotes supporting my claim, including one from Zelman Cowen, who is not a member of the Labor Party, but a former great Governor-General. The Leader of the Opposition's proposal for a convention is obviously a sham. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to speak on the republic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Before I make any comments on his statement, I make a couple of observations about some public comments that have been made about two of our existing vice-regal representatives—the Governor-General, the Hon. Bill Hayden, and the Governor of Western Australia, Major General Michael Jeffery.

PARA.TAB: It seems a little amusing that the very same people who leapt to Bill Hayden's defence and said that Bill Hayden ought to be able to speak out on issues on which he feels strongly—I agree with that, although I heartily disagree with his comments about homosexual adoptions and euthanasia—have been very critical of the Governor of Western Australia, Michael Jeffery, for making comments of his own. I must say in order to be consistent that I agree with some of the things that Michael Jeffery says and disagree with others. I make the point that I agree with the sentiment that governors-general and governors ought to be able to make observations and public comments so long as they do not bring their offices into disrepute. I would like to defend the rights of both gentlemen to make those statements.

May I make a couple of observations about the so-called republican debate. Republicanism in its latin usage means the public thing. In the final analysis, there is not a great deal of difference or, for that matter, a great deal of effect being proposed by either side in the republican debate, because the real nub of the dilemma facing Australians in their political system in the 1990s is the domination of the parliament of the people by the executive.

It is my view that all of the issues that have been raised in the republican debate—the consequences, et cetera—ought to be put back within the confines of that important debate; that is, the struggle of the Australian people to become sovereign again in their own nation. Quite clearly, as we have seen the development of the Australian model of the Westminster system, we have seen, particularly over more recent years, the extraordinary domination of the political system by the executive, to such an extent that the Prime Minister or the state premiers have all the powers to rival medieval princes in their standing vis-a-vis the parliament and other facets of our political democratic system.

It is important to bring the whole debate back into that context, because not to do so is to betray the interests of the very people to which we are referring—the Australian people—and their rights, responsibilities and duties as Australian citizens. It is also important to reflect that many of Australia's institutions are already essentially republican institutions. The debate revolves around the question of whether the head of a state should be a constitutional monarch—in our case, the Queen of Australia and her vice-regal representative, the Governor-General.

In the final analysis, will the change that is being proposed by the Prime Minister in his statement make a great deal of difference to the power and, I suppose, the rights of the people of Australia? I would say, `No, it would make very little difference.' I see the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) nodding—in fact, the Prime Minister conceded that this is a minimalist difference.

The people of Australia are not going to get much out of this at all because, in essence, there will be no change to the essential relationship between executive power and the people of Australia. In other words, the people of Australia will continue to become more and more oppressed in that relationship to such an extent—as we know within this particular chamber—that, as much as we care to debate about the issues of the day affecting our nation, at the end of the day the real decisions are made in executive cabinet. The decisions can be made at the whim of the Prime Minister who enjoys the majority of support within that cabinet room. That makes debate in this chamber less and less relevant to the decision making process.

By making parliament—the House of Representatives and the Senate—less and less relevant to the decision making process, it is progressively withdrawing the power and the authority of the people of Australia. The people of Australia have been referred to in this particular debate but, unfortunately, only in an abstract way. In a way, their relationship with executive power is less definable but, at the conclusion of the Prime Minister's proposal, it is probably no different from the situation in which they find themselves right at this moment.

I am indebted to Professor Patrick O'Brien from the University of Western Australia for his observations on these matters. I point out that the best illustration about the abuse of executive power occurred in Western Australia during the 1980s. Professor O'Brien wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: It is now clear that former Premier Brian Burke and his cabinet established almost complete control over parliament, over wide sections of the economy, and over the public purse. Nearly a billion dollars of taxpayers' funds were lost on extraordinary and mainly secret business deals involving donors to the Labor Party. Parliament was never informed of the truth; decisions were made on the run and in concert with conclaves of favoured business people at late-night meetings in private offices and homes; cabinet documents were altered; crucial departmental files either disappeared or were shredded.

PARA.TAB: And that is not all. Secret funds donated by grateful entrepreneurs were used to make large WA contributions to Labor federal election campaigns; in the `80s, federal Labor out-advertised and out-campaigned the coalition at every election. Secret funds were also used to invest tens of thousands of dollars in stamps, gold and property. Burke and several of his ministerial colleagues spent the money solely at their own discretion, and acts of parliament were changed to give ministers power over the boards of all government agencies

SPEECH.PARA: In theory, parliament is supposed to be master and the executive the servant. The system no longer works that way, and hasn't for a long time.
In reality, premiers and their cabinets—not to mention prime ministers and theirs—now form a sort of "elective dictatorship," with vast, and often unchecked powers.

When it comes down to it, much of the talk about the consequences of the changes proposed by the Prime Minister and, for that matter, the responses from the opposition have not addressed the significant problem, the dilemma facing the Australian people: how to restore their sovereignty; how to get back people's power in the Australian democratic system; and how to restore the power of the people in particular to this body, the parliament of Australia. As I mentioned earlier, if you look at the relationship now between the people, the parliament and the executive, it is quite clear that the executive is the master while the parliament and the people are its servants.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to highlight some of the irrelevancies that have occurred in the republican debate—in particular, the so-called sentiment of the Prime Minister that somehow by Australia's becoming a republic, or his talking about it, people will take him more seriously. I ask honourable members: at a time when one of the oldest republics in the modern political world—the republic of France—is thumbing its nose at the views of Australia and treating Australia in a very offhand and dismissive manner, did President Chirac for one minute consider the proposal by the Prime Minister and allow that to alter his point of view? Of course not. It made no difference whatsoever, and neither will it.

Much of the talk about somehow increasing Australia's standing by becoming a republic is not only irrelevant but also ludicrous. That sort of talk is patently absurd, particularly when the Prime Minister talks about improving our standing in Asia when we know that many of our surrounding nations have monarchs as their heads of state. I suppose they must look in wonder and bewilderment when the Prime Minister uses overseas trips in order to publicly criticise Australia's institutions—in countries which may well respect the institutions he is dismissing as irrelevant or out of date.

Changes need to be made to our system to make it a more democratic and responsive system. At this stage, I wholeheartedly support the proposal by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for a people's convention. But this ought not to be merely a people's convention to determine who ought to be the head of state. This must be a people's convention to look at the fundamental ways in which we can make the Australian people more powerful in their own political system.

We must look at relationships of the parliament, the executive, the balance of power, checks and balances and also political parties. As we know, political parties were not mentioned in the Australian constitution when it was written. However, in the evolution of the Australian parliamentary system since the constitution, we have seen the political party system become more and more entrenched within our political processes.

There are some advantages to that—and I have no doubts about that—but there are some substantial disadvantages. We have seen them in the context of the Western Australian Labor Party and the WA Inc. years. We saw how the political process, entrenched and dominated by the executive, fed and nurtured by the political party system, was able to give the Burke and successive governments unfettered executive power at the expense of the people.

There is also a fundamental responsibility on the part of the great political parties of this nation to ensure that their processes are democratic, constitutional and relevant to the people. If that unfettered power is going to be given to political parties—and I must say that I want to see that change—then, in order for the system to be democratic and relevant to people's interests, the political parties must also make themselves democratic and relevant to people's interests. We need to look at political parties in recent years. I have already mentioned the WA Labor Party. I could also mention the New South Wales Labor Party and some of its excesses in the early part of the 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Western Australian Liberal Party?

—I would also like to mention the Western Australian Liberal Party—a subject dear to my heart—because recent history of the Western Australian Liberal Party has shown conclusively that it is undemocratic, irrelevant and thoroughly in need of reform. The people's interests lay in having political parties that are democratic, constitutionally run—not illegally run—and in a way that allows full participation in the policy making process and, in particular, the most relevant to the processes of parliament, in the selection of candidates. It is my view that the sooner we get to a system of a plebiscite of members of parties in order to be able to determine candidates the better. I believe that system is the most democratic and the closest to the people.

PARA.TAB: I am a constitutional monarchist. I am a person who believes our system has worked very well to the extent—I qualify this—of the development of the Westminster system. In overall terms, looking at the large picture, the Westminster system has provided Australia with a stable, democratic, essentially decent and civilised society. That is a good thing. Winston Churchill once spoke of the British system. He said that it was the worst system in the world apart from all others. That was a very telling description. It means there are a number of faults and a number of things need to be changed but, at the end of the day, it is a system that outranks and beats most of its competition around the world.

Before I conclude, I want to make a few comments in relation to the Prime Minister's proposal. I might also add some matters relating to the people's convention. It is critical that we reform the abuse of executive power and, through that, the use of the external treaties provisions of the constitution to change legislation in Australia without recourse to the people.

We need to thoroughly overhaul the relationship between the executive, parliament and the judiciary to make this a system that more closely resembles the checks and balances that are useful in the United States system. I am not advocating a total movement to that sort of system, but that system would allow for a check and balance between the various components in our system.

The system between the executive and the parliament obviously needs to be looked at, in particular the way in which we select ministers from the body of members of parliament. That means that those members who might have very strong views about the relationship between the executive and the parliament may well have those views subsumed on their way to becoming members of the cabinet or the shadow executive because of course they then become committed to the executive.

At the end of the day if there is to be a proposal for the election of an Australian president, the list of candidates ought to be prepared by the Australian parliament with a two-thirds majority. There ought to be strict qualifications on those entitled to be on that list. Candidates ought to be over the age of 40 years and not have been an MP for the last five years, and there ought to be no participation by political parties in a national election to elect a president. Partisan activities in the election should be restricted or prohibited by law and public funding should be allowed to ensure all those candidates are able to run for election in a fair and equitable manner. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been an interesting debate, and I welcome the opportunity to make a contribution. To say that I support the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of 7 June that Australia's head of state should be an Australian and that Australia should become a republic by the year 2001 is somewhat of an understatement. I overwhelmingly endorse it. For me, it is the realisation of a dream I have always had. From an early age I could never understand our system of having a foreigner as our head of state. I have always believed that not only should Australia be a republic but we should have an Australian as our head of state.

PARA.TAB: Anti-republic people always think that being pro-republic is in some way being anti-British. That is certainly not so in my case. I lived for 12 years in the United Kingdom. I went to university there and, dare I say it, some of my closest friends are British. Indeed, I am a frequent visitor to Britain—although, I must say, to enter Britain now I must go through the gate marked `aliens'. So much for those Australians who want to enter their so-called motherland. Being pro-republic does not equate to being anti-British. So much of our culture, our heritage and even our traditions in this place stem from the Westminster system. Those traditions will always remain.

It angers me somewhat that those opposed to a republic somehow question one's loyalty. No-one has a monopoly on loyalty. I have never been a flag-waving person who constantly talks about loyalty to Australia or anywhere else. That does not mean that I am not loyal. I just do not parade it all the time. I have always been very suspicious of those who find the constant need to wrap themselves in a flag and go on and on about their loyalty. Why are they so unsure about their loyalty that they have to constantly talk about it?

Those who would choose a foreigner, however charming, gracious and kind, to be our head of state must have a problem regarding their own royalty because, try as they might, Mrs Betty Windsor is not Australian. Not by birth is she Australian, and, to my knowledge, she has never been naturalised. She does not reside here. The final irony is that she is now paying British taxes. She does not even pay Australian taxes; she pays British taxes. So Mrs Betty Windsor is a British citizen and a British taxpayer and in no way could it be claimed that she is an Australian.

When the Queen goes abroad for holidays or on a bit of a sales promotion tour, it is not Australian goods and services that she is promoting, but British goods and services. I have absolutely no argument with this but I wish people could accept that she and her wayward children are not Australian and do not represent the hopes and the aspirations of Australians.

Show anyone in Finland, Chile, China, Japan or any other place a photograph of Mrs Betty Windsor and ask: `Who is this lady?' and the immediate reaction will not be, `She is the Queen of Australia.' I suspect the immediate reaction will be: `She is the Queen of England' or, to be more precise, `She is the Queen of Great Britain.' The point is that no-one abroad and few in Australia except older Australians belonging to National Party branches and, I guess, the CWA represent her as the Queen of Australia. It is time that Australia and Australians believed in themselves, in their own identity and had an Australian as their head of state.

Since the Prime Minister presented the government's preferred option to the parliament, the old campaign has been waged by the defenders in this place of the constitutional monarchy. We have all been told that life as we know it, our society, our system of government, our institutions, will all somehow be completely uprooted and changed. Australia's constitution, our system of government and our institutions will change very little because the government has preferred a minimum of constitutional change.

The government on 28 April 1993 established a people's advisory committee to prepare an options paper which would set the minimum changes required to create a republic. Since that committee reported to the government, the republic has been widely debated and discussed in the media, in this place, in schools, in universities and in various community groups. All Australians are being exposed to this debate. In the process many Australians believe that the time is right for Australia to become a republic. Importantly too, many Australians believe that Australia becoming a republic is inevitable.

Like most honourable members, I have met and talked with hundreds of people about this issue. I have heard, read and talked with many Australians who are totally opposed to Australia becoming a republic. I have asked each of them: `What possible reason do you have as an Australian to oppose a fellow Australian holding the position as this country's head of state?' I have never received a satisfactory answer to this question. I do not believe that I ever will receive it because no fair-minded Australian can oppose a fellow Australian occupying this country's most important position.

Today, if we were charged with the brief, as the founding fathers were almost a century ago, of establishing this country's constitutional arrangements, there would be no thought of having as Australia's head of state someone who resides in another land 12,000 miles from our own. We would not give a second thought to ensuring that Australia's head of state would be an Australian. So what is the difference now? In proposing that our head of state should be an Australian, the government is proposing nothing more than the obvious.

At the moment, under the constitution, the Queen is Australia's head of state, and her heirs and successors in the sovereignty of the United Kingdom. Any fair-minded Australian should shake in anger at these words. They are not appropriate, they are not representative and in my view they are offensive.

It is often said that the thing the Americans pride themselves on most is that anyone can hold the most important position in that land; any one of them can become President of the United States, the head of state of the United States. Why should Australians not pride themselves on the very same thing?

Why should it not be possible for an Australian citizen to hold pride of place in Australia's highest national office? The simple fact is that it is not possible because of these words: `Australia's head of state is the Queen and her heirs and successors in the sovereignty of the United Kingdom.' These words should be changed, and I believe they will be when the Australian people vote in the referendum in either 1998 or 1999.

The changes announced by the Prime Minister show that Australia is ready to complete a historical cycle. A century ago the founding fathers put together a collection of colonies to make up one nation. Throughout this century, Australia evolved from a collection of British colonies. We became a single nation with somewhat limited independence. From there, we became a dominion in the British Empire and, finally, we became a sovereign nation in all circumstances, except that we allow another country's head of state to also be our head of state.

I am old enough to remember the debates when the Governor-General ceased to be a representative of the British government in Australia and became a representative of the British monarch only. I can well remember the debates about the abolition of all remaining rights of appeal to the Privy Council in London. It was only in 1986, with the introduction of the Australia Act, that Australian courts became the final arbiters on Australian law. With the passage of this act, the British parliament finally relented the last of its powers to make laws applying to Australia.

I can also remember when it was suggested that an Australian occupy the position of Governor-General. The debate was almost ridiculous—just as this debate about whether or not we should become a republic is. All of these issues caused some kind of controversy. They were peddled by those who still long for the return of the empire, by those who say that an Australian republic would be the end of the world as we know it. That is the same kind of scare campaign that the opposition is running around with now.
