Twenty years down the track, people are wondering what is happening now. I remember the debate about whether an Australian was fit to become Governor-General. People were saying, `We should have some minor, illegitimate lord from Britain as our head of state.' Twenty years from now, people will look back on these debates and laugh. They will roll about with laughter at the ridiculousness of us wasting the time of the Australian parliament and the community with all this nonsensical debate about something which will be inevitable anyway. It really is inevitable that Australia will become a republic with an Australian as our head of state—as it should be and as it should have been a long time ago.

As I said earlier, the changes the government seeks are minimal. The essential constitutional conventions, principles and practices will remain untouched and in operation. I suspect that, under a republic, this place will operate much as it operates today. The only difference perhaps will be that Mrs Betty Windsor's photographs about the place will be removed and replaced with photographs of the new Australian head of state. I believe that the role of this chamber and the Senate will remain largely unchanged. Australia will be a republic and continue to be a member of the British Commonwealth of nations.

The only area we seek to change is the wording of the constitution. We would change `Governor-General' to `President of the Commonwealth of Australia', ensuring that the person who holds this office is an Australian citizen. This president will perform much the same duties as the Governor-General. As happens now, these duties will be carried out on the advice of the government of the day. The president will perform ceremonial duties around Australia and represent Australia abroad.

The president will also retain those few powers now held by the Governor-General which may be exercised without, or contrary to, ministerial advice. The so-called `reserve powers'—the power to appoint the Prime Minister and the power to dismiss the Prime Minister and the government—will remain untouched. There has been some argument about why we in the Labor Party should support this. We support the fact that those reserve powers are there, because we realise that it would be in only the most extreme of circumstances—as it was in 1975 when they were illegally used—that those powers would be used.

There is some debate about how the head of state should be elected. I favour election by parliament, but I can see merit on both sides. I can see the merit of the president being elected by the people like, say, the Irish President and the French President, and I can see the merit of the president being elected by the parliament. So I am not going to the wall over this one. But I do think that, if we are going to have a non-political person in that office, it is inevitable that he or she be elected by the parliament, because once there is a campaign, as we saw in the recent French election campaign, the president becomes a very political person—and it is a political act electing that person. We as members of parliament are elected by the people. I think that a president who is elected by the parliament would be elected with the agreement of both sides of the parliament. As with the appointment of governors-general, it takes that political aspect away from the role of the president. If we want people in that position who command the respect of the majority of the population, I believe that it is only by having them chosen by a two-thirds majority in a joint sitting of the two chambers that we will get that.

We, the members of parliament, are elected by the people and in that way we would be representing the people. I cannot for the life of me see how a constitutional convention of 200 elected people and 200 appointed people can be seen to be reflective of the Australian point of view. The 200 appointed people would obviously be reflective of whoever appoints them. The real difficulty that the opposition has in this whole debate is that fundamentally it does not believe that an Australian should be this country's head of state. I know there is some division there, but in the main its problem is that it does not believe in an Australian occupying that position. Australia is making its way in this complex world. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of an Australian republic is not something that is new on the agenda. It has been around since the time that Federation itself was considered. It has been to date a concept which has been rejected on a basis of argument that has been both logical and sensible. From my own point of view, I have always asked two questions of those who would bring about change to achieve the end that they desire. The first is: what is the nature of the change that those people who propose it wish to have? The second is: how will that make Australia a better place? From my own perspective, I have heard no sensible answer to the second question, and only recently have we heard from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) an answer to the first. Having heard his answer to the first, I am still of the opinion that our present system serves us very well.

PARA.TAB: But, if we are to have a debate—and I am never one to run from a debate; I am always anxious to take part—I think we have to have a fulsome debate and look at what flows from the possibility of change. I do not have a crystal ball, I have never pretended to have a crystal ball, so I do not know what may happen in the future and I do not know what event may act as a catalyst for change. I do know that at the present time we have not got one, and when you bring about change in a vacuum you usually get it wrong. If you bring about change when there is a catalyst, you can usually see the direction that you ought to follow.

Had we lost World War II and not been the victors, we would be operating under a very different system indeed. We would not be the constitutional monarchy that we are today which ensures freedom of speech for individuals, which ensures the right to achieve maximum potential and enables us to conduct ourselves as a truly multicultural society where the contribution of every individual is acknowledged and important. I have not seen any riots in the streets by people saying, `We have to bring about change to our constitution because we are not free.' I have heard the arguments put forward in a manner that reflects, I think, prejudice of a different sort, perhaps in the manner of one of the speeches we might have heard earlier this day.

The proposal that has come forward starts from a premise which is fundamentally flawed. The opening premise is that a very small change—a minimalist change—can be made and nothing else will change. The system will continue to function as it is. That is a flawed proposition. It will be argued that there can be an election by the parliament: that is, a collegiate election of a head of state and that this person somehow remains above the political process. Nonsense. Once that person is elected—it does not matter whether the election is by collegiate system, as in the United States of America where the president is elected by a college of votes, or whether the head of state is elected by the people in a plebiscite—the bottom line is that the head of state is an elected person, and an elected person always has a mandate.

Under our current system, appointment by Her Majesty the Queen is the method by which we select a head of state who is truly above politics. Very simply, the Prime Minister of the day selects an individual and makes a recommendation to the Queen. That nomination may be rejected—convention has it that it is not—and the appointment is duly made. Bill Hayden, when he was appointed to the position, acted up until that moment entirely as a political person. After he was appointed to the position he has behaved, as have all governors-general, in an apolitical way and has carried out the responsibilities in a non-political way.

The other day, when the Governor-General chose to speak his mind on a number of subjects, his remarks were of interest for people to read, but they had no political clout because he is a man without a mandate. Had the same person been an elected president and made that speech, it would become politically relevant.

The difference is quite substantial. To say that there can be a minimalist change and that all things will continue on as they are is like saying that you can be a little bit pregnant. You cannot—things flow from the change. If the time comes that there is ever to be an elected president, my view is that the people should do the electing. That is the view that the rest of Australia seems to have—if the polls are any guide. Although I do recall that in 1988 we were faced with a referendum to change the constitution and in the opinion polls, about 80 per cent of people said, `Yes, this change is excellent and we must have it,' but once we got into the detail of it and what it was really entailing not one single state passed the referendums.

It is important that we look at the detail and what is really involved. Let us suppose that the people had their way. If there were to be a change and a president were to be elected by the people, what would flow from that? Currently, we operate under what we call the Westminster system, although I suggest that under the current government we do not. Under this government we see instances where ministers who have been found wanting and in error have refused to resign until they are virtually forced from office—for example, Mrs Kelly over sports rorts or Graham Richardson over the infamous Marshall Islands affair. There have been many instances where people have not behaved in accordance with the Westminster principle.

Under the Westminster principle we should have an apolitical Public Service; that is, a public service which merely serves the government of the day to the best of its ability with the best research and effort that is possible. Unfortunately, that is no longer the case either. Although there are first-class, splendid public servants who wish to perform in that way, through the influence of the current government we have public servants in senior positions who are very political in the way they behave.

So we look at what is an alternative to a Westminster system should we have an elected president. One model we can look at is the congressional system in the United States. There it has a true doctrine of the separation of powers, not as we have here. Here, although we have the judiciary separate from the legislature and the executive, we do not separate the executive and the legislature. Our ministers come from the legislative body, in this chamber and across the way, but under the congressional system, where there is a true doctrine of the separation of powers in operation, the executive comes by way of appointment by the president from people outside the elected congress. It may well be that, if we were to move to an elected presidential system, the people of Australia may also consider that to move to an appointed executive outside the elected membership may be a better way to proceed. It is often heard in debate from people who criticise the calibre of the ministers—and anyone who sees this chamber on B-day when the B-team is in can see it—that there is a lot lacking.

The point is this: if we are to embrace the thought of change and have a true debate, we need a forum where it can be held honestly. This is not the place for that debate because here, under our Westminster system—altered and perhaps corrupted as it is—we still have the system where the Prime Minister, the person who says he has a majority in the House to support the passage of the appropriation bills through both houses of parliament, is given a commission to form a government by the head of state, the Governor-General, Bill Hayden; and he looked pretty Australian to me last time I took a look. That government then consists of the people chosen by the Prime Minister, the man to whom the commission is given. He currently selects about 30 people to become members of the Executive Council. Those people and those people alone form the government. The Labor Party backbenchers are no more members of government than I am. Their responsibility is the same as mine; that is, to provide laws which are for the peace, order and good government of the people of Australia. Their positioning on the right-hand side of the Speaker's chair is merely to indicate that they are giving support to the government to ensure the passage of its legislation and particularly the appropriation bills—the granting of supply.

We saw in 1975 that it is the Governor-General who is the head of state in this country, who holds the reserve powers, who has the power to sack the government of the day, which simply means he or she withdraws the commission that has been given because that government can no longer carry out its undertaking to ensure the passage of supply. So that is the way the system works. But, if we are to have the change to the president, we could see the situation where the president of the day has been elected by two-thirds of the parliament, as the Prime Minister would wish, and he sends his legislation up to the head of state and the head of state says, `Veto.' The Prime Minister says, `You can't do that to me.' `Yes, I can,' says the president, `just watch me. Now get two-thirds of the parliament to sack me.' It might be a piece of legislation like the new 12 per cent wholesale sales tax with regard to building materials that might be chosen to be vetoed, and two-thirds of the parliament might think that is a jolly good idea.

There are lots of questions that have to be addressed. There are lots of queries and uncertainties that need to be debated, and the place to have that is in a people's forum, because in this place it is only the government of the day that can introduce the bill for the referendum. It is only the government which would have input into what goes into that bill and it would be a take it or leave it scenario. But, if you have a people's convention, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has proposed and given an undertaking to have, the people who are not truly represented in their view, as they see it, will have a say. The government of the day has said it will only offer a president who is elected by the parliament, and the people of Australia have shown that they do not want that, and it is only the government of the day which will have a say as to what goes into that bill that brings about the referendum.

However, under our system, there is even a fail-safe mechanism. There is the people's convention, and then there is a plebiscite. The plebiscite would have the following options: elected by the parliament, elected by the people, status quo, et cetera. So a whole range of things could come out of that. Depending on the outcome of that plebiscite, the referendum would then be formulated. It would not be formulated by the government of the day. It would not be formulated by the now Prime Minister saying, `I, me, myself, personally, Paul Keating, am going to dictate that that is the choice you will be given,' but by the option being given to hundreds of Australians to have the opportunity to take part in the discussion process.

I have always said that, once we got into the detail, the nature of the debate on the republic would change dramatically, and it has. We are now looking at the detail in earnest. We are looking at the ramifications. We are looking at what we want—from now and forever more—as our system of governance. The government has answered the first question by putting up a proposal. It is one which I reject. The opposition offers a more acceptable alternative.

The second question—how it makes Australia a better place—remains to be answered by those who say they want to bring about the change as manifested in the Prime Minister's greater wish. As we debate this, we know that the option is one of choice. The government offers none. The option is to take what the Prime Minister of the day wishes it to be or to allow the people of Australia to have a say in what happens to their constitution. The bottom line is that the constitution of Australia belongs to the Australian people. It does not belong to the Prime Minister or to the government of the day. It is not their plaything. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) should know that no-one suggests that the Australian constitution is anything but the property of the Australian people. For any person in this House to suggest that any member of this House has a different view is an outrageous lie. It is simply not true.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—I think the honourable member for McEwen should—

TALK.START.PARA: —If it offends the House, then I withdraw the expression `lie' and I will say that it is an `untruth'.
—I would be grateful.

—I withdraw `outrageous lie' and say `outrageous untruth', which is within the forms of the House. It is an untruth. It is a nonsense to suggest that a constitution of the type that Australia has is anything but the property of the people. It is the same as suggesting that this parliament is owned by the politicians who inhabit it. It is not. It is a product of the will of the Australian people. I reject the nonsense spoken by some members on the other side of the House.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Mackellar has, like other members of the opposition, put up this furphy that the Governor-General is the head of state of Australia. It is an absolute nonsense. Either they do not understand what the Australian constitution is or they have not read it. The Australian constitution is, in fact, a bill of the British parliament. It clearly defines that the head of state of Australia is the monarch of Great Britain whom, in some strange way, we call the Queen of Australia.

However, the reality is that the British monarch is simply that—the British monarch. Queen Elizabeth II is a fine and upright woman. I have met her, and I have nothing but admiration for her. Nevertheless, she is the monarch of Great Britain. By some strange legal reasoning, Australia has decided to adopt her and call her the Queen of Australia. Clearly, the head of state is the British monarch. So no-one in the coalition should try to promote this nonsense that somehow the Governor-General is the Australian head of state.

The Governor-General's role in the Australian constitution is as a representative of Australia's head of state. The role of the Governor-General is to represent the Queen in Australia and to be the representative of Her Majesty in the Executive Council under the formulation and the rules which exist in the Australian constitution.

When we have a debate such as this, the lack of understanding in this House on the nature of the Australian constitution is also something that worries me. The constitution is a document which is vacant on most of the important things that matter in running this parliament. For example, most Australians do not understand that there is no such thing as a Prime Minister mentioned in the entire Australian constitution. It is not mentioned—not once. It is a convention that there is a Prime Minister. It is not written into our constitution. It is a convention, because we all understand that without the conventions operating we would not have a constitution which would work.

So the Australian constitution is lacking in almost everything that a modern constitution needs. We are only talking about one part of it—a minor part of it. I must say that, if I had my way, I would rewrite the entire constitution, because it is a terribly deficient document. Can you imagine having a constitution which does not recognise the position of Prime Minister? It does not mention the word once in the entire document. It operates only on the basis of what we call conventions. Conventions are simply unwritten rules which people in the political system accept as being proper and reasonable so that the system can in fact run. Without the recognition of the conventions, we would not have a parliament that would work. That is how bad the Australian constitution really is.

To some members opposite it is some sacred document written in blood—something magical and special. The fact is, of course, that when it was written it was written in conflict. It was a compromise. It is not a perfect document. It was a compromise between six competing colonies who were not particularly interested in a federation. They wanted to maintain their own separate political identities. There were free traders and protectionists. Again, I do wish some people in this House would actually pick up a book on Australian history and read it. I do wish they would actually learn the background to how the Australian constitution came into existence.

The vast bulk of conventions, so-called, that were held to draft the Australian constitution were not elected. Only one was elected—the last one. But the conventions that actually drew up the constitution were not elected because, in most locally held referenda, the Australian people did not want to federate. It was the leaders of the day, who understood the great need for Australia to become a great nation, who led the arguments and brought the general feeling of the people with them. That is what needs to be done in changing a constitution. You need leaders. You need people to stand up and put a proposition to people and say, `We believe we need change and this is the change we believe we need.' That is called leadership. It might be that the Australian people reject that view. Nevertheless, the fact that it has been brought into the public domain, that it is now a topic which is being publicly debated, is only because there is a leader—the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is not the sort of thing we would ever get from the other side of the House. There is never any leadership from that side in terms of change.

The Australian constitution was developed by people such as Deakin, despite the general lack of will in the then colonies to federate. We eventually got federation because there were leaders back then who were prepared to carry the people, take some political flak and run the argument. So it is important that the argument be put. It is important that we debate it. It may well be that the end result of change to the Australian constitution may not be what I necessarily agree with because, ultimately, it will be Australian people who make the decision—not me, not this parliament, not the Prime Minister, but the Australian people. However, it is proper that views are put on what sorts of changes we, collectively or individually, see as necessary.

I have probably given more oaths to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, her heirs and successors to title than most other Australians. From the cubs, the scouts and the venturers, to the police force, the citizen's military forces and local government, as a justice of the peace and on being admitted as a barrister and solicitor of Victoria and of New South Wales—I have given oaths to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, her heirs and successors to title so how many times that I have lost count of them. Why? It is because she is the nominal head of state. But, as an Australian, I have always wondered why I am being asked to pledge my loyalty to Queen Elizabeth II of England. She is a nice person.

TALK.START.PARA: —Likes dogs.

—Likes dogs, corgis. I have got no beef with her. I have been privileged to meet with her on more than one occasion. On the other hand, she is not an Australian citizen; she is a foreigner. That is an unarguable fact. She does not have Australian citizenship. She is a foreigner. I have often wondered when I have taken multiple oaths over the years why I was being asked as an Australian to give an oath of loyalty and allegiance to a British monarch. I am pleased that finally I am getting the chance to say in this parliament that I am an Australian first, an Australian second, an Australian third, and I would like to have an Australian head of state. There is nothing wrong with that.

PARA.TAB: Some people can disagree with it. Some people can say they are happy to have a British citizen as the head of state of Australia. That is an acceptable view if that is what they want. But I am an Australian, and I want an Australian head of state. I do not want to be represented by a foreigner—be that foreigner British, American or whatever. If people want to criticise me for that, let them. If they want to be represented by a foreigner, let them stand up and say that. That is the major issue that has to be first answered: do Australians want an Australian head of state or do Australians want a foreign head of state?

We can debate all of these things, but until members of the opposition answer that principal question we will not get to first base because their proposals, quite frankly, avoid the issue. The whole philosophy behind the approach of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) of having a convention of which 50 per cent would be elected and 50 per cent appointed by him—no doubt, as Prime Minister—is to avoid the issue. It is to avoid having to put a question to the people in the first place. It is the way the conservatives of this country want to avoid the debate. It puts it away, puts it aside, and does not solve the issue.

Why is there a fear of the debate? Are the conservatives of this country and in this parliament frightened of the debate because they have not got the numbers out there? Is that the reason they would go for this quite nonsensical approach of having 50 per cent appointed by the Leader of the Opposition, no doubt, and 50 per cent elected. We do not know how they are going to be elected or what the franchise would be. We do not know anything about how the other 50 per cent would be elected. We do not know what reference the convention would be given. We do not know what they would be asked to discuss, what the details are of what the convention would be asked to do.

Assuming this convention accepted the view that Australia should change to an Australian head of state, we have no guarantee at all from the opposition that it would do it. If the opposition is elected, puts up its convention and, despite having 50 per cent of its members appointed so that it can control them, the convention recommends that there be a referendum, a minimalist position, and accepts an Australian as an Australian head of state, there is no guarantee a conservative government would put it to the Australian people. It is a nonsense.

What is their fear? Why are honourable members frightened of asking the Australian people? I frankly do not understand it. I do not understand why anyone in this parliament would be frightened of the Australian people having the choice. The proposition put forward by the Leader of the Opposition denies that choice, takes it away from people and stifles the process.

I am totally baffled as to why the opposition is frightened of the Australian people and frightened of why they should not have that choice. I noted that the member for Mackellar was talking about the Public Service in Australia and the apolitical nature she thinks it should have. The implication of what she said is that the Public Service in Australia is politicised. That was the allegation she put to the House in this debate.

If there has ever been a politicised body in this country it was when Barwick went to the High Court, as Chief Justice Barwick. When Barwick was the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia the Australian taxation system was totally torn asunder. Under section 260 of the tax act, a very simple section—I would say a five-year-old child could tell you what it meant—tax avoidance was illegal. That is all it said, but somehow or other the Barwick court managed to rule that that did not mean anything. Under Barwick, people of privilege and people of wealth were given the option of paying no tax.

Professor Russell clearly demonstrated in a report to this House that, under Barwick and under this apolitical system that the honourable member for Mackellar suggests applies when the opposition is in government, the taxation system was destroyed. Who was the Treasurer who did nothing to stem the rapid outflow of revenue at the time? The now Leader of the Opposition. Let us have none of this nonsense, this waffle, from the member for Mackellar about this government criticising the Public Service. We know full well how it is done because over the years we have seen just how good the opposition is at destroying legislation through its mates getting the jobs.

I support an Australian republic; I have long supported an Australian republic. My ancestors came here in 1776; they were British; they married into Irish stock on my father's side. No-one has better credibility in this debate, and I support a republic. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech of the previous speaker, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), was somewhat lacking in credibility when he was starting to presume what the opposition position is. It is quite clear that a people's convention will be called and that it will decide which questions go to a referendum. The Australian people will have the chance to decide whether we remain a monarchy or move to a republic. Nothing could be clearer than that.

PARA.TAB: I find it quite bizarre that we are having this debate in the chamber for most of the day when there are other issues out there that are concerning my constituents more than this. We have a debt in this country, for example, that is greater than Mexico's. It is unbelievable that we have been reduced to that status under this government. A debt greater than Mexico's is something that we ought to be ashamed of, something that we certainly should be doing something about, and the government will not even allow us to have a question time tomorrow to talk about the current account deficit figures when they come out, let alone have a debate on the debt that this country is carrying, which is now greater than Mexico's.

In this country we have public hospital health queue numbers which run to six figures, the federal government has virtually halved federal road funding, and we have three-quarters of a million unemployed. We are just, hopefully, coming out of one of the worst droughts in history and, while farmers are still being denied a basic, civilised type of welfare system because of a government that could not care less, it seems, about people who are destitute, even though they are people who are contributing to the country, we are here today having a debate on the republic.

A debate on the republic will cost the parliament, depending how long it goes, something like $200,000 or $300,000 today alone. I would like to have that money, for example, for three kilometres of bitumen between Bourke and Wanaaring. I am sure my constituents out there would prefer that. But why are we having this debate? We are having it because the government is using it as a diversionary tactic from the problems, some of which I have just mentioned, that are besetting this country, and apparently because of the apparent paranoia of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about anything that is British.

In the 11 years that I have been a member of parliament I have not had one constituent come to my office and request that Australia move toward a republic. I have not had one person telephone me and I have not had one letter on the subject. I do not deny that there may be people out there who hold this view, which is quite right and proper to have in a democracy, but it is obviously not a burning issue with them. There are 80,000 voters in my electorate and 110,000 constituents when you count those under 18 years—and never in 11 years has anyone approached me on this particular matter. They certainly are not tossing and turning in their sleep about this issue; I can assure the government of that.

Despite that, this government is going ahead with the proposal. The referendum alone is going to cost about $50 million. No doubt literature will go out to every household in Australia putting the for and the against case beforehand and that will cost several million dollars more. We have a debt worse than Mexico's debt and yet these are the sorts of things being proposed.

Why are the Australian people not demanding that this happen in the same way as the government is demanding it happen? The reasons are that they have other problems which they give a higher priority to and that they are relatively happy with the system that we have in this country. We have a stable system of government that is envied by the rest of the world. We live in a very free country, a very tolerant, multicultural country. We have a system that has delivered a very high standard of living. It is a country that has allowed us to express the unique Australian characteristic that this continent has bestowed on all of us.

We are even a member of the Commonwealth of Nations and it is interesting to note that 22 out of the 51 members are still monarchies; the others are republics. It is a little ironic to me because I have always felt that in a sense Australia really is a republic. I know we call it a monarchy but to all intents and purposes, given the way the system works in this country, we already are a republic. I do not know what the percentage would be but Australia would be very close to 99 per cent a republic anyhow. We have only got this little bit tacked on the end, this one per cent, this monarchy bit tacked on the end, and it is totally harmless. It gives the Queen no effective power whatsoever over the running of this country. If the Queen had some power to direct us how to conduct the laws of this nation or our daily lives, I too would be arguing that that link be cut. But the Queen has no power whatsoever to direct us in how we conduct our business in this country. Even if she did, while we might listen we would not respond.

Concerning this little bit tacked on the end, the poms pay for it anyhow. It is not as though it is a cost to us, for heaven's sake. They pay for it. It seems to me that we are getting the best of both worlds. We have the best of both systems. We have the best of a republican system—which essentially we are—and the best of a monarchical system because of this little bit tacked on the end.

I can cast my mind back to the experiences that I have had. Two or three years ago the Queen came to Dubbo. I was walking a step behind her for most of the day during the activities and I was staggered at the welcome that the people on the footpaths gave her and the emotion they showed. It amazed me.

A year or so ago, Prince Charles had some dreadful difficulties in his private life. At that time, he visited Parkes and Forbes for a day. I was curious to see how the public would react to him after all the adverse publicity he had received. However, it did not seem to make any difference. There were crowds the size of which had never been seen before in Parkes and Forbes, and those people were all willing to wish Prince Charles well. I thought, `This costs us nothing. The public seem to love it. Why deny them the pleasure they seem to get from this sort of thing?'

In the mid-1980s, when I had been a member of the House for a short time, I attended a peace conference in Bulgaria. In those days Bulgaria was probably the most repressive communist country in the world. It is a wonderful country and, fortunately, that system has now gone. I had never been to a communist country before, and apart from the stark, colourless concrete buildings and streets everywhere, and the people with blank looks on their faces, the thing that horrified me the most was that on the buildings were enormous photos of Marx, Engels, Lenin and Todor Zhikov, who was the president of Bulgaria at the time.

The monarchy had been banished in Bulgaria. It had been made illegal. Religion had also been outlawed. It dawned on me for the first time in my life that the average man and woman in the street likes to have someone to look up to. It can be argued that it is illogical. It is illogical, but the average man and woman in the street likes to look up to someone. If the monarchy is banished and religion is banished, all that is left is the politicians. What could be more unhealthy than to have people looking up to politicians in that way? I found it quite repulsive.

The system we have in Australia—even though I have said that it is essentially a republican one already—allows us, because of this little bit we have tacked onto the end, to avoid the worst elements of a republic that exist in many other countries. Those elements are ugly, costly and colourless, even in the world's great countries.

I have recently returned from looking at the political system in America. When I was visiting the White House, President Clinton drove past. I was standing on the footpath with hundreds of people when he drove past. Some women standing in front of me were almost swooning because the President had driven past. Yet he is an elected representative. It was not an edifying spectacle. It is wrong that elected representatives should be looked up to in that way. It is best to have non-elected representatives fill those positions.

It needs to be asked, if we have a republic—and to be frank, I do not lose any sleep over it one way or the other—what will it give us? I dare say it will give a warm inner glow to those on the other side of the chamber. If that is something that they cherish, then good luck to them, but it is not going to affect my life much one way or the other. It is no guarantee that things are going to get better.

Let us examine republics around the world. One that we would have admired—France—is letting off nuclear explosions. Germany does not have a system that I admire. I would not like to transplant America's system here, having just had a look at it. The system in other republics—such as Russia or Ethiopia—is not for me.

The system we have today, with this little bit tacked on, reflects our history. I do not want to deny our history. I am proud of it. The system of justice in this country emanates from Great Britain. The system of democracy that we have in Australia, which I think is the finest in the world, comes from Great Britain. The system of education in this country, which we cherish so much, comes from that part of the world. The language that we speak also comes from that part of the world. This country has the best systems in the world. Yet the government says that we have to become mature, take that final step and totally cut the links with Great Britain.

I can see some logic to that argument. But it is a little like a child leaving home who refuses to have his or her parents come and visit once in while, or to let them have any influence whatsoever, even of a symbolic type. I think it is a sign of maturity, not a sign of immaturity, that we still have this. It adds colour to our lives. I just gave the example of the socialist republic of Bulgaria, which was totally colourless in the mid-1980s. If we want to take away the system that we have got now, well and good, but I think we will be at least a little diminished by it.

There will be significant changes, even down to the trivial things. I just looked at my local telephone directory, which is mainly based on Dubbo, and found there were 24 royal prefixes in the telephone book. In the Sydney phone book, there were 189. I see that Senator McMullan, in a press release of some time ago, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is inappropriate for national organisations to be seeking to add themselves to the list of those with royal titles.
This is the sort of directive, no doubt, that will be emanating more rapidly from the government when we do become a republic.

PARA.TAB: Is it such a crime that we call a yacht club `The Royal Yacht Club', or a blind society `The Royal Blind Society'? What are we are going to change the name of the flying doctor service to? Will we call it the `Republic Flying Doctor Service', instead of the `Royal Flying Doctor Service', so we can keep the same initials and not add the cost of changing the emblem?

TALK.START.PARA: —What's wrong with calling it the `Australian Flying Doctor Service'? What is wrong with you people, for heaven's sake?

—There is nothing wrong with calling it `Australian'. If the people, of their own free will and volition, choose to call it that, what is wrong with that, in a democracy? What is wrong with that? To be frank with you, it does not trouble me much, one way or another. But here is the government giving directives that one must not call the flying doctor service the `Royal Flying Doctor Service'. I think it is a farcical stage that we have reduced ourselves to.

PARA.TAB: What is next? Are we going to change the name of Queensland, for obvious reasons, or change the name of Victoria because it resembles `Queen Victoria'? Presumably, New South Wales will be next, because it resembles somewhere in Wales. Where do we end with this? Is the Prime Minister embarrassed when he is overseas, because we have a so-called queen as head of state? Is he going to be embarrassed to go into a pub to have a beer because it is called the Royal Hotel? Is that what the government has next in line for us? What a farce. One wonders where it will all stop.

The solution that the government has put up is the Tippex solution: we will cross out `governor-general' and write in `president'. It is much more complicated than that. I am sorry I do not have time to elaborate on those arguments. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: My first memory of the monarchy comes from 1 May 1970, when, as a nine-year-old student at Ashcroft Primary School, I lined the street to watch Princess Anne pass by on her way to opening the Green Valley Community Centre. I was there because the school had made it compulsory. For me, it was a curiosity. For a schoolboy standing on the streets of working-class Green Valley, nothing could have been more curious than the idea that we were, in any way, associated with a family—the royal family—founded on the worst traditions of social hierarchy, elitism and class distinction. For a schoolboy born in Australia, knowing nothing of Britain other than from school books, nothing could be more foreign than the idea that we were in some way affiliated to Britain.

PARA.TAB: For Australians of my generation, without memories of or emotions for Britain, Australian independence is a natural feeling. That is what makes the Republic so inevitable: the natural feeling of Australian independence. This is what makes this debate, and the historic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), so compelling.

There is something special about feeling proud of one's country. In most respects, national pride is at the heart of this debate. To feel proud of Australia—to feel strongly about this country—is to want Australia to be strong. We are stronger when we stand on our own two feet, when we do things our way and when we express ourselves in an independent way. Let there be no doubt—we would be stronger, as a people and as a nation, if the Australian head of state were an Australian citizen. Indeed, the move to the republic is part of Australia's growing maturity, and part of our passage from adolescence to adulthood as a nation.

If I can continue the analogy further, the formulation of the Australian constitution from the 1890s led to Australia's birth as a federated nation in 1901. In this debate it is very important to get a feel and appreciation for the national mood and the politics of that era, now 100 years ago. Australia had, as its earliest and strongest emotion—this goes back as far as 1788—the need for protection, the need to shelter the colony, as it was at that time, from what was regarded as a vulnerable place in the world. It is not surprising, if we consider how insecure those early Australians would have been at the thought of being part of a penal colony. Two hundred years ago Australia was a convict colony at the bottom of the world, isolated from what, at that time, was the homeland in Europe.

As a result of those feelings of insecurity at the very first time of white settlement in Australia, this feeling of protection was woven into our culture, our institutions and our system of government. The sense of insecurity and the need for protection was given expression through tariff protection, the attempt to shelter Australian markets from overseas goods. It was expressed through the White Australia policy which enjoyed bipartisan political support for so long, giving expression to the feeling that we needed to lock out people from other races and other nations, particularly in Asia.

The sense of insecurity was expressed through our foreign policy: our reliance on the protection of, firstly, the Royal Navy and, during and after the Second World War, the United States of America. It was also expressed through the cultural cringe: the feeling that the only worthwhile items of culture and expression could come from Britain. Robert Hughes, in his outstanding book, The Fatal Shore, captures the mood so well:

SPEECH.PARA: The idea that whether or not England should feel ashamed of creating the [convict] system, Australians certainly had cause to be proud of surviving it and creating their own values despite it, was rarely heard.
In Australia at that time, and indeed for more than a century, Britain was seen as the only source of social respectability. Again, according to Hughes:

Nothing could be allowed to diminish the gratitude Australians were meant to feel for the imperial umbrella. The essence of colonisation was that they could claim no history of their own . . . educators played their part, with the result that it became impossible to find in any history book in any Australian schools up to the mid-1960s, a satisfactory or even coherent account of penal Australia.

In this respect, British trade, British arts, British literature, British symbols, British institutions and, most of all, the British monarchy, were used by Australians for so many decades of our early history as part of the search for respectability. For the tories of that time—and for the tories of this time—it was all about touching the hem of the British monarchy, that feeling of cultural insecurity and cultural cringe, and the search for what was regard as social respectability.

PARA.TAB: The popular culture of those years of course reinforced the view of the British as a superior race of people. The royal family stood at the pinnacle of that system. The republic is about breaking the cultural cringe for all time. It is about recognising, for all time, that Australia should assume in all aspects of our social and cultural fabric the responsibilities of an independent and mature nation. The cultural cringe extended far beyond the realm of the arts. For so many years, it made the country wary of assuming proper responsibili ties.

But we have broken free and matured and picked up responsibilities in so many areas. We show confidence in the way we have internationalised our economy; we no longer feel insecure about pursuing a place in the world economy. We have matured and picked up responsibilities through an independent defence and foreign policy. We have picked up responsibilities through transport and communication improvements which have integrated Australia as a nation.

We have picked up responsibility in culture, in the arts and letters, with a distinctive and a very proud sense of Australian cultural identity. We have picked up our proper responsibilities towards Aboriginal people with the historic decision of the High Court and the legislation of this parliament for native title.

The republic and constitutional change in the 1990s is about topping up that process, breaking the cringe for all time. In our constitutional arrangements we should exercise the proper responsibilities of a mature, independent nation by making an Australian our head of state. Breaking the cringe says something about Australia's identity and our sense of worth.

The republic in many respects should be seen as a celebration of the Australian achievement. Far from cringing, we should be telegraphing it and informing the world that we are very proud of what we have achieved in this nation, to settle a harsh country and build economic prosperity. To do it within a tolerant, progressive, egalitarian society is one of the great achievements of the Western world, and constitutional independence can top it off. Constitutional independence would be the full expression of nationhood and the ultimate celebration of the great Australia achievement. The Economist magazine said it well in June of last year:

SPEECH.PARA: Only colonies continue to borrow the monarchies of other lands.

I would urge the Liberal and National party representatives in this house to take a look across the Tasman, where a small trading nation at the bottom of the South Pacific, led in that instance by a conservative government, is breaking free of the colonial mentality. Jim Bolger, the New Zealand Prime Minister, is trying to advance the cause of a New Zealand republic. Let me quote Bolger:
I see it as completing the journey from colony to nationhood.

New Zealand is in similar circumstances to Australia in the broad sweep of history. Its Prime Minister, a conservative Prime Minister, sees the republic as completing the journey from colony to nationhood. As it is in New Zealand, it should be in Australia.

PARA.TAB: More than that, the republic represents a great opportunity to rectify some of the problems with the constitutional monarchy. At the end of the day, in a modern, liberal, progressive, egalitarian society, the monarchy can be regarded, and I think broadly is regarded, throughout Australia as unrepresentative and undemocratic. There is an objection across the nation to filling public offices in a fashion which relies on inheritance. It is contrary to the belief that all people are born equal in status, dignity and opportunity. The rules of succession for the monarchy as we have them in Australia discriminate on the basis of religion, sex and birth. Section 116 of the Australia constitution prohibits the imposition of any religious test as a qualification for any office under the Commonwealth, yet our head of state, the British monarch, also serves as the head of the Anglican Church.

Further, our own Sex Discrimination Act would render the rules of succession unlawful in Australia, because they discriminate actively for men and discriminate against women. For Australians interested in social equality, religious tolerance and equal opportunity between the sexes, the monarchy has become an unrepresentative, unsuitable, divisive institution in our society. It has been used in the past to show that Australians were of British stock. That is clearly no longer the case. The monarchy is perhaps well suited to a class ridden society like Britain, but it is totally unsuited to Australia's egalitarian traditions.
Francis Adams in his Australian Essays put it best as long ago as 1886:

SPEECH.PARA: The people in Australia breathe free. They do not feel the weight of the great divisions of the middle class that is above them, the well-to-do and the gentlemen. Working men here do not go slouching down the streets, as they do in England, crushed under the sense of their inferiority. . . This is a true republic, the truest, as I take it, in the world. In England the average man feels that he is inferior: in America he feels that he is superior: in Australia he feels that he is equal. That is indeed delightful.

So, if we have had in our social status, in our social fabric, this feeling of republic egalitarianism, it should be fully confirmed now in the 1990s in Australia's constitutional arrangements. For once, on this matter I can agree with the founder of the Liberal Party, Sir Robert Menzies. He said in the second reading speech on the Royal Style and Titles Bill 1953:
The plain truth is that Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second sits on the throne not because of some law of Australia but because of the law of the United Kingdom.

Menzies thought that was acceptable because he regarded himself as British, as of British stock. But now, when Australians no longer regard themselves in that fashion, it is no longer suitable for the Australian head of state to be determined by British law. The Australian head of state should be one of us. The Australian head of state should be determined by Australians under Australian laws passed by this parliament and confirmed at a constitutional referendum.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that an Australian citizen, under the current arrangements, can never be the Australian head of state. That is a decisive breach, an unacceptable breach, of Australian sovereignty and independence. It is interesting to note that Prince Charles himself acknowledged as much in June last year when he said that, as an heir and successor, he would rather be seen as a defender of faith than a defender of `the faith'. That is, he acknowledged that all citizens are equally important irrespective of religion. It is divisive for the monarchy to be associated with just one form and one expression of faith.

Prince Charles also said that it is absurd the monarch should be prevented from marrying a Catholic. So if Prince Charles believes the monarchy, as presently structured, does not represent all Britons, how can it represent all Australians? Prince Charles is saying that the head of state in Britain must be representative of British society. In Australia, surely that means the head of state must be an Australian.

A republic is a state in which sovereignty is derived from people, not from inheritance, and in which all public offices are filled by persons ultimately deriving their authority from the people. The only Australian office incompatible with a republic is the monarchy, and the only change required to overcome that shortcoming is to remove the monarchy from our constitution.

When the Queen visits Australia she is seen more as the Queen of Britain than the Queen of Australia, otherwise she serves as an absentee head of state. When the Queen visits other nations, she is seen as the Queen of Britain. Australia does not have a head of state who can represent this nation overseas and be seen by foreign citizens as our head of state, as an Australian. That, in their eyes, makes Australia look like a colony. Some of the comments of the British head of state when she travels overseas could potentially contradict Australian foreign policy and trade interests.

The truth is this: not only is the monarchy unrepresentative and undemocratic by the standards of the 1990s but also the royal family itself is discredited. I noticed in the Australian newspaper earlier this month that the British Scout Association has decided to disaffiliate itself from Prince Charles, saying, `It will be hard for some people to promise'—that is, to swear—`their allegiance of duty to an adulterer.' What a telltale sign—that the British monarchy in the 1990s cannot sustain the support of the British Scout Association. For the monarchy as an institution, particularly in this country, it is five minutes to midnight. Time is up for the monarchy. It is time for Australia to express itself as a mature, independent, egalitarian and progressive nation. It is time we had an Australian as our head of state. We need to make sure that our head of state is one of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting debate that has been taking place today with regard to the speech made on an Australian republic by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The state of play between the political parties involved, as far as that goes, is the main area I want to address in speaking on this matter this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: At this stage, it has predominantly been a political debate. It is far too important an issue to contemplate it being controlled by politics.
Mr Latham interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is. You have had your go. We should be empowering the people of Australia to participate in the whole process of developing the models if we are going to go down this path. The government of today will present to the people of Australia the option that they vote either yes or no on how to go about this, how to develop it, how to structure this move. As has been indicated in the polls, the majority of people in Australia do not agree with that system either. The government should be very cognisant of that fact.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), served a fairly lengthy time in local government, where people demand a say. I also have a background in local government. He was probably elected to the mayoral position, which he held before he came into this place, by popular vote as well. It is the absolute basis of the democratic process of Australia. You cannot devolve the power any lower than to give all the people a say in who leads them or in what happens in the country.

It is interesting to note that the government speakers in this debate today have been running the line that the Prime Minister has been running—that is, we want an Australian as our head of state. That is an interesting argument when the occupant of the position of Governor-General has, since 1965, always been an Australian. That is the political angle that the government is trying to put on this debate. It is trying to generate a bit more anti-British emotion.

Earlier this year I had the opportunity to visit the United Kingdom with a group of young Australian people from the Labor Party, the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Democrats. When talking to different people throughout the United Kingdom, the one dominant question was: is the government's push or the notion of moving towards a republic in Australia purely born out of a hate for the British? That is the feeling that they are getting in the United Kingdom. We had to dispel that myth and point out that it is not born out of a hate for the British. We pointed out that, unfortunately, that is the line the Prime Minister of Australia is running. We have heard this line from some of the government speakers in this debate.

There are a lot of people in Australia who believe that we should be moving towards a republic, but who do not hold the same views as the government. Some people hold the view that maybe Australia has reached the stage where it is going through puberty blues or a change in identity and therefore it is time to revisit the issues. It is really the people of Australia who should be having an input. It should not be the 148 representatives in this parliament who make a decision and make this into a political debate between now and when the Prime Minister decides he wants to hold his referendum and ask the people of Australia whether or not they are prepared to accept his option.

The coalition's position is that the people of Australia should be involved in this discussion from the beginning. We believe that they should be involved all the way through. The people of Australia should make the decision when we have the constitutional referendum before the turn of the century. What is wrong with giving the people of Australia a decent dose of democracy? It is about time that a few more people around this place—particularly those on the government side—recognised that we do live in a democratic society and that we should be giving the people of Australia a dose of democracy in relation to this issue.

What are the positions at this point? The government has declared that Australia should become a republic by the year 2001. It keeps running the line that the head of state should be an Australian. The opposition says that since 1965 the Governor-General, as the Australian head of state, has been an Australian.

The key proposal advanced by the government in terms of the establishment of a federal republic is the election of a federal president. It says that the president should be an Australian and elected by a two-thirds majority in a joint sitting of both houses of parliament on the nomination of the Prime Minister and cabinet. The government also believes that the question of Australia becoming a republic should be put to the people in 1998 or 1999.

What is the coalition's position? The coalition proposes the establishment of a people's convention in 1997 which would examine not just whether or not Australia should become a republic but other important issues as well. One of the issues is the role of the head of state in the Australian constitution. Another issue is the implications of a change in the role of the states. There is an underlying complication in this debate which relates to the states. The conundrum could arise where the Commonwealth as a whole wants to head down a certain path but one of the states does not.

Other issues that should be addressed at a people's convention are the allocation of legislative and executive powers and functions between federal and state governments, including areas of overlap and duplication; whether we should introduce four-year instead of three-year terms of parliament; and the basis on which new states, in particular the Northern Territory, would be admitted to the federation. Other matters which the people's convention would determine itself would also be discussed.

The people's convention would consist of 50 per cent of members who have been appointed by the government of the day, 10 per cent of whom would be between the ages of 18 and 25, and 50 per cent of members who have been elected. The arguments for a people's convention, as put forward by the coalition, include enabling a range of community views to enable proper examination, gauging the mood for change in the Australian community, and providing a forum which unifies rather than divides the community. As I said earlier, we need to devolve power to the lowest possible level and empower the people of Australia with the ability to participate in the development of this debate from start to finish. This provides a forum which unifies rather than divides the community.

The Prime Minister says that you are either for the republic or you are against it. He says, `Either you stand over there or you stand over here with me.' That is not unifying this nation. If that is what the republican debate today is all about, I do not believe it is going down the right path. We should allow the people of Australia to decide the questions and the options for the referendum. We should involve all Australian people at the beginning, the middle and the end of the process. This would create a unifying position for the people of Australia. We should have a broader group of people than the government of the day deciding the arguments for and against, putting the propositions for and against, and developing the questions to be asked in the constitutional referendum.

The crux of this whole issue relates to how much say and how much democracy the government is prepared to give the people of Australia. By `say' I am not just referring to what is written in the newspapers; I am referring to constructive criticism about this whole debate and the direction we are heading in.

The current constitutional arrangements have served Australia well, delivering great stability, cohesion and tolerance. Those points cannot be undermined or debated by the government. Australia is one of the most stable countries in the world today, and this is because of our constitutional arrangements.

The Prime Minister's comments about an Australian head of state are an attempt to imply that anyone who opposes a republic is a lesser Australian. The reality is that, over the past 30 years, the Governor-General has become Australia's constitutional head of state. That position has been occupied by an Australian since 1965. It is unthinkable that anyone but an Australian would occupy that position in the future.

Despite the success of the present constitution, many Australians are attracted to the idea of a republic. The coalition believes that the matter should be fully debated and that ultimately a vote should be taken on the issue before the turn of the century. In government, the coalition will in 1997 establish a people's convention to debate the whole issue. Other matters will be discussed at the people's convention. However, the issue of Australia's head of state will be debated first and separate from all other issues.

If a consensus emerges from the people's convention regarding the head of state, that consensus will be promoted by the government at a constitutional referendum. If no consensus emerges, then the Australian people will be asked to vote on a series of options for changes to establish which of them they desire. These options for change will include that of electing the president by direct popular vote as well as by a parliamentary vote as proposed by the Prime Minister. Another method of election could also emerge as an option from the whole process of discussion. Naturally, the option of retaining the present system would be included in any vote.

The fact is that the government, particularly the Prime Minister, is facing a bit of a problem at the moment. As has been indicated in some of the polls that have been conducted since the speeches of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on this issue, the level of support around Australia for a republic is about 50 per cent.

Yet there has been another interesting element to the poll; that is, the question of how we arrive at that position, whether directly via the Prime Minister's approach—come and vote on my development for a republic, on how I want to have it—or via the Leader of the Opposition's process of a people's convention, having a broader base of discussion and debate. It is interesting that 38 per cent supported the approach of holding a people's convention to discuss constitutional reform compared with 36 per cent support for the Keating republican blueprint.

What does that tell you? That tells you that, although there is a view across the nation—as yet not a majority view—that Australia should head down the republican path, the people of Australia want to have more involvement in the early stages of the debate. They do not want to be just dished up with a yes or no answer, whether you have this type of republic and we will select or elect the president this way or the head of state this way. They want to be involved in formulating the arguments on both sides of that debate. They want to be involved from the start, through the middle and towards the finish of that debate.

I think it flies in the face of everything that we stand for in this place as members of this federal parliament, as representatives of the people of Australia, to deny the people of Australia that democratic right in what could possibly be, and arguably will be if we do end up at a constitutional referendum, the most enormous change that we are going to make to the way this country runs, to the constitution of this country, since Federation. I do not believe that the government has the right to deny the people of Australia from having that broader input into that debate in developing those questions.

The challenge is there. The cards are quite clearly on the table. On the one hand, there is the proposal by the government of the day, the Prime Minister's blueprint for a republic, to push towards a constitutional referendum in the latter part of this century. On the other hand, there is the very clear position of the coalition—that in 1997 we head for a people's convention so that we can devolve the debate, devolve the power, and empower the people of Australia to have a much broader input into the development of the arguments for and against the question, and the development of the debate, as to whether we should go towards a republic, whether the head of state should be selected and elected by a two-thirds majority of this parliament, or whether the head of state should be elected by everybody in Australia. The people of Australia have the right to have that decent dose of democracy dished up to them, so they can have input in this debate from the start, through the middle as well as at the end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Ms CRAWFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I start with the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating):

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are all Australians. We share a continent. We share a past, a present and a future. And our Head of State should be one of us.

We have heard much in this discussion about a republic, and it seems that some people feel the very fabric of Australian society is being challenged. Let me say to you that surely the issue of an Australian head of state does go to the heart of the Australian government. It is surely an issue about equality. We need to look at the role of the constitutional monarchy and ask ourselves: who is a monarch? Where do monarchs come from? What gives them authority to rule? What gives them authority to rule is an accident of birth.

PARA.TAB: I think most of us now would recognise that there are values and attitudes within the British monarchy that most of us as Australians would not wish to emulate, nor would we wish to espouse. When we look to our own nation as an Australian we see the kinds of things that make us Australian. At the heart of it is the issue of equality. At the heart of it is the right—more importantly, the obligation—of all Australian citizens to exercise their democratic right to vote. There is no question of a notion of birth, of where one comes from or of who one is. It simply states that as Australians, as citizens of this nation, we have equality before the law and in the role of this government.

It is interesting to hear members of the opposition talk about the notion of stability which comes from a constitutional monarchy. I suggest to members of the opposition that one of the great things that leads to stability within the Australian democratic process is the fact that we all participate, that there is a role for each and every one of us. Contrary to very many other industrialised nations in which small groups of people who happen to be better educated, happen to have more money or happen to be able to buy votes are the people who rule, all Australians vote and we in this parliament represent our electors. In fact, once that election has taken place, we then represent all of those people who reside within that area.

I say to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), who was talking about doses of democracy, that he should run his own discussions on the constitutional monarchy, that he should represent the kinds of views he believes are abroad in his electorate. I suggest that he will find that more than half the people with whom he mixes are enamoured of the idea of an Australian head of state and an Australian republic.

We have also heard comments by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on this notion of a people's convention. The coalition is the same lot of people who say, `Get government off our backs' and `Don't have government interfere.' Suddenly the role of a people's convention, to which it appoints 50 per cent of the people, is now some sacred cow. It is an extraordinary claim that a people's convention to which it appoints half the delegates will be the forum for open and free discussion. What a lot of nonsense.

If we are talking realistically about the notion of a head of state being elected by two-thirds of both houses of this parliament, we can say almost categorically that that person will not be from the field of politics. If, however, we are to have a universally elected head of state, we can absolutely and categorically expect that that person will be either party political or extraordinarily rich. We will be looking at someone who has to garner the votes of 8,000, 9,000 or 10,000 Australians and who needs the wherewithal and the financial capital to do that.

If that person is not a member of one of the two major political parties, which have the structures within our community to do that, that person will have to be a media owner or some other person who is extremely rich. We have seen what has happened in places like Italy where this universally elected president has, by definition, to be somebody who is extraordinarily rich. Look at the American President. He is someone who needs to be extraordinarily rich or have rich and powerful friends.

The election by two-thirds of the House of Representatives and the Senate means that the president will not be a member of either of the major political parties. This person will be chosen in a bipartisan manner. The potential president will also be somebody who is looked upon in the light of the checks and balances which operate within this community and within this parliamentary process. It will also be somebody who then gets his or her power from the elected members of the parliament. The Australian citizens as a whole, who elect all of us here, then have their representation and can move the issue along.

This notion of a people's convention is particularly extraordinary. Firstly I draw people back to the 1890s conventions which were proponents of change. They were concerned with only one question: how to create, from separate Australian colonies, a Commonwealth of Australia. More than half of the Australian population were non-participatory in that early people's convention. Most people will know that no female had any role in any of those conventions. Indeed, school children upstairs in the gallery may be interested to know that women were required to sit up there and watch the proceedings while the men decided what the Commonwealth of Australia was to be about.

I am not suggesting that a people's convention as proposed by the Leader of the Opposition would exclude women, but I do know that he is appointing half the delegates. In my summation, that means, `I have control of the numbers.' I find it quite extraordinary to dress this people's convention up as something which is open and free to all people if `I am appointing half the people'. To me, a convention is no sacred cow. I see the 1890s convention as having brought about the Commonwealth of Australia but having excluded me and all those other women who go to make up the other half of the Australian population. I look at the 1973-85 conventions in Australia and I see that none of them were able to come to any conclusion at all.

All of us here know the jokes about committees. I believe that the proposal for a people's convention on this issue represents the attitude: if you cannot come to a decision, you have a committee. Indeed, that is precisely the path which the Leader of the Opposition is taking. He cannot make a decision. He does not want an Australian to be head of state. He does not want Australians to determine who they are and where they are in the 21st century.

What an extraordinary state we have got ourselves into: we have a monarch in Britain making decisions about us when, in fact, in many aspects of our lives we no longer have very close ties with Britain. If an Australian were to be head of state in an Australian republic, it would not deny the fact that very many people in Australia trace their roots back to Britain—England, Scotland and Wales. Some of us trace our roots back to Ireland. Now, many Australians trace their roots back to other places which are much closer to home—the Philippines, Cambodia, Vietnam, parts of eastern Europe, Romania, and so on.

All those people claim Australia as their own and look to Australia and the Australian government to provide them with their own head of state in a system which gives them a say. Many people who have come to Australia's shores are being provided, through their taking up of Australian citizenship, with the right to vote for the first time in their lifetime. That is important; it is at the heart of representative government.

We are here representing people and offering leadership. We often hear tell of the role of the Prime Minister—about the need to lead our people, the need to offer direction. The Prime Minister of Australia is talking of an Australian head of state in order for all Australians to share a future together. But now, somehow, that is not about leadership but about telling people what to do. How far from the truth this is. Republicanism and an Australian head of state are simply saying to the world, `We are Australian, we rule ourselves, we make our own decisions.' Quite simply, in a society which espouses equality and diversity, how much more correct is it for us to have an Australian head of state?

The kinds of spurious arguments we have heard on the constitutional monarchy pale into insignificance when we look at the nature of the British monarchy and when we look at the kinds of checks and balances which operate within this parliament and within this parliamentary system to ensure that there is stability and representative government. I say to those opposite: if we are to take and if you are to take representative government seriously, then it is up to each and every one of us to represent quite clearly the views of the 70,000 or so people who are in our electorates—not our personal views on this matter, but the views across the spectrum of what is happening.

As I move about my electorate, I find that the majority of people are in favour of a republic and an Australian head of state. Some people are in favour of a republic but not a change in the flag. Some people are confused about the notion of a republic and some other symbols which go with that. Some people stand for the monarchy, although the number is very small and diminishing; by and large they tend to be somewhat more elderly.

Young Australians and the young Australian population with whom I mix and meet have a very clear view about who they are, about the kind of government they want and about where they are going in the 21st century. They are joyful about the Sydney Olympics. They are joyous in the notion of being part of a great industrial democracy. They are joyous in being part of a country in which representative government gives them a whole range of opportunities, and checks and balances. They are joyful in the notion that at last there are people who will stand up and say, `Being an Australian is something of which to be proud.' This is unlike what happened in the 1950s and 1960s when people cringed over to Britain to seek their education, to seek their artistic talents, to seek publication for their works or whatever else. No, the height of joy is here in Australia in a dynamic community and in a healthy artistic society—a society which people can be proud of and in which opportunity is very much part of the role.

At the heart of all of this is the notion of who we are, where we are going and who we represent.
