I know that all Australians agree that in future our head of state should be one of us, with the checks and balances that being elected by two-thirds of the House of Representatives and the Senate will bring to the role of an Australian president in an Australian republic in the year 2001.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the member for Forde (Ms Crawford), one can see that the republican debate has a long way to go. There will be plenty of time to debate the serious and important constitutional issues involved in the proposals for a republic. In my short contribution at this stage I do not want to delve too deeply into that, but I do want to ask a few questions about the methods and motives of the government in pursuit of its republic, particularly about the actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: To change the constitution it is necessary to go through all the formalities under section 128 of the constitution. This means that there must be a referendum proposal passed by a majority of this House and of the Senate, and that it must be put to the electors. It will only be passed if it is approved by a majority of electors in a majority of states and by an overall majority of electors voting.

Since Federation, some 42 proposals have been put to referenda, but only eight of those 42 have passed. None of the eight has involved major constitutional change. In fact all the larger proposals for change have failed. No proposal which has been seen by the smaller states as a threat to them has been approved in a referendum. Very few referendum proposals involving an increase in Commonwealth power have been approved by the people.

When we look at what is involved in a referendum proposal for Australia to become a republic, the changes involved to the Australian constitution are massive, even on a proposal that seeks to effect least change. In addition, it must be borne in mind that the Crown is also the symbol of each of the states. Each state has a constitution and, in order to change those constitutions, whatever is required under the respective state constitutions must also be gone through. In effect, in seeking for Australia to become a true republic, you are asking for seven sets of changes—all of them major—to be effected simultaneously. It would be very easy for such proposals to be defeated if there is any significant sector of the community which does not support it.

There has been no referendum proposal passed since 1977. The most recent attempt, in 1988, failed because the proposals did not have bipartisan support. It is highly unlikely that any proposal put to a referendum would pass if it did not have the support of the major parties. It is highly unlikely that it would pass if it did not have the support of all of the states and, in particular, if it is seen as a threat to the smaller states.

In the light of that, one might wonder why the proponents of an Australian republic do not seek to make the issue a bipartisan one, because it is only if it becomes bipartisan that it will be approved. The Australian Labor Party has had the subject of an Australian republic as part of its platform since 1981. So far as I am aware, absolutely nothing was done between 1981 and 1992, except in 1987 when the platform was amended to set a target date of 2001.

The matter seems first to have been raised by the Labor Party in the public arena during the 1992-93 election. It was raised in a very odd situation—obviously, a partisan situation where the parties were contesting an election. The Prime Minister came up with the extraordinary proposition that it would be good for the economy if Australia were to become a republic. I fail to see any relationship between the nature of the constitutional arrangement at the pinnacle of our government and economic conditions.

Subsequent to that election, there commenced what was referred to—erroneously, in my belief—as the republican debate. It was somewhat pointless because it seemed to raise the question: do you want Australia to become a republic? If not, why not? It did not descend to the question: if yes, what sort of republic do you want? That debate went on, promoted by journalists, for some considerable time until April 1993 when the Prime Minister decided to appoint a Republic Advisory Committee.

The Republic Advisory Committee might have promoted a bipartisan approach had the question of the appointment of the committee been approached by the Prime Minister in a bipartisan way, but it was not. He pointedly appointed a former Liberal Premier who was a pro-republican to the committee, invited the then Leader of the Opposition to nominate one person to a 10-person committee and required the states, each of which has a different and significant interest, to appoint one representing larger states and one representing smaller states. The result was that there was a committee which was seen right from the outset as being the subject of a partisan appointment process.

The Prime Minister seems to have thought it was also a relatively simple question to determine how to become a republic because he gave the committee a very short time frame within which to report. In fact, it could not report within that time frame and got a one-month extension. The government received the report in October 1993. The government then said, `Well, we won't be announcing what we are proposing immediately. We will do that early in 1994.' However, the Australian public waited in vain for the whole of 1994 for a government response.

In October 1994, the coalition proposed that there be a people's constitutional convention convened in 1997. That would have been to consider, among other things, whether there should be a republic, and, if so, what form that should take. The response of the Prime Minister to that was hardly bipartisan. He was asked a dorothy dixer in question time in this House in November last year, to which he answered:
Let me say this to the Leader of the Opposition: the government will be holding no dialogue with the coalition until it declares a belief in the need for an Australian head of state—none whatsoever.
If you do not accept the need for an Australian head of state, there will be no constitutional convention and no contribution and attendance at it by us.

SPEECH.PARA: There the Prime Minister is foreshadowing what he sees as the simple question for the resolution of the republican question: do you want an Australian head of state? The republican debate will not, in my view, be advanced while arrogant, censorious comments of that sort emanate from the government and generate a partisan approach.

PARA.TAB: The government must not have found it very easy to develop a response to the Republic Advisory Committee report, because nothing emanated from the government until 7 June. So it took all of 18 months and heading towards the better part of two years for a response from the government. The timing of that really raises another question. The response was given at a time when there was frequent and loud talk of the prospect of an election.

The response by the government, to promote a head of state elected by the houses of parliament jointly, is no doubt a valid proposal worthy of consideration by the Australian public in the course of the republican debate that will no doubt continue for some time. But there are partisan aspects to the proposal. First, the proposal does not deal with the situation of the states. It would be ludicrous to contemplate an Australian republic without the states being involved in the transformation from a monarchy to a republic.

Second, in the context of public opinion, the proposal adopted runs strongly counter to the public's substantial majority view that the head of state should be elected by the people. Third—and I have already mentioned this—the response to the Republic Advisory Committee was not quick and it was not done in the course of 1994. The response from the government was not put until as late as this month in the context of a possible early election.

In the course of announcing the government's proposals, the Prime Minister also said that what we have is a simple question. He asserts that the only question involved in the republican debate is: do we want an Australian head of state? He camouflages the real issue, because in order to get a true Australian head of state—the Governor-General effectively being an Australian head of state—we have to ask how we get one. It is not, therefore, simply a question of: do you want an Australian head of state? It is: do you want an Australian head of state elected by the Australian people? Do you want an Australian head of state elected by the parliament? Do you want one appointed by the Prime Minister? Do you want one who is elected by the state governors, or is one of the state governors appointed to serve for a limited time, as has been seriously suggested?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is obfuscation and you know it, Daryl.

—No, it is not. It seems to me to be highlighting the fact that this proposal is being put in an election context. The Prime Minister is reported by people in the press gallery as having said that he can win an election on the republic issue. If that is his attitude, I am very disappointed, because the issue is far too important to be treated like that. But so many signs are pointing to that being the way the Prime Minister in particular is approaching it.

PARA.TAB: In the few minutes I have left to speak I will contrast the coalition approach. As foreshadowed in October last year by the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) when he was the Leader of the Opposition, the coalition will, on being elected to government, convene in 1997 a people's constitutional convention. Half the delegates will be elected; half will be appointed. They will be elected on state and territory bases, with parliamentarians disqualified from running for election. The election process will recognise that young people, women and people from non-English-speaking backgrounds are currently underrepresented in decision making processes. Strenuous efforts will be made to encourage them to stand for election.

The remaining half of the delegates will be appointed from federal, state and territory parliaments. The Prime Minister, premiers, chief ministers and attorneys-general will be delegates. Federal and state oppositions will also be represented. There will also be representatives from local government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. Ten per cent of those at the convention will be in the age group 18 to 25. If a consensus emerges from the people's convention as to what should be done about a head of state, the coalition has undertaken that that will be promoted by the government at a constitutional referendum.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think?

—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, who is at the table, asks me what I think. I am one of 17 million people. I believe, as the coalition does, that the question ought to be asked of the people, the issue debated at this convention and the consensus that emerges be put to a referendum. We have in contrast the government approach, which is that we as a government have decided what we want to do and we will tell the people that is what they have to do.

PARA.TAB: The coalition also provides for the possibility of there being no real consensus, just as there is in the community at the moment, on a particular form of republic. In that event the coalition would put a series of options to the people for them to vote on. Those options would be put in the form of a plebiscite, not a referendum, and if a consensus emerges from that it would be put to a constitutional referendum. That is a two-stage process.

The virtue of the coalition approach is that the people will be consulted. It makes sense in the context of the need for a constitutional referendum, bearing in mind that so few constitutional referenda have been passed by the Australian people. They apparently treat their constitution very seriously, and proposals for change—they have been for only small changes—have been treated very seriously to the extent that most of them have failed. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe it is about time Australia had its own head of state. We are approaching the 21st century and our centenary of nationhood, and it is about time we made our own way in our region and in the world. At a time when we are attempting to become closer to our Asian neighbours through trade and culture, they are amazed that we still have a sovereign head of state who lives 10,000 kilometres away.

PARA.TAB: Some of these people are pretty amazed that, when the Queen of England visits Malaysia, for example, she is usually assisting or leading a delegation of English trade people who are working on trade balance for England—certainly not on trade balance for Australia. It is time we showed our own colours and our own way as a nation. The Queen of England has been with us for a long time, and it is now time we are able to elect our own Australian head of state. That is what this debate is really about: Australians having their own as the head of their nation.

The Queen of England in reality now only acts in her role as Queen of Australia when she is in Australia. That is not very often these days. Most of the time in touring other countries she is the Queen of the United Kingdom. When talking about those interests she is talking about the interests of England and the trade of England and the economies of the United Kingdom. That is fine. That is the way it should be for her as the head of England, but it should not be that way for the head of Australia. When we have a head visiting another part of the world that head of our country should be promoting this country, Australia. When our head of state visits those countries, it should be an Australian.

We may ask why we have hung onto these remnants of the past for so long. There are a lot of reasons. Our history, our early European population, was British based. The economy was geared to the European market until relatively recently and certainly until postwar in Australia. Maybe it was tied too close, maybe we should have broken the ties earlier. Our population is English speaking, with an accent somewhat equivalent to cockney English. Therefore we were seen as an easy place for English migrants to settle. We do have some strong ties, and some of us have strong memories. My wife is English born, so my mother-in-law is English—a great woman. She came to live in Australia in 1983, was naturalised in 1984 and at 78 now firmly believes that Australia should have its own head of state, should be able to state its own case with its own head and should be proud of the fact that it has a head of state born and bred in Australia.

As Australia's population has grown through its migrants, especially its postwar migrants, through those changes Australia has come away from the European economy. Many more nationalities have settled in Australia and we have changed from our early roots. Those changes in trade were very easy to see in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s when England went into the Common Market and basically destroyed the Tasmanian apple industry. It was the right thing for England to do but it certainly did not do anything for Australia's trade and it certainly did not do anything for a major industry in Tasmania.

In England now the Prime Minister is having a few difficulties in convincing his more conservative colleagues in his own party that England should be going into the European Union in a fully fledged way, as all the other nations are. That is probably right for England and that is probably where it should be in its trading bloc, endeavouring to gain the best out of that. But Australia's future is in the Asian region, the Pacific rim. That touches everything from South America to the Americas, North America and Canada right through Japan, right down to China, right around Asia and even across to South Africa and the Indian rim.

We have great trade opportunities emerging in those areas in the future. To make the most of them we need to have someone who can go there as the head of Australia, someone who is an Australian. I believe we will be seen to be a country that has finally reached its full maturity. Our early relationship with Britain, our heritage and our affection for that country do not need to change. We have grown up with them. I personally have many English friends who will not change a bit when Australia becomes a republic. They will still be my friends. I will still enjoy their company and be proud to know them.

The head of state in Australia should embody and represent Australian values, traditions, experiences and aspirations for the future. We should incorporate the dreams and aspirations that the indigenous people of Australia have for our nation. I would like to see us becoming one Australia, but it will rely on a decision of the Aboriginal people—will they help us develop our nationhood in a way that is acceptable to their people? That is something that I do not think could ever happen under a head of state who was born somewhere outside Australia.

Every Australian should be able to aspire to be the head of state, chosen because of a particular achievement or outstanding service. There is no reason why we should not look forward to having an Aboriginal as the head of state some time in the future. Many Aboriginals have contributed to building our great nation, and many more will do the same.

Under the current constitution, the head of state is the Queen. Most of her responsibilities are carried out by the Governor-General. The only power she retains is the appointment of the Governor-General which, by convention, she does on the advice of the Prime Minister of the day. The historical aspect of that is that in 1933 the Governor-General ceased to be the representative of the British government in Australia and became solely the representative of the Queen. In the same decade, it was accepted that the British monarch would act on the advice of the Australian government, not the British government. Also Australia assumed responsibility for its own external affairs—its foreign affairs as we call it today.

In 1980 all remaining rights of appeal to the Privy Council in London ceased. Australian courts became the ultimate arbitrator of Australian law. There has been a move towards our becoming a republic over the years, and we have divested ourselves of a connection to British law, its courts and its appeal system. In the Australia Act, the UK relinquished the last vestiges of power, making only Australian law apply to Australia—a small but important step and the last in a process which began about 100 years ago.

If we take the minimalist approach, the only thing that we will need to change is the position of the Governor-General and how he or she is appointed. All the constitutional principles and practices will remain the same. The role of the House of Representatives and the Senate will be the same, and we will still have a federation of states. The functions of the head of state will be that of the Governor-General—except in the most external circumstances—although we will still have this ongoing debate about the reserve powers and that aspect of control.

I know that the polls have shown that within our country people would like to vote on the head of state. I think as we emerge from this debate—although I am sure there will still be a lot of debate before there is a referendum—people may come to realise that changing the way we elect the head of state from a two-thirds majority of both houses of parliament would require a major change to the power structure that we presently have in this country. Hence, we would have to rewrite and change the power of the Senate. We would have to look at the power of the Prime Minister, the Executive Council and the executive government. A major change would have to take place, and that process would involve enormous changes to the power structure.

If we had a popularly elected head of state, we would need to change the power structures that we presently know in our country today. An example could be that people would be able to make representations to the president—whether or not he is popularly elected—to override government decisions. If a president tried to pursue an issue like that, it could bring us into a constitutional crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the member for Blaxland. I refer the Prime Minister to Senator Evans's claim in the Senate yesterday that he had asked Indonesia privately to rethink its plan to appoint a military figure who supported the Dili massacre as its new ambassador to Australia. In light of the Prime Minister's close personal relationship with President Suharto, has the Prime Minister raised any concerns about General Mantiri's appointment with President Suharto?

—No, I have not. It is the right of governments to select their ambassadors and to propose them to the country of their service. The record would show that governments receiving ambassadors rarely reject them and only do so under the most extreme circumstances.

PARA.TAB: As far as the Dili question is concerned, Australia has made its position very clear on the Timor massacre many times over. I myself have done so to President Suharto. No doubt the President, in nominating General Mantiri, does so as a senior military figure in that country. I can see no circumstances on which we would or should reject his nomination by the President.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister, and it concerns Accord Mark VIII. Will the Prime Minister inform the House of the benefits to Australia of the signing of Accord Mark VIII?

—We are seeing again the value of an agreed basis of income determination between the work force and the government of the day. It is best demonstrated by the fact that since Accord Mark VII we have had 630,000 jobs created in Australia and an inflation rate between one per cent and 2 1/2 per cent, or in some cases under one per cent, during the cycle of that accord.
—And look at the level of unemployment.
—The member for Goldstein will not interject today.

—After eight accords over 12 years—each accord covers a period of about 1 1/2 to two years—with Accord Mark VIII we can see for the first time the development of a permanent perpetual wages system whereby, having used the accords to move away from the centralised wage fixing structure, we are now moving to a decentralised wage fixing structure. In that decentralised wage fixing structure, enterprise bargaining is growing apace throughout the community.

PARA.TAB: Those working Australians who cannot avail themselves of an enterprise bargain will be protected by the safety net being proposed by the government. In other words, we have had accords which dealt with award restructuring and flexibility within awards and we have had accords which were predicated on the amalgamation of major unions under a system of award restructuring. That now largely having been accomplished, we can focus on a permanent wages system with low inflation.

I imagine that it is a matter of some substantial comfort to the community that the ACTU, on behalf of the work force, said that, for the period of this Accord, the wages system will be based on an underlying inflation rate on average of two to three per cent over the cycle. I ran into an employer's representative yesterday and he said to me, `I grew up with automatic wage indexation. For my whole working life there has been automatic wage indexation.' To see an underlying rate of inflation of two to three per cent—in other words, running the wages system, including the enterprise bargaining stream to produce two to three per cent inflation—is a quite remarkable and revolutionary change. It means that we can run the Australian economy faster than we would otherwise be able to were we relying simply on interest rates to curtail inflation.

In those countries where we have seen only a reliance on fiscal and monetary policy we have generally seen a much slower rate of employment growth and economic growth than in Australia. Having the three instruments of policy—fiscal, monetary and wages policy—with some weight on each rather than a heavy preponderant weight on any one really means that we can run the economy much faster and more safely in terms of inflation and, at the same time, spread the benefits.

I told the House last week that since 1983 we have had an increase in household disposable income of 40 per cent or, in per capita terms, an increase of over 19 1/2 per cent. There have been over two million jobs created. That is a fairly remarkable record. We have a system which takes account of the core need for competitiveness. We hear a lot from the opposition about the current account deficit. It is now the only thing that those opposite harp on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to hear more too.
—That is the only thing it has left. We did not hear much from them when we had double digit inflation because they did not know what to do with it.
—Other places in the world had it.
—Order! The member for O'Connor.
—It took a Labor government to break the back of Australia's inflation. It is perhaps the great economic victory of the last 10 or 12 years.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left.
—And so we had a depression.
—Order! The member for Ryan.

—We put the core indices of our competitiveness—inflation—back under two to three per cent. We have actually seen it under one per cent for part of the recent period. To do that is a great breakthrough for Australia. It is a great breakthrough for Australia's competitiveness. Competitiveness, which promotes that ever growing level of exports, is the thing which in the end will deal with the current account, as will the savings changes that the government has put in place.

PARA.TAB: I have talked in this House before about the debilitating effect that double-digit inflation that we had for 15 years had on this country. I have made the point that people could not save at the levels they were when inflation was tearing the quality and value out of their savings. With low inflatison and an accord of this kind we are also seeing a very great reduction in industrial disputation and we have seen a much greater promotion of industrial peace in the period. I notice that the Leader of the Opposition was launching the industrial relations policies of the coalition in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going there?
—Order!
—He would do better to stay at home and launch his own policies.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—In the drizzle, let the member for Bennelong tell us about his industrial relations policies. Having opposed every wage increase bar two since 1981, having supported a $16 increase over 14 years and having tried to tear the middle out of the wages of Australians, let him now come clean and tell us exactly what his industrial relations policies are.

PARA.TAB: The government has told everybody what its policy is. It is in the Accord. It is in the eighth one. It has been published. People can see it. They know what the consultative processes were and they know of the consultations we had with the industry groups, including the MTIA. It is the better way. It is up to the opposition to show in this critical matter of wages and inflation that it can do better.

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell us why you will not go to Queensland.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I know it hurts the Prime Minister, but could you direct him to answer the question as to whether or not he sent two letters to President Chirac and what was in each of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister will withdraw that last—
—With deference to you, Mr Speaker, of course I withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister has withdrawn.

—Could you imagine his obsequious fawning pose, the Uriah Heep configuration, before a French minister or a French Prime Minister or a French President? He would go through the gate of the Hotel Matignon on his hands and knees. Now he is the great fighter for a nuclear-free South Pacific, when he opposed all the way Australia's advocacy of the cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons right through the 1980s—

—Order! Those on my left!

—The very same program that he talks about now. In the annals of rank opportunism, the Leader of the Opposition's remarks of late rank strongly, even if the genesis of his position was given to him by an advertising agency.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: at the commencement of his answer, the Prime Minister was quoting from notes. I invite him to table those notes and the two letters he allegedly wrote to the President of France.
