—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister inform the House about the benefits to workers and the economy of Accord Mark VIII? Can the minister also inform the House about the contribution the Accord and the Industrial Relations Reform Act have made to the decline in industrial disputes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt that Accord Mark VIII is a framework for another four years of low inflation, high growth and high productivity for the Australian economy. It certainly continues our tradition of industrial harmony—the one we are so pleased and proud to boast about. And what better day to show it off than the day the ABS statistics have been released, showing that for last year, 1994, Australia recorded the lowest number of industrial disputes in any year since 1940—the lowest number of industrial disputes for 55 years. What a sensational performance!

PARA.TAB: Just have a look at what we inherited in 1983 and compare it with what we have today as a result of the Accord. Here we have the graph. Here we have Everest. Who was presiding over the economy then? Who was right up there, scaling the dizzy heights? The Leader of the Opposition, the then Treasurer of Australia. His former Prime Minister has left the chamber, I notice.

Where are we today? Right down here, with the lowest level since 1940. These reductions have been even more dramatic as a result of the conjunction of the Accord process and the 1993 Industrial Relations Reform Act. It was only a few days ago that the publication Workforce published an article dealing with this question of industrial disputes, days lost and protected bargaining. What it had to say is very revealing. Workforce said:

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction of a legal right to strike has failed to produce an upsurge in industrial action, confounding employers' predictions that the new laws would create industrial turmoil. In fact, in the 12 months following the introduction of the new federal laws allowing unions to stage protected industrial action, the number of working days lost due to industrial action declined by more than 46 per cent.

It went down in that first year by more than 46 per cent! All of this is great news for Australian business. It is great news for Australia's exports. It is great news for Australia's economy. Of course, it is all thanks to the Accord and it is all thanks to those industrial reforms that this government has driven home.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that, under Labor, that exceptional performance will continue. Accord Mark VIII, after all, guarantees it. All working people in Australia have their standards fundamentally guaranteed through the four safety net adjustments provided under Accord Mark VIII, the $8 increase from Accord Mark VII and the three annual adjustments—$9 to $12 for each of the following three years, 1997 through to 1999. In the case of low paid workers, it is a bigger increase—from $11 to $14.

Consistent with the budget, there is a better retirement income guaranteed under the Accord for all workers through the introduction of employee superannuation contributions, contributions which will be met, dollar for dollar, by this government. We have improved this area. We have driven home the reforms. We have provided additional assistance for families. We have a comprehensive package we can truly be proud of.

That is in stark contrast to the promise of what members of the opposition have in store if ever they are elected to government in this country. There is no comprehensive award safety net under them whatsoever. There is an absence of a no disadvantage test against which enterprise bargains can be measured. There are no safety net increases. There is a single miserable hourly rate of pay. How do we know this when there has been no release of the federal policy? It is worth noting that yesterday the Leader of the Opposition went to Queensland and released the Queensland state opposition's IR policy. It provided all of these things—each and every one of them.

The approach of the opposition to industrial relations is no different now from what it was in 1993. It destroys all workers' protections. It would return us to the industrial turmoil, shown here so graphically, of the early 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, some two years ago, in reflecting the concern of a substantial section of the Australian community, I indicated to the House that, regrettably, you were coming dangerously close to becoming the Neville Chamberlain of South-East Asia in respect of our relations with Indonesia. Does not the agreement of the government to the appointment of Lieutenant General Mantiri as Indonesian Ambassador to Australia, whose view is that the Dili massacre was `a quite proper response', reinforce the view that the government is following a policy of appeasement to a military dictatorship? Given the fact that this appointment flies in the face of Australian public opinion since 1975, why have you allowed this ambassadorial appointment to humiliate this country in the eyes of the world and to hold up to ridicule any human rights statements this country may make in world forums?

—I am at a loss to understand the reference to Chamberlain. Does the honourable gentleman think that Indonesia is about to declare war on Australia? Does he think we have a relationship of that character?
—Yes, Neville.
—You want peace at any price.
—Order! The member for Sturt and the member for Canberra.

—This is our nearest largest neighbour of just on 200 million people. It is a country whose fortunes are inextricably linked to Australia's, and ours to theirs. It is a relationship which is absolutely central to Australian foreign policy. For that relationship to be operated only on the basis of a foreign policy relationship, or one that takes the opportunity of simply expressing exclusively an Australian view or a sectional Australian view as the basis for the operation of that policy, would be doing the wrong thing by Australians.

PARA.TAB: It is more the pity that, for a very long period of time, so much of the Australia-Indonesia relationship has centred around Timor; it has because of what has happened there. Australia has made clear that it has condemned the denial of liberties and the denial of human rights in that province and has sought a better order in that province. But it wants to conduct that conversation about East Timor in the context of a broader conversation with Indonesia about the totality of the relationship and our relative importance to one another.

That is now what has happened. We now have a broad relationship with Indonesia that sits on many foundations, whereas in the past it was exclusively a foreign policy relationship where, were that to crumble, the whole relationship would have crumbled.

I can only repeat what I said earlier: we have made our views very clear about Timor. We are constantly saying to the Indonesian government that there needs to be an approach to the development of Timor to give the people of that province opportunities and to give them, in their own view, a role in the way in which their province and their society function—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to write a letter to the ambassador to tell him that he is wrong?
—Order! The member for Wills!
—And, as a consequence, try to see that this does not remain the issue for the East Timorese people or the issue in this relationship.

PARA.TAB: I think we can see that there has been a substantial change in the way in which Indonesia accepts the Australian view, deals with the Australian view. One should remember also the changes which are taking place in Indonesia. About eight years ago 65 per cent of Indonesians lived below the poverty line; that is now 15 per cent. There has been a substantial distribution of the wealth in Indonesia. One can see the changes taking place there perpetually. As a consequence, there is a lot of improvement in living standards and, with it, the general human condition in that country. They are advances which I think Australia should encourage and applaud.

So, while we will always take the view that wherever liberties are constrained or human rights violated we will forcibly put our view—which we have done and will continue to do with Indonesia—that we do want to maintain a broad relationship with that country. I do not see the character of General Mantiri's appointment being such as to rupture that relationship. In saying that, I say that in the broad interests of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the racial vilification bill?
—Not an errant section of the Victorian Far Left, which is your view.
—A massacre is a Far Left interpretation, is it?
—The member for Wills will not engage in debate.

—There has to be a totality in the relationship, and there is. I think that balance has been struck. Both the foreign minister and I, in the course of keeping that balance, will never fail to put Australia's views about democracy, liberty and human rights. I do not see General Mantiri's appointment by President Suharto as the Indonesian Ambassador to Australia as in any way curtailing our capacity to put that view.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister outline to the House the government's view of the value of a people's convention as an instrument of constitutional change?
—There is no more effective way of giving expression to the will of the Australian people—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This matter is on the Notice Paper at the present time, so it is an invalid question. I ask you to rule it out of order.
—The honourable member has raised a valid point. It is on the Notice Paper and it has been debated today so it is, therefore, out of order.
—Mr Speaker—
—Mr Speaker—
—I call the member for Port Adelaide.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is a clear precedent in this House that you give the call to either side. That question was ruled out of order after you gave the member the call. You are now obliged by precedent to give the call to this side of the House.

—The honourable member raises that it is precedent. In the spirit of fairness, I was giving the opportunity for those on my right to ask a question. I had given the call to the member for Port Adelaide.
—Fairness! Ha, ha!
—I will then give the call to the honourable member for Barker.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. You acknowledge that the precedent exists, then you defy the precedent and say that, in a matter of fairness, you will give it to your own side. You are obliged to follow the precedents.
—It is not my own side while I am occupying this chair.
—Why do you acknowledge the precedent and then not follow it?

—I have just said that, in the spirit of fairness, in the balance that is normally maintained here members are given the call. I have said that I called the member for Port Adelaide, but I then indicated that the member for Barker would get the subsequent call. The member for Port Adelaide.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—No.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister able to advise the House of the principles—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—If it is on the same matter, there is no point of order.

—You have said again and again in this House when dealing with points of order that we are to be referred to the House of Representatives Practice and writings on the history of the standing orders. Very simply, the Practice says that you must follow the precedent. That is the way that the rules governing the House are built.
—No. I have already ruled on this. I have said—

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: under the arrangements between the government and the opposition 14 questions are provided, which means that the opposition gets its questions. It is not a matter of the opposition being denied a question, whatever the sequence.
—There is a valid point there. As I have said, I am prepared in the spirit of fairness to give even-handedness and calls each way. I call the member for Port Adelaide—and let's get on with it.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister able to advise the House of the principles which have underpinned government policy formulation since 1983? Is the Prime Minister able to assure the Australian people that his government will continue to involve the Australian people in all aspects of policy development and implementation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Virtually from day one the government changed the model of governance in Australia by a process of consultation. This began with the Economic Summit in 1983, the prices and incomes accord, and consultation with employer groups and the peak union bodies under the Accord to curtail prices and to see wages come back to be within affordable levels. That process has continued right down the years, and Accord Mark VIII is a further development of that process of consultation.

PARA.TAB: You can see it again more recently in the consultations that the government had with the peak farm bodies last year and in the consultations we are still having in relation to such questions as land management and soil and water conservation. By and large, the government has believed that, on a basis of talking and listening to interest groups, one can secure policy solutions which advance the country more rapidly and more fully. As a consequence, we advance ourselves in a way that we might not otherwise. In the last two months, the government has delivered a number of profound reforms. In fact, I doubt whether any government has been quite so productive in such a short period of time, and the process of consultation that we have had has encouraged it.

Let me remind the House that the budget delivered, amongst other things, a budget surplus, a new maternity allowance and a revolution in national savings via 15 per cent being put away for Australians in award superannuation.

Since the budget we have seen the Justice Statement; we have seen the completion, at last, of our oldest national goal—a standard gauge rail link linking the mainland capitals via Melbourne—we have seen the beginning of a national civics education program; we have seen the government's proposal for an Australian republic with an Australian as our head of state; and we have seen Accord Mark VIII which was delivered last week—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; he is just reading from notes.
—The member for Mitchell!

—I have already told the House about the benefits to Australian workers and to the economy flowing from that statement. Opposition members do not enjoy this modality of policy making, just as they did not enjoy the other achievements of the past three years. They hated the One Nation statement; they hated the white paper on employment; and they hated Creative Nation.
—We hate your debt.
—I am sorry they find all reforms so unpalatable.
—Let the children pay.
—Order!

—Perhaps the game was given away when the member for Bennelong said that he thought the `nation had reform fatigue'. These recent achievements stem from the government's fundamental belief in policy: a belief that governments should lead, that they should address the potential of the country and that they should have faith in the people's capacity to embrace the necessary change—
—You cannot tell them the truth.
—I warn the member for O'Connor!

—to take people into the government's confidence and encourage them, along with our own processes, to reach the higher levels of policy prescription. It also means that we recognise there can be no honesty in government without policies. There can be no credibility and no trust between the government and the people—or a political party and the people—without a process of development of policies.
—What about l-a-w?
—Order!

—That is why the opposition's claim that it is somehow in touch with people is so laughable. Opposition members say they are in touch but they will not, on any basis of trust, tell the public what their policy prescriptions might be. It seems to me that it is an antithesis of the argument of being in touch. You are so out of touch that you do not believe the public should know what your policy thinking is, and you will not bring them into it. You will not even tell your own backbench. I heard the interjection from the member for Flinders. When his GST proposal was unveiled in the last parliament, it was, of course, again without consultation with the public or even with his own party.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—But here we have it from the horse's mouth. A report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 June 1995 stated:

PARA.TAB: The Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, has called a special party room meeting for Friday—

ANSWER.PARA: to head off any concerns over lack of backbench involvement in policy and strategy decisions for the Federal election.

PARA.TAB: This "brainstorming session" . . . is to allow MPs to air their views on the Coalition's electoral tactics.
However, senior figures stressed that the meeting would not canvass detailed policy areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Oh, no, there will be no trust for the MPs and certainly no trust with the community—no trust, but they are in touch!

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you tell your backbenchers about the Commonwealth Bank?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—What about the Commonwealth Bank?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—Half an hour before you announced it.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—Mr Howard is too frightened and too devious to even release his policies to his own backbench for their scrutiny and approval. But this is not because the policies have not been prepared. Senator Robert Hill had this to say about their policies, published in The things they said:

ANSWER.PARA: As chair of the coalition's policy review committee, I can tell you that we now have in place draft framework policies for almost every portfolio, including my own area of responsibility—education science and technology, he says. The finer detail of that policy will be the subject of ongoing debate over the next few months. The full policy will be released in the lead-up to the election at a time of our own choosing. But this stand should not be misinterpreted as an unwillingness or an inability to engage in policy debate. In fact, it is time to intensify the debate.

In other words, the opposition has, as Senator Hill says, its draft policy framework in place. We saw a bit of the quality and morality of the draft policy framework when Senator Ian Macdonald talked about introducing policies he had no intention of actually proceeding with. In today's Australian—I do not usually quote many journalists in here, and I do not want to make a habit of it—Mr Megalogenis said:
Macdonald's briefing paper to shadow cabinet contained what must rank as one of the dumbest passages ever drafted by a politician.
It was not so much dumb as an outbreak of honesty, an uncharacteristic outbreak of frankness. Let us make it clear that we are now well within 12 months of an election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve months?

—Twelve months of an election. What are we seeing from the opposition? We are seeing policies that are prepared in framework, but not to be released—not to be shown to the public. Yet the Leader of the Opposition will tell us that the opposition is in touch with the public—the same public he will not share his secrets with, the same public he has no trust in and the same public who have no relationship of trust with him. The opposition has no process of consultation, no accord, no discussion with bodies like the peak farm bodies and no discussion with the employer groups, as the government has.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard is either too scared or too embarrassed to release his policies. The point I want to make is that the country has advanced by frankness. It has advanced by consultation. It has advanced by sharing information. It has advanced by taking the public into the government's trust. This has not happened with the opposition, which claims to be in touch with the very people it believes it cannot trust.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Is the minister aware of today's TV appearance of Matt Rigney, the chairman of one of South Australia's three ATSIC regional councils, in which Mr Rigney confirmed Doug Milera's earlier statement that it was men who came up with the idea of women's business and it was men who told the women about it. How could the women's business be secret if it had been not only discussed with men but also—as now confirmed by Mr Rigney—initiated by men? Will you now admit that your administration of this issue has been totally incompetent? In the interests of all Aboriginal people, will you urge them to cooperate with the South Australian royal commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Few things are certain in public life, but one of them is that, whenever Channel 10 runs a report in relation to Hindmarsh Island, the member for Barker will speak from his political grave, with the active support of the Leader of the Opposition, in an attempt to try to take this issue just one step further. Let me refer to the Channel 10 report that the honourable member for Barker speaks about. The Channel 10 report begins with an introduction—
—A good starting point!
—Let me tell you about it—in which it says:

ANSWER.PARA: Matt Rigney is the most senior elected official in South Australia's Aboriginal community.

Wrong! That in fact is Yami Lester, the elected ATSIC commissioner from South Australia. It then goes on to say, just in the introduction, that the Ngarrindjeri Heritage Commission secretary is a Mr Doug Milera. Wrong! In fact the secretary is a Miss Liz Tongerie. They are the errors just in the introduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on to the quote.
—Order!
—I will go to the quote. The fact is that in this very short Channel 10 report there is a great deal of internal inconsistency.
—So what has that to do with it?
—I have already warned the member for O'Connor.

—Among the things that are said in that report is a suggestion by the journalist concerned that Mr Rigney `maintains that no lies have been told'. He goes on to say, `Everyone has been telling their version of the truth.' I wish to table a letter from Mr Rigney addressed to me dated the 7th of this month, in which he states:

ANSWER.PARA: It is most disappointing that some of our Ngarrindjeri people have spoken out about fabricated stories.
These are not the views of the majority of Ngarrindjeri people. It is our view that those who spoke out about fabricating the women's stories are politicising Aboriginal heritage.
My Council and I commend you—
on your stance and assure you that my Regional Council stands with you in a show of solidarity against those—

TALK.START.PARA: —He seems to have changed his mind now.
—Here's your turn in the letter—

ANSWER.PARA: valueless politicians who are using Aboriginal people for political point scoring.

I table the letter. This House and the parliament—in fact, the people of Australia—are most grateful to Mr Michael Gordon of the Australian for his recent feature piece in which he told us of the exploits of the Leader of the Opposition at, would you believe it, the Caboolture golf club.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?

—At the Caboolture golf club. We find in the Australian a detailed account of the way in which the opposition is seeking to use this issue in a most divisive and improper way, trampling on standards of proper behaviour in a way it would never deal with or treat the spiritual beliefs of non-Aboriginal Australians. The Leader of the Opposition said in his speech that the government—that is, me—was responsible for economically `bashing up ordinary, decent Australian citizens'. That is what he said.

PARA.TAB: What the member for Bennelong did not tell the good people of Caboolture is that one of the two developers that he so unstintingly praised without any kind of equivocation is in fact facing criminal fraud charges in the state of South Australia. The member for Bennelong did not tell those people that, and he ought to go back there and—

TALK.START.PARA: —You say this under parliamentary privilege.

—If the member for Bennelong doubts what I say, he should have regard to the Adelaide Advertiser of 22 April in which it is quoted that the developer is charged with misappropriating $70,000 from two estate trust funds. The article states:

ANSWER.PARA: Chapman, 54, of Hindmarsh Island appeared briefly in the Adelaide magistrates court.
I suggest that the opposition leader then have regard to a report in the Adelaide Advertiser of 10 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that sub judice?
—Order! The minister is getting very close to sub judice.
—No; I am simply reading—
—No; I suggest to the minister that he look very carefully at those quotes if he is going to read them.
—I will respect your wishes, Mr Speaker. Let me turn to some more facts that the Leader of the Opposition conveniently failed to put on the public record at the Caboolture golf club.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—I am not surprised.
—Order! The minister will resume his seat for a moment.
—The point of the question, which the minister simply will not address, is that, if it is not secret—
—Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Sit down!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Barker has the call for a point of order. The Prime Minister can speak to the point of order in a moment.
—The point of the question was: if the business was initiated by men, how could it possibly be secret?
—No, no! You are now debating the issue. Resume your seat. The minister has the call. He has been entirely relevant to the questions asked of him.
—Despite the fact that the member for Barker enjoys the unrestrained confidence of the Leader of the Opposition, that is not a view shared on this side of the House.
—Oh, I am devastated!

—The Leader of the Opposition, in his speech at the Caboolture golf club, talked at great length about the developers, the nature of the deal they were involved in and how it was all so dreadfully proper. What he did not tell the people at the Caboolture golf club is that the former Leader of the Opposition and now Premier of South Australia likened the deal to which they are a party as `the State Bank revisited'. That is what the Leader of the Opposition did not tell the people at Caboolture.

PARA.TAB: The member for Barker asked whether I would come into this House and give some active support to that Star Chamber royal commission convened by the South Australian government into the spiritual beliefs of a group of South Australians. I will do no such thing. It is very strongly my view that the royal commission in that state is in breach of the spirit, if not the letter, of the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act and the Commonwealth is seeking further advice on that question, as are others.

In case the Leader of the Opposition is in any doubt about how far out of step he is with the middle ground of Australian public opinion in endorsing the royal commission as he has, let me also table statements in the form of media releases issued by the Catholic Church in South Australia, the Uniting Church in South Australia and the South Australian Council of Churches. We in the Australian Labor Party stand with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware of proposals to loosen fiscal policy? Treasurer, can you tell the House where these proposals have come from and what their implications are?

—I am aware of a continuing stream of proposals to loosen fiscal policy which keep coming from the opposition. We saw in the reply to the budget from the Leader of the Opposition that the opposition was determined to oppose various tax measures, which would have meant a loosening of fiscal policy to the tune of $1 1/2 billion this year and $2 1/2 billion the subsequent year. Since then the opposition has proposed one expenditure measure, that is, in relation to non-work related child care. Now we see another, in relation to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The opposition is taking the view that various measures proposed by the government to stop the rapid growth of one of the fastest growing expenditure items in our whole array of outlays should be opposed.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has taken the view that in regard to our attempts to clarify the eligibility criteria and to prevent various claims which have been made on the basis of an application of the law which we never intended, such as, for instance, to diesel fuel used in maintaining council parks and gardens or in quarrying activity, there should be no retrospective application of that legislation to prevent claims being made on a basis which the government never intended them to be made. That is, the opposition wants the companies which are making these claims to be able to get money out of the government on the basis of an application of the law which was never intended by the legislature.

The money involved in this is substantial. It is about $160 million, if all the court decisions were to go against the government. That is the amount of money at risk and that is the addition to outlays which would come from the opposition being successful in its attempts to prevent the government from restricting outlays in this area.

It does not stop there. The opposition is also trying to prevent us from eliminating quarrying prospectively as an area which would not qualify for the diesel fuel rebate. That would cost an extra $20 million per annum approximately. So what we are looking at here is, across the forward estimates, something in the order of $240 million of additional outlays—that is, $160 million for the various claims and an annual $20 million for the inclusion of quarrying.

It should also be noted that of the $160 million of claims, $90 million would go to three companies. Those three companies, of course, have charged their customers in the past for the full amount of their costs, including the diesel cost without the rebate. Do you think those companies are going to hand back the $90 million to their customers? If you do, you have another think coming. If you really believe that, you are totally naive. This will just be $90 million straight into the pockets of three companies, to their benefit and to the benefit of their shareholders.

What we have had in this budget debate so far is opposition members opposing outlays in the order of $400 million, and thereby trying to increase outlays to that extent. That is just on two measures—the only two outlays measures that have so far come before the parliament.

At the same time, we have this ranting from opposition members about the need to tighten fiscal policy. The fig leaf of respectability that they have had on this issue has produced this response: `You should not be doing it through tax measures; you should be doing it through outlays.' But that fig leaf has been torn away by your own actions, because you keep opposing the outlays measures.

The naked truth is that this is an opposition without any policy credibility whatsoever. This is supposedly the alternative government, but it totally lacks policy credibility. It is trying to have the argument at the macro-level by saying, `We support fiscal tightening.' At the same time, it is opposing all the measures at the individual level—even, incredibly, the outlays measures. How could anyone take such an opposition seriously? How could anyone believe that this is an opposition with credibility and decency and with any policy ideas? By God, you need that brainstorming session tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Now that your new 12 per cent sales tax on building materials has been defeated, do you stand by your desire to tax building materials for the first time? Is it the case that at the next election a vote for the Labor Party is a vote to increase tax on every new house, every renovation and every extension to a family home in Australia?

—In line with the opposition's policy of trying to loosen our fiscal policy—and totally contrary to its supposed policy of being concerned about taking the pressure off interest rates and tackling the current account—it is taking action on every individual measure to try to prevent the interest rates pressure coming off—
—What is your policy? Tell us your policy, Ralph.
—The Leader of the Opposition is not helping.

—By doing that, it is showing to the nation that it has no policy credibility. It is a fact that the opposition has been successful in getting the minor parties in the Senate to give it support in relation to building materials, with the result being that the Senate has rejected that budget measure. When that measure comes back here, the government's position will be that we will accept that Senate decision.
—Because we know that we will not get it back if it is returned to the Senate.
—You don't want an election on it, do you?

—That does not mean to say that we think there is any decency or appropriateness in the opposition's action—quite the contrary. If you had any sense of responsibility or policy credibility, you would have supported that measure.
—You don't support it any more!
—Order!
—Simply because, every time—

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order relating to the question of relevance: the Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked what the government's policy was. The minister is refusing to outline the policy, which leads us to conclude that the government has no policy.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat because, as he knows, the government may not announce policy in the House in question time.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Treasurer is in order.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh, oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!

—As I was saying, any pretence from opposition members that they are concerned about the level of interest rates or the balance of payments can be disregarded, given the policy that they have pursued in relation to this budget.
—You cannot argue that way after what you have just said.
—Order! I warn the member for Mackellar.

—The opposition has attacked, opposed and tried to prevent all of the measures of substance that have been put in this budget to try to tackle the interest rate and balance of payments issues. When you say that you have those concerns, there should be horse laughs around the country. You have demonstrated by your actions time after time after time that you have no such concerns. You are quite prepared to see interest rates go up. You do not give a damn about the balance of payments or the current account deficit, because you oppose all the measures that are being put forward to tackle those issues.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the minister aware of claims that the government should reduce its expenditures more significantly? Can the minister provide the House with information regarding the economic impact of those concrete measures regarding government spending which have been proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly can. The Treasurer answered a question related to this, and I have further information. Although I am able to provide the honourable member information on the constant stumbling over the hurdles of this alleged opposition position, I said that we ought not to be addressing any element of the revenue side on this budget. We should, as they said, reduce expenditure significantly. Also, in a statement a week or so ago from the opposition spokesperson on treasury matters, it was stated that substantial massive measures were required in the expenditure area to address, in his terms, the current account deficit.

PARA.TAB: I have a small piece of good news, but a small piece of good news only, for the Treasurer. His statement that every single item of expenditure restraint that had thus far gone before the parliament had failed in the Senate with the opposition opposing it has to be amended as from late last night. Their opposition to the changes in the export market development grants scheme pursued once through the Senate was not pursued a second time.
However, having retreated in the face of the blandishments of the government in the course of the last week, Senator Parer could not let it go. He said in the Senate last night:

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I would state on behalf of the coalition that, on election to government, the coalition would recognise tourism as our largest single earner of foreign currency; and it will give tourism the same access to export market development grants and to any other facilities as are applicable to any other industry. This is a coalition commitment which will be delivered; it is not an empty . . . promise—

That is what Senator Parer had to say. That would constitute something like a 7 1/2 per cent increase in the expenditure in this area to provide opportunities for free tickets or subsidised holidays for foreign tourists coming to this country, as though an industry which is now upwards of about $7 billion actually requires the additional assistance that this proposition puts forward.

PARA.TAB: When we had a detailed consideration of these matters—unlike the way the opposition makes policy—it was pointed out that all the funds and resources that were going into this area were, to a substantial degree, creating competition between particular tourist destinations, facilities and operators in Australia as opposed to enhancing tourism to Australia. The opposition nevertheless says, `In our giveaway show, we will whack in another 7 1/2 per cent there.'

That particular proposition comes on top of the opposition's propositions that we had occasion to mention here earlier in the week. The hurdle those opposite fell over—as opposed to how they stumbled, got up, ran round and jumped over again in the case of the export market development grants scheme—was in the area of the restriction to non-working mothers of a very generous 12 hours a week subsidised child care. The opposition spokesperson said that I had been mistaken. I turn now to the relevant press article, which has not been denied by the coalition. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The coalition will go to the next election promising non-working mothers up to 50 hours a week subsidised child care.

The coalition believes stay-at-home mothers should be entitled to up to $94 a week child-care assistance, even though they receive a $30 a week home child-care allowance to stay at home and care for their children.

That has not been denied by the opposition, and we costed it. The cost was $1 1/2 billion. It is a $1 1/2 billion promise that you find yourselves committed to. As far as the increased diesel fuel rebate outlays issue is concerned, which was referred to by the Treasurer earlier—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a personal explanation, you turkey.
—You have never got up and specifically denied that.
—Order! The Leader of the House will not respond to interjections and there should be none anyway.

—As far as the increased diesel fuel rebate outlays issue is concerned, is it not interesting that those opposite walk around this place talking about $6 billion worth of cuts. They do not put anything on the revenue side; they do not in any way hit for revenue anyone whom they regard as their strong supporters. They put it all on the outlays side. As far as the rebate is concerned we are talking about an outlays option not a proposal that actually imposes a tax retrospectively.

PARA.TAB: Nobody would collect, if that decision were to go through, an amount of money off anybody. In fact, it would be a donation. Big hearted Arthur across the chamber would make a donation of $160 million to highly profitable companies, with no obligation on those companies to pay it across to people that they have already charged to cover that tax. Those opposite do not worry about them, but they get stuck into the safety net and they get stuck into the battlers in society to make up for the $400 billion worth of outlays that they are prepared to add on.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the member for Blaxland. I ask the Prime Minister: is it a fact that after your next sales tax increase on KST day—Keating's sales tax day—this Saturday, 1 July—Australians will—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member knows that he is not entitled to incorporate that sort of material in a question.
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: I hope before you rule that you will, in the spirit of fairness—
—I am always fair.
—recognise that there is a lot of liberal incorporations in this House and it would not be in accordance with the spirit of fairness if the question were to be ruled out of order.

—In the spirit of fairness, I refer the Leader of the Opposition to my remarks yesterday where I asked one member on my left to change the question because it was not really in the spirit of fairness. The honourable member for Isaacs can certainly ask a question as long as it is couched in the appropriate terms.

—I understand what you are saying, but I suspect that the sales tax increase is not in the spirit of fairness either. Is it a fact that the total sales tax slug for Australia will be $14 billion, which is equivalent to $785 per person per year or $60 for every four-person family per week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will check the statistics, but if the member wants a precise answer he should stick it on the Notice Paper.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I will round up the answer with a couple of points. The key point is that this is the second lowest taxed country in the Western world. This comes from a member of parliament who, in the last parliament, wanted to put a 15 per cent tax on everything—that is, food, clothing and the very same goods that he now refers to.
—They are all going up.
—Order!
—Here is the graph.
—Is that for wholesale sales tax? Coming back from Sydney in the aircraft today I picked up a copy of this week's Time magazine.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145 relating to relevance. I asked the Prime Minister a fairly simple question. It does not require him to pull out a bulletin that he has read on a flight. It is a simple question: is it a fact that the sales tax increase is going to cost the average family $60 a week?

—Order! There is no point of order. I again refer the honourable member for Isaacs, as I do all members in this place, to the discussion paper that was put out by Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee on Procedure. I refer members to pages 8 and 9 where it refers to the relevance of answers. I again say that, if members have some concerns about the issue, they should respond to this committee.

—The Leader of the Opposition was holding up some charts about Australia's debt, making a point about the state of the Australian economy and the state of Australia. I was reading this article called `Tough tests'. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: The Maastricht criteria for EU countries joining a single currency require a budget deficit of no more than three per cent of GDP and government debt of less than 60 per cent of GDP.
Then it is marked in yellow that:
Only three nations make the grade.

This is in Time magazine. Those nations are Luxembourg, Germany and Ireland. The question for those 15 European nations is effectively what the dowry is to join in partnership with the German mark; what dowry is needed to marry yourself to the German mark. Australia would have come in second. With a budget surplus—no other country would have had a budget surplus; not one—we would have come in first.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going to join the ERM?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, your indulgence has run out. You will not interject.

—I am just making the point: the opposition can hold up charts and talk about debt. But on the test that matters most in Western Europe, on the bulk of the largest conglomeration of economic states in the world in Europe—that test is to join the single market—Australia would have been one of two or three countries able to join on the basis of its budget surplus and its government debt. Government debt of Ireland is 85 per cent; of Germany it is 58 per cent. From recollection, government debt of Australia is 16 per cent. If we want some measures about how Australia is doing, we would have come second out of the 15 states in respect of joining the single market. Let us keep these things in some general context. Let me make this clear to the honourable gentleman: is he saying that he will repeal the wholesale sales tax measures were they to become the government of Australia? Is that what you are saying? Will you repeal them?
—Answer the question.
—The member for Isaacs!
—I do not know. You are not saying that. You are not saying you will repeal them, are you?
—Through more tax.
—The member for Isaacs, just take a breath.

—You are very solemn and very quiet about that. You are not saying you will repeal them. The opposition talks about the growth in the wholesale sales tax in this country. That is in part because the economy has grown so much in 12 years. You get more tax from more growth. Is that not funny? Is that not a revelation?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Those on my left!
—Is that not a revelation?
—And you are taxing them more.
—The member for Moncrieff!

—You get more tax from more growth. The more people buy whitegoods or some of the other items of manufacturing equipment or other substances or other things which are sales taxed, the more tax they pay. That is why the sales tax rises. The general point that Australians are interested in is the total tax take—not the wholesale sales tax. In respect of the total tax take, Australia is the second lowest taxed country in the world. That was not always so. It was not true under the member for Bennelong when he had his sticky fingers in the Treasury till. It was not the case then. It has been the case in declines of government spending under this government.

PARA.TAB: When this government came to office, government spending was 30 1/2 per cent of GDP. It is now around 26 per cent of GDP, and it is heading back to 23.8 per cent. It is a full six per cent of GDP smaller spending than when John Howard was last a minister and Treasurer of this country. And, Mr Speaker, guess what? If you spend less, you need to tax less. That is why there has been less taxation under a Labor government—
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Let me remind people: what was the top tax rate under J. W. Howard? Sixty per cent. He was Mr 60 per cent. What is it today? Forty-seven per cent. What was the bottom tax rate under Mr Howard? Thirty per cent. What is it now? Twenty per cent.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: under standing order 145, I think I have been reasonably tolerant, and so have you. The Prime Minister has covered everything else except the answer to the question of why families are paying $60 a week extra in sales tax.
—Order! The Prime Minister has been talking about sales tax. As far as I understand, he is still talking about tax. I would invite him to bring his answer to an end.

—We will have to send him down to the corner to play with the cars again. The bottom rate has dropped from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. The top rate has dropped from 60 per cent, under John Howard's treasurership, to 47 per cent tax, and the tax-free threshold has risen. When we look at the revenue and, therefore, the tax levied on Australians, we see that this is a lightly taxed country. This would not be so under a high taxing coalition government. The high taxation specialist is the coalition, the Liberal and National parties—the super tax merchants. We saw it at the last election, we have seen it in the past, and were they in office we would see it again.

—I ask the Minister for Communications and the Arts: will he advise the House about recently announced changes to strengthen media laws? Is he aware of alternative proposals? Is he able to advise on the implications of these proposals for ownership and control of major mass media assets?

—The cross-media ownership rules passed by this parliament are designed to encourage diversity of ownership in the media. The changes which the government announced on Tuesday night will strengthen and buttress the cross-media ownership rules, and that is something which we believe will limit cross-media holdings, whether it be print, television or radio. These changes are a considered response to the report to the government from the Australian Broadcasting Authority. Despite claims by the Leader of the Opposition, they are not directed at any individual because the 15 per cent cap applies just as much to News Limited's investment in Channel 7 as it does to Channel 9's investment in Fairfax.

PARA.TAB: What it does is provide more certainty for the industry because it provides, for the first time, a tightening of the net for the definition of `quasi equity' and puts the cap at 15 per cent and also maintains that control test for less than 15 per cent. For all of these reasons, the government believes that these changes are the right policy response to the ABA's report.

That can be contrasted with comments that have been made in the last 48 hours by certain members of the opposition. Senator Alston, the opposition's official spokesman for communications, was asked on Tuesday night whether a coalition government would reverse these changes. He said, `Well, there's not much here to reverse.' Yet on Wednesday morning the Leader of the Opposition said, `It's a legislative dagger aimed at Mr Packer.' He said, `It's just a KO Kerry exercise.' But the previous night, according to AAP, Senator Alston said our proposals were expanding the types of shares covered by the act and that was overdue. But on Wednesday morning the Leader of the Opposition said that this was Packer specific and prejudiced, biased legislation. But on Tuesday night Senator Alston said, `It's a step in the right direction.'

On Tuesday night what was long overdue and was, according to Senator Alston, a step in the right direction, was, by Wednesday morning, according to the member for Bennelong, prejudiced, biased legislation and a dagger at the heart of Mr Packer. I am starting to feel a bit sorry for Senator Alston. Is it any wonder he gets tangled up when the opposition, after 12 years, still does not have a media policy? So is it any wonder that Senator Alston is getting confused?

The only firm statement we have on cross-media owership from the opposition is the Leader of the Opposition's commitment to abolish the cross-media ownership rules. He thinks we should only rely on the Trade Practices Act—the Trade Practices Act that he weakened and the member for Holt had to strengthen. And when the member for Holt introduced the changes to strengthen it the Deputy Leader of the Opposition opposed the changes. So the Leader of the Opposition says that we should only rely on the Trade Practices Act, even after the chairman of the Trade Practices Commission says that means there are no limits on cross-media ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder how he will vote on the amendments.

—It will be very interesting to watch how you vote on those amendments. All of this could be cleared up for Senator Alston, to stop him getting into these tangles, if the Leader of the Opposition would answer just one question: would a Howard government permit someone to own a newspaper and a television station in the same city?

PARA.TAB: You had the hide to be interjecting on the Treasurer, `Tell us your policy.' We have been waiting for three months for you to tell us whether a future Howard government, if it is ever elected, would let someone own a newspaper and a television station in the same city. You have refused to answer for three months. All he ever says to us is that all will be revealed at a time of his choosing.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right. You've got it right.

—Our information is that, when all is revealed, all we will get is some vague promise for an inquiry or some vague promise for a review—maybe even some vague promise for a people's convention to decide media policy. The Leader of the Opposition will do anything to avoid a decision. He will do anything to avoid showing some leadership on this. He will do everything to avoid telling us whether or not he thinks someone should own a newspaper and a television station in the same city.
—My question—
—Tell us! Tell us now!
—Order!

—I will start answering questions in this place when you come second after the next election. My question is addressed to the member for Blaxland. As this is the last question time this session, I remind the member for Blaxland of his promise on his first day as leader of the Australian Labor Party when he pledged to `deal honestly with the people', to `tell them the truth', and to `resist the temptation to gild the lily'. Will he concede the truth to all Australians today that his prime ministership has delivered tragically high levels of youth unemployment, massive pressures on home buyers, uncertainties amongst elderly people, long waiting lists for public hospital treatment, a more unequal society, heavy burdens for families and small business and a current account deficit that is worse than that of Mexico? Is it not a fact that, when it comes to the Prime Minister telling his version of the truth, Australians have simply stopped listening?

—There was one principal commitment on which this government was re-elected; that was, to bring down unemployment. That is what the government did. It has brought down unemployment now to under nine per cent—down to 8 1/2 per cent from over 10 per cent. In the last 12 months we have had the largest fall in unemployment on record. As a consequence, we have had job growth of 630,000 since the last election. That was the principal issue of the last election campaign—employment. It is on this that the government kept complete fidelity with the Australian people. Not only that; the other thing I said on election night was that we wouldn't—
—Infidelity! Infidelity!
—The member for Cowan has been warned constantly this afternoon. He will cease interjecting. He has been given a formal warning now.

—On election night I said we would not leave the unemployed behind. We introduced a $1.6 billion policy in Working Nation to deal with long-term unemployment. The success we are having to date is now that just on a quarter is going to the long-term unemployed. They are the facts. That is what, for a start, wipes the Leader of the Opposition's question away. The Leader of the Opposition talks about the burden on home owners. We have had massive falls in interest rates over the period.
—Twenty-seven per cent.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will have his chance in a moment.

—The housing affordability index is now up again for people to buy a home. We have seen sustained falls in interest rates. We have seen housing interest rates fall in this very week and last week with fixed rates again under eight per cent. As a consequence of that, we are seeing housing affordability rise and the level of home ownership rise.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition also talked about uncertainty for the elderly. These are the same elderly people he left at under 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. We now have the age pension at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, a very large free area which is now removed totally from the tax system, plus huge increases in rent assistance for pensioners renting privately.

I point to the hide of the Leader of the Opposition to even dare mention these categories of people, when he saw their real standard of living fall, when he was prepared to see the real value of the age pension rot, when he was prepared to see his massive interest rate policies lead to a tremendous burden on home owners, and when he was prepared to see over 11 per cent unemployment with no prospect of repairing it.

That is the government's record, and the government stands very proudly on that record. In this parliament, on this side of the House, we believe in those dual aims of high employment growth and reasonable wage remuneration. I refer the parliament to what was said by Robert Reich, the US Labor Secretary, about the United States, about high employment growth and falling real wages for 15 years; or Europe with high real wages and terrible employment growth. This government has brought Australia up the middle, with high employment growth—

TALK.START.PARA: —And low wages.
—and affordable growing levels of remuneration.
—That's not true.

—The very burden of the question is about the incidence of the weight of government policy on people, yet the questioner, as I said before, has opposed every wage increase since 1981, bar two. He supported a $16 wage increase in 14 years; that is all he has ever done. Yet he has the temerity to get up and talk about battlers, and he gave himself away in saying, `We've been battling for battlers for a week' when the Labor Party has been battling for them for a century.

PARA.TAB: When we introduced in the budget the occupational superannuation change to give Australian working people the right to put away and have for their retirement 15 per cent of their income and to add to national savings, what did he say? He would crimp it at where the SGC now stands and give them tax concessions.

When tax concessions were the order of the day there was only a 40 per cent coverage, and there is now a 90 per cent coverage. Not only would this be a bad thing to do in economic terms, in national savings terms, but it would be a very harsh thing to do to Australians, who finally under a Labor government have got themselves the right to a decent retirement income by accessing the superannuation provisions—which the Leader of the Opposition, never learning, now says he wants to crimp and leave the SGC.

On those big brush issues—employment; complete fidelity by the government with the long-term unemployed; support for families by increases in family support, the guardians allowance, maternity leave, the home child-care allowance, the generalised child-care rebate—these were all specifics in the last election campaign and they have all been delivered. On top of that, the thing that we did not promise people but happily have been able to give them is 15 per cent occupational superannuation by the year 2002 for the rest of their lives, so that no Australian will be able to go into retirement worried about their income. Also, in Accord Mark VIII, in this last week, we have seen the payment of decent increases under enterprise bargaining—and a safety net for those who cannot access it—of $10 to $12 a week, and $11 to $14 for those on awards only.

In this area of the social wage, economic growth and opportunity, leaving aside the other great things like access and equity in health and education, and these high participation rates, the government has stayed completely faithful to its creed of a century: to make its policies relevant and helpful to the Australian working people. That is what it has done and that is what it has been very proud to be able to do.
Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

As these questions have considerable significance to the conduct of this place and have not been answered, could you please take action under standing order 150 and write to those ministers requesting an urgent answer?
—Under the relevant standing order—
—Are you staying for this MPI, Prime Minister?

—The member for Isaacs certainly will not be if he keeps interjecting while I am responding to one of his colleagues. I will take the appropriate action under standing order 150 for the honourable member for O'Connor.

—I also have questions that have been on the Notice Paper for over 90 days. They are questions Nos 2227, 2228 and 2229 addressed respectively to the Minister for Social Security, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice. I ask you to have the ministers honour me with an answer.

In our view, if a question is totally out of order you have no choice, on the basis of precedent, but to pass the next question to the other side.

—I will give you my answer now. In the course of the afternoon whilst question time was going on I did give some thought to it and I find that the member for Flinders generally has raised a valid point. I will endeavour to act accordingly.

—My question is on the exact same point as that raised by the member for Flinders. I recently asked a question of the Special Minister of State in question time and he took the point that it related to matters outside his ministerial responsibility and was, therefore, not within standing orders. If the precedent applied today to the question of the member for Throsby, which was outside standing orders, is applied, then I or any coalition questioner who asks a question of a minister which is outside his responsibility is entitled to ask a replacement question.
