TALK.START.PARA: —I present papers on the following subjects, being petitions which are not in accordance with the standing and sessional orders of the House:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia calls for the immediate release of the Gari Fourteen, a group of buddhist nuns from Gari nunnery, unjustly imprisoned by Chinese Authorities in Tibet. Furthermore, we ask that the Australia government exert maximum pressure upon the People's Republic of China in order to secure their immediate release by:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)sending an official representative from the Australian Embassy in Beijing to take up their case with the appropriate Chinese authorities in Tibet.
(b) raising the issue of the Gari Fourteen as a `matter of urgency' with the Chinese Ambassador presently residing in Canberra.

(c)committing the Australian government and its respective agencies to placing the issue of women political prisoners on the agenda for discussion at the United Nations 4th World Conference on Women to be held in Beijing in 1995.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, humbly request that urgent and strenuous efforts be made to develop a nursing home for the Mossman area.

With a large and increasing aged population, the Douglas Shire already has a pressing need for dedicated nursing home beds and Mossman Hospital simply is not funded for such care. Consequently all nursing home type patients must be placed outside this area with considerable distress to families and to patients, many of whom have lived in Mossman all their lives. Due to travel time and distance they face a loss of contact, reduction in quality of life and severe difficulty for their families in maintaining support and contact.
We request that urgent consideration be given to specific funding of a nursing home facility in our Shire.

SPEECH.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the Child Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House support the following changes:
1. That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

2. That The Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
3. That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
4. That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
5. That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
6. That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

7. That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament. The Petition of Certain Citizens of Australia draw the attention of the House to:

PARA.TAB: In 1994 over 2,500,000 Pension cheques were paid into banks. Banking services, like clean water, electricity, Food and Housing are a basic need, NOT a luxury, in this day and Age it is impossible to live without a bank account.

Two thirds of Australians 1.64 million Aged Pensioners live on less than $200 a week, with fewer resources and greater levels of disability, they are the hardest hit by fees and charges for over the counter services. Older People on Low Incomes can ill afford these extra costs imposed by banks on low account balances.

We strongly oppose any call from banks for the Department of Social Security to provide a subsidy to meet the cost of bank fees for pensioners. With $19 Billion per year, Pensions paid into banks, plus $3.4 Billion in Pensioner Deeming accounts and latest bank profits $5.2 Billion, profits up 81 per cent.
We call for the banks to be directed to provide access to a basic banking service

SPEECH.PARA: AS A CONDITION OF THEIR BANK LICENCES

PARA.TAB: We call for Federal and State governments to take steps to reduce the burden of these iniquitous taxes immediately, we, your Petitioners humbly pray.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Prime Minister to understand the real concerns of Australians and to recognise the pain inflicted by his Government on families, individuals, communities and the nation.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —If anybody in this parliament were to ask Australians to sum up the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), they would invariably come up with one word. They would not come up with the word that he would like them to come up with, and that is the word `leadership'; they would come up with another word that he finds distinctly uncomfortable, and that is the word `arrogance'. He has arrogance of a personal kind; he has arrogance of a political kind; he has arrogance of an economic kind; and he has arrogance of an offensive un-Australian kind, which sits like stigmata on the head of the entire Keating government.

PARA.TAB: It was with arrogance that the Prime Minister of Australia, after only five minutes of economic sunshine, told the Australian people that `this is as good as it ever gets'. He wonders why, through the length and breadth of Australia in 1995, he is regarded as an arrogant man. Yet having gone through the worst recession in 60 years with still a tragically high level of youth unemployment, with Australian home buyers now seeing 27 per cent of median family income devoured to pay off a home versus 19 per cent in 1983 and with Australians recognising that they and their families are labouring under a foreign debt that has increased by 600 per cent since 1983, he wonders why he is called arrogant. He wonders why so many Australians have now simply stopped listening to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why isn't he here?

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects, `Why isn't he here?' Of course, the Prime Minister's reply is: `Well, you lot finished second.' I have got news for the Prime Minister: whenever the next election is held it will not be us who finish second; it will be the mob over on the other side who finish second. The reason why, above everything else, they will finish second is that the Australian people have caught up with the Prime Minister. The Australian people have caught up with the fact that he is an arrogant person.

PARA.TAB: After 12 years they have got rather tired of all the empty promises, of all the empty rhetoric, of all the lies, of all the deception and of all the misleading of the Australian people. They have caught up with the fact that he promised them things before the last election that he was not able to deliver. In his increasingly arrogant style, what does the Prime Minister say? He says, `The Australian people respect the fact that I get the mail through.'

Let me say to the Prime Minister: yes, he does get the mail through but the problem is that only his mates get the cheques while those in mainstream Australia have letterboxes full of junk mail and bills. He can talk about getting the mail through; he can talk, in his typically arrogant style, about how he will answer questions when it suits him; and he can talk about people who come second. But, unfortunately for him, and unfortunately for many of his colleagues who hold marginal seats, it is the Australian people who feel that they are coming second under his stewardship.

The Australian people feel that after 12 years they are entitled to something better than bluster, insult and arrogance. After 12 years they are entitled to wonder why it is that this country has the worst current account deficit in the industrialised world. I can think of few things that are more humiliating and insulting to the proud Australian nation than to be told that our trade deficit is worse than Mexico's. I can think of few things that are more offensive and more insulting than to be told that.

There is an interesting atmosphere around the parliament today. There is an atmosphere that something that was meant to come to a climax did not come to a climax. I wonder whether it is due to the fact that the plan of the Prime Minister was to have an early election.

When you actually go through it, you get a very interesting scene. To use military parlance, you have fired all those 25-pounders, but somehow or other none of them has hit their target. Let us go through them. You had the disaster of the Canberra by-election—it is a fascinating study in political combat and political science—that brought our colleague over here, the member for Canberra (Mr Smyth), into the House. It was not just the average by-election swing; it was the biggest by-election swing in modern Australian political history. That was achieved in the heartland of a town that was regarded as welded onto the Labor Party and he secured a swing of 16.7 per cent. It was a very great result.

What was the reaction of the government? The government said, `Right, we are going to take this seriously. We are now going to keep our nose to the grindstone. We are now going to govern in the interests of all the Australian people.' Do you know what it did? It produced the budget. The first shell out of the 25-pounder was the budget. That was meant to demolish the opposition. But, somehow or other, it did not quite work like that.

I smiled to myself today when the Prime Minister said that we would not let him into our confidence about what our policies were. I say to those sitting opposite: do you know that I knew what the government was going to do with the Commonwealth Bank a long time before you did? I, in fact, predicted what the government was going to do with the Commonwealth Bank the weekend before the budget. Do you know when you were told about the sale of the Commonwealth Bank? You were told at 6.30 on the night of the budget. You were told an hour before the budget was released when the Commonwealth Bank was going to be sold.

The budget did not quite hit the mark; something went wrong. Maybe the Australian people are a little cynical of somebody who for 12 years said that it is akin to burning down the gum tree to sell the Commonwealth Bank and then suddenly, because he wants the dough and nothing else, he marches in and says that it is an inspired piece of policy. That struck a very discordant note. The Australian people thought to themselves that that is not really fair dinkum. If the bloke was really opposed to selling the Commonwealth Bank, if he really believed in public ownership, if he really believed in the legacy of Ben Chifley, whether he needed the dough or not, he would have held onto the Commonwealth Bank.

There is something cheap and tawdry about a man who gets into paroxysms of principle in opposing the sale of the Commonwealth Bank but, when it really comes to the crunch and he needs the money, he capitulates and he parades his free market credentials. I think the Australian people see through a hypocrite and a humbug—and they have got one now as a Prime Minister. I think they see through him, and that is one of the reasons why the shell that came out of that 25-pounder did not hit the mark.

Then there was the really big one—the republic. That was really going to wipe the smile off every face over here. With the almost unanimous support of the federal parliamentary press gallery and with the unanimous support of every newspaper around Australia—we might have noticed, just in passing, some a little more than others—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Australian?

—No. The government paraded that one out. This was going to demolish us. He thought the great line was, `Don't you favour having an Australian head of state?' Do you know what the subtext for that was? It was that they over there are better Australians than we are. What the Prime Minister of Australia was basically trying to do was to set Australian against Australian in that particular debate.

PARA.TAB: I would say to those who sit opposite that the reason why that one did not find the mark is that the Australian people once again saw through that. The Australian people know very well that, no matter who wins the next election, they are going to have a vote to determine the constitutional future of this country. They know darn well that, if they vote for the Liberal and National parties, they will have a greater range of choice than if they vote for the Australian Labor Party.

It is ironic—many of those who sit on the Labor Party side must feel a little uncomfortable—that was going to be your king hit issue, wasn't it? You were really going to wipe the floor with us on this issue, but somehow or other that did not work either. The big `R' word did not really bring home the bacon, did it? It is a bit like many of those failed budgets of the past: it just did not quite work. Instead of it splintering the opposition, it has turned sour on the government.

Australians all around this country know there are passionate Australians on both sides of the constitutional argument. It is not a test of who is the better Australian; it is a test of what is the better system of government for the future benefit of all Australians. Then something happened along the way to the secretary-generalship of the United Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gareth Gareth.

—He is not called `Gareth Gareth' for nothing. Something happened. Ever so faintly, he said, `Please, monsieur. Don't let off ze bombs.' There was no stridency. There was not the strength of a foreign minister who walks with power, fervour and passion on behalf of his countrymen. Government members talk about nationalism; they talk about independence; they talk about Australian sovereignty. If ever a man failed the test of robust Australianism, it was Gareth Evans with his pathetic performance in Tokyo. He really failed to match the nation's need.

PARA.TAB: All you lot opposite have done since then is play catch-up politics. That is all you have done. It is always `me too, please', `don't forget me' and `please include me in your acknowledgments'. The Prime Minister has been reduced to nothing more than a pathetic letter writer to French newspapers. He has never displayed any leadership on this issue. He has said that, because we supported the American nuclear deterrent in the 1970s and 1980s throughout the Cold War, in some way we have no right to express our opposition to French nuclear testing. He lies about the attitude of the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and he lies about my attitude—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member will withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, then, he misrepresents us. He is deceitful to the Australian people—this is more explicit and more precise—about the attitude of the member for Mayo and my attitude. Our position is very simple. Of course I supported the American deterrent during the Cold War. Every sane Australian did. There are a few insane ones opposite who did not.

PARA.TAB: Now that the Cold War is over and now that the Soviet Union has disintegrated, we are living in a completely new world. It seems as though the only people who have not realised that the great majority of the Australian community felt that are the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). Ever since that fateful press conference in Tokyo, which has buried for all time Gareth's prospects of ever leading the Australian Labor Party—he knows that; his crest-fallen countenance ever since is a very good illustration—

TALK.START.PARA: —Kim likes this.
—Kim is pretty happy. He is a new man. Look at those colourful ties. The Right took a collection and bought him a suit. May I say, I respect his relative sartorial splendour. I think it is terrific.

PARA.TAB: Something has happened. We had this marvellous sort of intention. I think the whole idea was to fire off all these 25-pounders, demolish the opposition and send us packing in disarray. And then what were they going to do? The Prime Minister was going to trot out to the viceroy, as Gough Whitlam used to call him, and get a dissolution. Something has happened. Somehow or other there has been a disconnection between the will of the government and the wishes of the Australian people.

The Australian people are saying very clearly to all of us in parliament, `We the Australian people have stopped listening to this man and we the Australian people think that after 12 years he should have done a little better as he has had his hands on all of the levers for all of the time, as he never tires of telling us.' He is a remarkable Prime Minister. He keeps saying that he has all the hands on all the levers, yet somehow or other things keep going wrong.

The Australian people say that after 12 years we should not have a worse current account deficit than Mexico's. They say that after 12 years we should not be paying more to service housing loans than we were paying in 1983. They cannot understand that after 12 years our foreign debt has gone up by 600 per cent. They cannot understand that after 12 years the average unemployment rate is higher than it was under the Fraser government. They cannot understand why real interest rates are now double what they were during the Fraser period of government.

They cannot understand why the Australian dollar has sunk to such abysmally low proportions. They cannot understand that we have a 27.4 per cent youth unemployment level and, above all, they cannot understand why the Prime Minister of Australia is so arrogant and out of touch with the wishes of mainstream Australia. Arrogance would be bad enough if he had something to be arrogant about, but if ever a man has nothing to be arrogant about, it is the Prime Minister after what he has done to this country over the last 12 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once the proud boast of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was that he was the most conservative politician that had ever led the Liberal Party. Once it was the proud boast of the Leader of the Opposition that he provided the intellectual leadership of the Liberal Party and of the nation. He would be the person who would put in place a raft of Liberal Party policies that would overcome what he thought was his humiliation in the period that he was Treasurer of this country, from 1977 to 1983, at Malcolm Fraser's hands. He would be the man who would put it all together. He would be the man who would deregulate our economy. He would be the man who would send Australia down the road to a new future.

PARA.TAB: What has he become? He has become timid, presenting as small a policy ball to kick around as he possibly can, and hoping that Australians are sufficiently ahistorical not to remember either his record in government or his record as Leader of the Opposition. His record was one of the most vehement hostility to the life and prospects of the ordinary Australian in this country. He set a test for this government. With great rhetoric and to the applause of his backbenchers he said, `What a humiliation—Australia with a current account deficit behind that of Mexico.'

Let me inform the Leader of the Opposition, if he regards that as the most massive national humiliation ever imposed upon this nation, that the year he became Treasurer of this nation Mexico's current account deficit was half the size of Australia's. The year he left the Treasury, booted out as Treasurer by the Australian public, the Australian current account deficit was half the size of Mexico's. If that is what the opposition leader puts down as a criterion for whether or not we ought to re-elect this government and as a lodestone by which we ought to measure the achievements of governments present and past, on his own test in government he most miserably failed. That was his position on that.

He has been wandering around the country talking about five minutes of sunshine. We have had four years of growth. We have had in the last three years 630,000 jobs. We have had a continuation out of recession and through into recovery of an inflation rate of three per cent—something you could never hope to achieve. Interest rates for the average householder in his term of office did not fall below the level to which they have now risen. If you want to take those comparisons—which he is always terribly reluctant for us to do, to have regard to history; those opposite have talked a bit about history and I will have more to say about that later—let me go through them.

The bank housing rate when John Howard left office was 12.5 per cent. The current bank housing rate is 10.5. The building society rate when Howard left office was 13.9 per cent. The current building society rate is 10.5. The bank housing loan rate was 13.5 per cent in December 1982 and the building society housing loan rate was 14.8. He sneers at that achievement on jobs. The fundamental promise that the Labor Party made at the last election was that we would reach out our arms to the unemployed and give them an opportunity—630,000 jobs later—to continue our record which has seen, since we have been in office, the annual growth rate per year in jobs in this country at 161,000. Under John Howard as Treasurer, the average annual growth rate in jobs was 51,000. Our level of growth is more than three times that achieved by the Leader of the Opposition when he was in office.

John Howard talks about whether or not this is a government for the battlers. He sneers at the fact that he thinks I buy my suits in circumstances that most Australians buy them. He sneers at the fact that he thinks the parliamentary Labor Party provides me with ties—

TALK.START.PARA: —We do.

—I will own up to the fact that one member of the parliamentary Labor Party has provided me with the odd tie, but others have not. Nevertheless, this great defender of the battlers has to contemplate his record on things that are serious—such as the social wage. The social wage, which includes all those things that relate to the family support measures that have been put in place—and we have introduced many of them while we have been in office, but some were already there as hangovers from the Whitlam government when it was in power—fell 17 per cent in real terms while John Howard was Treasurer, and he made a virtue of that. Under us, and in a period of extraordinary restraint, the social wage has risen by something like 70 per cent in real terms since we have been in office.
—Seventy-eight per cent.

—I am corrected; it was 78 per cent. The Leader of the Opposition has become a small policy fur ball—the sort of thing you cough up every now and then, but you do not dissect. He does not want any form of dissection of his policy positions. He does not want any dissection simply because he thinks it is a clever political tactic. It is not that. He does not want any dissection because he knows that, if you crack open the Liberal Party policy bank, you will find a series of unpalatable policies that will not work. You will discover an opposition too tired to come out with a sensible set of propositions to take the country forward. He realises that the views he held were tried around the Western world in the 1980s and produced a massive thumbs down around the Western world in the 1990s. He has nothing further to add.

PARA.TAB: He speaks with pride about his idea of a people's convention. His idea of a people's convention is to avoid a decision. Let me quote from an interesting article written by Alex Mitchell in the Sun-Herald recently. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Two years ago, I had a private discussion with a very senior Liberal. At that time, Prime Minister Keating had nailed his republican ideals to the mast and I asked how the Liberal Party intended responding. "No worries. We can kick the whole thing into touch by calling for a people's convention. The people's convention is a perfect talking shop. It will keep the issue off the party political agenda and the election agenda. With a people's convention up and running, the Liberal Party would not have to say or do anything about the republic. It would effectively bury the issue for as long as we want it."
I really wonder who that senior Liberal was! Later on in the conversation, the senior Liberal said:
I am a monarchist. I was born a monarchist and I will die a monarchist.

I would bet London to a brick that that senior Liberal whom he had a conversation with was none other than JWH. He talks with pride about his people's convention. Let us see how that people's convention emerged.

PARA.TAB: John Howard produced the most tired response conceivably possible to the vision that the Prime Minister presented. His first response included the statement: `We are going to have a people's convention. What we are going to do with that people's convention is not put anything on the republic; we will put to the people's convention whether or not we should change the external affairs power which protects our environment and protects people's wages.' That is what he said he would put to the convention.

Having said that that was the only issue he wanted to put to the people's convention, he found he had to retreat from that position. He said, `Perhaps we will put a republican issue to the people's convention.' He was asked, `What if your rigged people's convention didn't work it out?' He said, `Then we would put a policy proposition on a republican convention to the people in two bites—one a consultative referendum and the other a constitutional referendum.'

Since when has any proposition on the constitution been carried by a party that put it forward and opposed it? Since when has any proposition on the constitution ever been put up by a party that decides that what it will do is put it forward and then oppose it? Alan Ramsey summed up the value of the Leader of the Opposition based on the performance which provoked that extraordinary retreating reaction. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: His speech two nights ago was that dreadful it was facile, contrived, pedestrian and disingenuous. It had no commitment, no passion and no clarity. It revived all the flaws that brought him undone that first time six years ago. It marked him perhaps fatally as truly yesterday's man. It exposed him more brutally than ever as a leader locked into the past; as a politician of indecision, no courage, no guile, no ideas, no true understanding of his own country in the 1990s and no feel for the future. If it wasn't complete humbug, it was absolute political disaster.

Indeed, it was. That absolute political disaster produced a three-day gallop, and he revised policy on the convention. He had one advantage from that gallop: he did not have to defend exactly how the people's convention would be created. The people's convention is going to be started by having 50 per cent appointed. The old government of the day is going to make absolutely certain that it is a well and truly rigged people's convention.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite were ever to get into office and put a republican proposition to the people, it would be bowdlerised in such a way that no-one with any commonsense would support it. This is a man and a party which have, in the course of the 1980s, moved from attempting to come to grips with higher principle, have walked back from all of that and are now desperately asking the public, `Please, find everything you can conceivably object to about the government. Vote in a hollow shell of a leader, vote in a hollow shell of a front bench.'

When we got into office in this country, every single member of the Labor Party front bench was a household name because they had developed policy and had been prepared to test and argue it with the public—and Barry Jones was one of them. There is not one member of the Liberal Party front bench—outside the Leader of the Liberal Party and his deputy, and now the foreign affairs spokesman—who can be named by more than 10 per cent of the Australian population—not one. That is because there is no intellectual leadership. They are a tired old crew. It is an unbelievable thing to say but it is nevertheless true.

After 12 years in office, the government's frontbench is on average two years younger than the opposition's frontbench. It is an extraordinary statement to make but it is true. As far as I can see, the only role the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) performs is to lower the average age of the Liberal Party frontbench. He has had nothing to say about economic policy. He has developed no economic policy. If he were removed from the Liberal Party front bench, that two-year difference would go up to something like 2 1/2 or three years.

They are a totally tired policy-free zone. There is only one element of the Leader of the Opposition's tactic which I think is sensible—that is, when he develops his policies he does not confront the Liberal Party backbench with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Laurie Oakes caught you on Tony Blair.

—No, he did not. The only thing I would agree with him on is that I would not bother consulting the Liberal Party backbench on a matter of policy. They are the oldest pack of time servers, a total bunch of wasters. Leave them alone. Leave them out there. Unfortunately, the demands of democracy are that you get up on your hind legs and develop policy.

PARA.TAB: You should do the sort of thing Tony Blair does. This is a good role for oppositions. Tony Blair does exactly what we did in the early 1980s: he restructures party policy, gets his party spokespeople to come out with policies well in advance, discusses them with the British people and refines them down to election day. It is not a matter of, `You will get our policies in the election.' It is a matter of, `You get our policies straight away. You have an opportunity to interact with those policies.' When the time comes to go to the polls, that emerges as a platform. That is what Tony Blair does. I know that and Laurie Oakes, I am afraid to say, did not. Helen Trinca got that analysis of Tony Blair wrong. Tony Blair happens to be a genuine opposition leader, not a tired, recycled opposition leader.

The Leader of the Opposition objects to the fact that we are not calling an immediate election after his having said for the last few months that all we ever wanted to do was call an early election. He objects to the fact that no early election is being called and that it was never foreshadowed by this government—for one reason and one reason only. What on earth is he going to say for the next nine to 12 months? You can make yourself a fur ball and roll around the ground for a few months, but there is no chance whatsoever that you can make yourself a fur ball for another nine to 12 months. You will not get away with that. This MPI comes from a tired old fellow and we need take no notice of it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a somewhat disappointing speech from the new Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley). I remind the Deputy Prime Minister of one policy area where Labor has completely failed and that is in the area of uranium policy. None other than former Prime Minister Mr Bob Hawke has described your uranium policy as illogical, yet you persist with that illogical three mines uranium policy. This is another example of Labor's policy vacuum.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the republic, it is the coalition which has a legitimate policy to include people in the review of our constitution after its operation for some 100 years. Our policy involves looking at the path that Australia correctly pursued in the 1890s when it originally formulated the constitution for the Commonwealth of Australia. It involves a fair dinkum people's convention and a fair dinkum set of questions being put to the people by way of a referendum. The coalition will have a referendum on the question of whether Australia should become a republic. Contrast that with Labor's approach that we have to cop it sweet, we have to cop its model of the republic, we will get no input into what that model will be and we can take it or leave it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe in a republic.
—I concede that the member interjecting might be a full-on republican, but he will be endangered by that process. That is the wrong way of putting a fair set of questions to the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The House is debating a matter of public importance which relates to the failure of this Prime Minister to understand the concerns of Australians. His failure was revealed very starkly again during question time today. The Prime Minister said, on assuming the leadership of the Labor Party, `I will tell the truth.' He said at the time of the 1993 election, `What I am promising is not to put up taxes.'

The budget papers detail that real growth in taxation revenue will increase by 10.3 per cent this financial year, which finishes tomorrow. Next financial year there will be an additional increase of 9.3 per cent in the tax take. This federal Labor government continues to grab more and more by way of taxation. From Saturday 1 July, sales tax will go up. Not only will the rate go up but there are other factors involved as well.

In relation to rate increases, it was revealed in the 1993 budget that the wholesale sales tax rate will jump from $435 million to $585 million to $1,207 million to $1,345 million over the four financial years to 1996-97. What we have is a government that is getting bigger and bigger on the backs of blue-collar workers. It is doing that in a very unfair, unjust and unreasonable way. It is getting bigger and bigger on the backs of families who are battling to survive in very tough economic times. If members would like an insight into this problem—and perhaps government members are so out of touch that they need to be reminded—I remind the House of what the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures said today in a survey report. It stated:
New South Wales manufacturers say they expect to shed about 2,600 jobs in the next 12 months because of a severe downturn in business, according to a survey released today.

The NSW Chamber of Manufacturers and State Bank June quarter survey found any improved conditions in early 1994 had evaporated and manufacturers put the blame on higher interest rates, increases in sales tax and a slump in the building industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Listen to this:

PARA.TAB: The NSW Chamber's chief executive, Philip Holt, said the survey highlighted the difficulties facing the manufacturing sector.
"The picture painted by the survey demonstrates the dilemma faced by the government and Australia . . .
"While the current account deficit careers out of control, we have lost control of interest rates—the single most important barrier to investment in manufacturing."
Mr Holt said Chamber members had told him they feared another recession.
State Bank chief economist Hans Kunnen said the survey showed a clear downturn in the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: That is from the real world where Labor members hesitate to venture. That article was about a survey released today. I want to examine the government's lack of performance and take up another challenge of the Deputy Prime Minister. He was extolling the virtues of the government's frontbench team. I concede that sometimes those of us in the lower house forget to look across the corridor to the Senate and to examine the other portion of the Labor government's frontbench team—the Senate ministerial team.

PARA.TAB: When we examine the monumental lack of leadership coming from this government, what do we find? The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) is enduring his worst fortnight ever in politics. He is enduring it through dint of his own lack of effort over a range of issues. If you want a manifestation of what the government thinks of Senator Gareth Evans, may I remind you of what happened last week. You will recall that the government altered by 24 hours the date of election of the new deputy of the Labor Party when the member for Batman (Mr Howe) suddenly handed in his resignation to ensure that Gareth Evans was caught overseas and was unable to attend the caucus meeting.

Minister Evans has really failed with regard to French nuclear testing. The way in which he failed to raise our concerns in key correspondence was shameful. His response to the decision of President Jacques Chirac has been weak; it has been late; it has been timid; and it has been lacking in leadership. As a consequence of that and other factors, we face the prospect of some horrific French nuclear testing in the next 12 months in the Southern Hemisphere. Minister Gareth Evans has failed again with regard to a certain matter involving Australia and Indonesia. I will not dwell on that due to time constraints, but it is there to be seen.

Then you might turn to the magnificent Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). Do you remember Rosemary Crowley? Have any of you heard of Minister Rosemary Crowley? She got so excited a couple of Christmases ago that she tried to cut out Christmas carols. That was the sort of leadership she provided to the Senate and the nation.

More recently, we have the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan). He really is in the B-grade team. Yesterday, he was very effectively exposed in an article which showed that he has totally got the APEC strategy wrong. As a consequence, he has run up the white flag on a key dimension of Australian trading policy. He has left Australia exposed in what is a very unlevel international playing field. The coalition recognises that and has developed policy to respond to that. The government's Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, still cannot get it right with respect to a non-discriminatory approach with regard to APEC and future trading arrangements and a discriminatory trade approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Minister Faulkner?

—Then we have the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner). Well might the Deputy Leader of the National Party refer to him. He was the one who relied on environmental extremists rather than objective scientific endeavour to evaluate Australia's forests of environmental significance. He was totally humiliated when the cabinet steamrolled his submission, making him look like a lobbyist rather than a minister.
—He looked like Ros Kelly.

—Remember the list. Ros Kelly's whiteboard was bad enough, but Minister Faulkner's list of coupes, including everything from airstrips to quarries, was a total dereliction of duty, determination and leadership with regard to that key important environmental portfolio. Then there is the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). He has just had a spectacular performance on a piece of industrial research and development legislation which has now been exposed by coalition senators in a way which has severely embarrassed him.

PARA.TAB: They are just five of the other team up there which is failing this government, and you know it. You admit it in your hearts. We often do not have much direct exposure with these ministers. I just thought it was timely, as we debate the leadership in this government, that we expose its B-grade team here today.

I say to the House that what this country wants is fair dinkum leadership, in touch leadership. What it has, sadly, is the Prime Minister, a leader who goes around saying, `This is as good as it gets.' Fancy making that comment a few weeks ago when this day the Chamber of Manufactures has found that it has the need to speak of a further recession arising from the results of its most recent survey. I have to say this is not as good as it gets. It will get a whole lot better when we have John Winston Howard in the Lodge and a coalition government providing real leadership for this country—the sooner the better. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion should be seen for what it simply is—a shabby attempt by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), 12 years after the crime, to try to expunge the guilt of his own assault on families, communities and the Australian nation during his time as Treasurer. Throughout question time we have observed the coalition wallowing in the worst kind of hypocrisy. It has been very hypocritical over French nuclear testing. It has been hypocritical over economic policy by its failure to tell the Australian people its own policies, and now we have this motion criticising the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: I note with some degree of interest that the honourable member for Bennelong said that it is sheer arrogance for the Prime Minister to come into this House and defend the rights of workers. We have that criticism coming from a second-rate leader who has been rejected three times by his own party and the Australian people. I think it is the height of arrogance for the Leader of the Opposition to come into this House with an appalling economic record from his own time in opposition and make these charges against the Prime Minister. It is even more arrogant coming from a man who cannot even bring himself to countenance an Australian as an Australian head of state.

The Leader of the Opposition completely forfeits any right to speak on this particular matter of public importance before the House today. He has levied the charge against the Prime Minister and the government that the Australian people are coming second under the Prime Minister's stewardship. Is he talking about the long-term unemployed, who have been the recipients of the caring resources that have been put at their disposal to bring them back into the work force by the Prime Minister and the government through the Working Nation program? Is he talking about the Aboriginal people, who can now walk with pride in the wake of the Mabo legislation, which has been brought to this House by the government and opposed at every step by a weak-kneed leader who could not keep the rednecks in Western Australia under control?

Is he talking about the pensioners whose living standards have increased over the past 12 years? Are they the people that he says are coming second under the stewardship of the Prime Minister, or is he talking about the low paid workers who will receive benefits under the Accord that the Prime Minister announced in this last sitting of parliament? Are they the people who are coming second under the stewardship of the Prime Minister and the government?

Let people in this House have no illusion about the leadership qualities of the people who lead the government and the opposition. There is not anybody on the other side of the House, nor on this side of the House, who really holds the belief that the Leader of the Opposition would have had the wit, the courage, the intellectual depth or the political resolve to restructure the Australian economy while at the same time maintaining the social cohesion and advancing the living standards of Australians.

Is there anybody in this House who really believes that the honourable member for Bennelong could have constructed the Mabo legislation and guided it through the houses of this parliament? Is there anybody on either side of this House who really believes that the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition, could construct the Accord process which will deliver Australian workers low inflation over the next four or five years?

Is there anybody on the floor of this parliament, or outside of this parliament, who honestly believes that the honourable member for Bennelong could have constructed APEC or that he could have delivered the great social wage that Australian workers—the individuals, the families, the communities and the nation—enjoy?

The honourable member for Bennelong refuses time and time again in this House to answer the challenge of the government to table the policies of the opposition. It is going to be a really interesting brainstorming session tomorrow without the brains. There are no policies on the table that the Australian people can judge.

We know exactly how the Leader of the Opposition is handling the policy debate. It was done in Victoria by Jeff Kennett. Kennett made a promise to the Victorian work force and to individuals, families and communities that are the subject of this MPI here today. He made the promise that no worker would be worse off when the Kennett government came to power. After a massive assault on the social wage and on the living standards of workers, represented by an increase in taxes of $1,200 per family, we finally found out the real policies and the real agenda of the opposition. It gets worse than that because the honourable member for Bennelong will not even tell his own backbenchers. How can you hold a brainstorming session when you have nothing on the table and you will not even tell your own backbench what the policies are?

The Prime Minister is a family man. He has successfully raised a family of four while devoting his political life to the welfare of the working people of this nation. What possible construction could the opposition put on this MPI accusing the Prime Minister of causing pain to Australian families and Australian communities? During his whole political life, the Prime Minister has been the architect, the weaver of the fabric, of the social wage, which has been the rock of support on which low income earners and working families have pinned their hopes for a decent standard of living in this country.

Australia, because of the efforts and the leadership of the Prime Minister, is acknowledged as being one of the great social democracies in the world. That has been the hallmark of the Prime Minister's life—an untiring and unswerving dedication to the improvement of the living standards of all Australians. That concern was reflected in the budget that he, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) crafted recently, which was delivered to the Australian people and the nation.

The government delivered a prospect of economic security taking us beyond the year 2000, a gross domestic product improvement of 3 3/4 per cent, business investment rising by 13 per cent, employment growth of three per cent, over 240,000 jobs, a fall in the unemployment rate, an increase in the real disposable household incomes of people, continued low levels of inflation and decreasing interest rates. Are these the hallmarks of a government that is attacking the working families of this nation? While I am on the subject of families, I say that we introduced a range of measures designed specifically to improve their living standards.

What of the prince of pain? What of the Leader of the Opposition, whose record in office condemns him in the eyes of every economic commentator and in the eyes of the Australian people? While he wines and dines with the desperate tories of the Melbourne Club, he ought to tell us about the pain working families would have suffered by virtue of getting a miserly $16 rise over the last 12 years. While he sits on the cocktail circuit on the North Shore, he might tell the working people of this nation how he plans the most massive assault on their wages and conditions with the aiding and abetting of his state leaders in New South Wales and elsewhere around this nation.

The Prime Minister of this country has constructed a social wage which has supported the working people of this nation. But the Leader of the Opposition has a record where, over his time in office, that social wage declined by 17.5 per cent. The Prime Minister has been the consistent defender of the wages and conditions of workers and their families while the Leader of the Opposition lies in the grass, waiting to rip and tear at the heart of the wages and conditions of working people in this country.

It is the Prime Minister who has delivered the lower levels of taxation for families and individuals in this nation; and it is the Leader of the Opposition who, while Treasurer, let the tax bludgers send their files to the bottom of the harbour and skive away—those spivs and tax bludgers who got away with $2 billion. The Leader of the Opposition deserves the universal condemnation of this House. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The discussion is now concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Does the honourable member wish to make a personal explanation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do.
—Please proceed.

—During his MPI response today, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) arrogantly asserted that the coalition frontbench lacked public recognition, except for our leader and deputy leader. In refuting that claim, I challenge him or any of his ministers to get out anywhere with me and see how they get their recognition.
—Order! That is not a personal explanation. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, just by the way—
—Just resume your seat.
—By the way—
—Resume your seat!
—those blokes could stand up while you were here and say—

SPEECH.PARA: The tariff proposals which I have just tabled contain alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The changes are operative from 1 July 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not seek a division on the motion before the House, but I bring to the attention of members of the House that the motion fails to include the provision for question time to be held tomorrow. When I first raised this matter with the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), the answer I got was, `We don't have a question time on this extended day because it is not the precedent of the House to do so.'

PARA.TAB: He was rather lost for words this morning when I pointed out to him that there is a precedent for holding question time on extended sitting days of the House. The significance of that is that, when that further point was put to the Leader of the House, he was left with no alternative but to confess that there is absolutely no reason whatsoever why the parliament should not have the benefit of question time tomorrow.

It is important that question time be held tomorrow. There are important statistics coming out tomorrow which will reveal the latest accumulation in Australia's foreign debt, courtesy of the current account figures which will be released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I suppose, for many Australians, when you say `current account deficit', their eyes tend to roll over. It has been revealed in the last week or so that Australia's current account deficit is now worse than Mexico's and is the worst in the OECD.

The implication of that is that, because the country has a massive debt, a huge mountain of debt, the rest of the world requires us to pay more interest. The effect on the average family, rather than glazing your eyes over, should make your hair stand on end. If you have a mortgage, if you owe money on your bankcard or if you owe money on your overdraft, then you are paying more as a result of the massive indebtedness which has been built up by the failure of this government's economic policy over the last 12 years.

As the figures are released tomorrow, a lot of Australians would like the government to answer some basic questions about why it is that, after 12 years, Australia has racked up this massive and still accumulating debt. Australia's debt when Malcolm Fraser left office was about $23 billion. Today it is around $160 billion or $170 billion.

We have a massive debt, and as a nation we are now borrowing to pay our interest bill. Think of that in your own family circumstances. If you got a notice from the bank saying that you owed $1,000 or $900 on your bankcard, think of the difficulty you would be in if, to pay your monthly bankcard bill, you had to go down to the bank and get a loan to meet the outstanding liability. If you were borrowing to pay your bankcard bill, you would not need to be an accountant to work out that you were in serious financial problems.
They are the circumstances facing our great country. After 12 years of this Labor government's mismanagement, the truth of the matter is that, as a nation, we are borrowing to pay our interest bill.

—On behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, I present the committee's report entitled The workforce of the future, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The committee's inquiry into the work force of the future has reviewed demographic and labour market trends to draw attention to the future challenges and possibilities for Australia. Challenges and possibilities have been forced upon us by changes in demography, technology and the development of a global market, a market without frontiers.

PARA.TAB: It will be futile for governments to fight rearguard actions against change, but there can be substantial benefits in seeking to understand the directions where already apparent trends are leading. The committee's report on the work force of the future examines demographic, economic and labour market developments and makes recommendations for government to assist workers and employers to adapt to structural and social change. The past 21 years have been marked by striking changes in the composition of the Australian labour market.

For reasons that are not entirely clear, the year 1974 stands out in international labour force statistics as marking a sudden end to what has been called `the golden age of full employment' which ran for 30 years from the end of World War II. A variety of explanations have been put forward including the impact of the oil shock of 1973; general use of the contraceptive pill, which changed the whole pattern of fertility and led to increased female labour force participation; a loss of confidence in government intervention, Keynesian style, in the economy, leading to a revival of neoclassical economic theory and practice; and a clear indication of the post-industrial phenomenon with sharp declines in manufacturing employment, now down to 14 per cent, and demand for manual labour.

Before 1974 Australia's unemployment rate was one of the world's lowest, far lower than that of the United States or Britain. Since 1974 it has generally been higher than that of the US, and sometimes higher than that of Britain. However, our wage levels have maintained value better than in the US.

The committee emphasises that the composition of the 1995 labour force is radically different from that of 1974. Since 1974 female participation in the labour force has increased from 41 to 51 per cent. The post-war Beveridge-Chifley concept of full employment being defined as `one adult breadwinner per family' has been overtaken by events.

Another important development has been the growth of part-time work. In 1973 only 12 per cent of workers were employed part time. By 1993 this had doubled to 24 per cent. A high proportion of part-time jobs are performed by young people between 15 and 24 years of age and by married women. The number of jobs created in Australia between 1973 and 1993 was 1.8 million, or a growth of 32 per cent. However, over a million of those jobs were part time, which was an increase of 164 per cent in part-time employment.

Largely due to these factors, Australia, in common with most OECD nations, is now experiencing the unprecedented phenomenon of high employment and high unemployment simultaneously. It sounds like a contradiction in terms. All it means is that many of those, mostly males, who were traditionally in work are now out of it and unlikely to return while those, mostly women, who were traditionally not in work are now in it.

Apart from the high employment-high unemployment paradox, the age and gender composition of the labour force has changed dramatically. So has the length of working life, at a time of increasing life expectancy in Australia and most comparable economies. The 35-year working lifetime is likely to become the norm, replacing the 50-year model. Many more jobs have been created but, at the same time, labour force participation rates have never been greater. At 63.7 per cent, they have stayed close to their historic highest levels since 1974.

While the composition of the labour force has changed, a revolution in the work force has also occurred. Far more people work with telephones and computers than with traditional tools. Technical innovations have transformed every area of work from manufacturing processes to transport, warehousing and retailing, transforming the range of tasks performed. The regional impact of employment changes is extremely varied.

Along with changes to tools and techniques, there have been far reaching shifts in the leading employment sectors in Australia. Since 1974, the fastest growing employment sector has been the information related employment sector—including the whole range of media and entertainment, market research, consulting, administrative, management, clerical, education and financial services. This sector is estimated at 42.5 per cent of the labour force.

The second fastest growth has been in domestic and quasi-domestic work including `hospitality' and tourism, essentially paralleling work which used to be carried out at home without a wage. These sectors between them now employ the bulk of services employment. Services in total comprise 79 per cent of the labour force.

These developments have been lost in the statistics produced by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The committee accordingly recommends that the government request the Australian Bureau of Statistics to review the appropriateness of its existing data collection methodology and to indicate significance of information and domestic or quasi-domestic service employment.

The committee took on Peter Drucker's important argument about the decline of hierarchical work, that management structures have been flattened out. He argues that the coming post-industrial society is `the first in which not everybody does the same work. This is far more than a social change. It is a change in the human condition'. In a knowledge society, having a hundred or a thousand people performing the same task, as was characteristic of agriculture or manufacturing, would be pointless.

The committee also drew attention to the formation of dual labour markets. The primary labour market is characterised by high skill levels, comparative security of employment and a full range of award related working conditions. The secondary labour market may be characterised by insecure work, low skill levels and a deteriorating range of award coverage. There is also increased wage disparity between the primary and the secondary labour markets.

The domestic services and tourism and hospitality sectors are where most new jobs are now being created. Some 55 per cent of all work is estimated to be unpaid or informal work, once almost exclusively done by women, now increasingly outsourced. Evidence to the committee indicated that an additional two million potential jobs were waiting to be created by outsourcing services such as food preparation and delivery, home maintenance and gardening, cleaning, security and child minding. Of course, such outsourcing would be dependent on the restoration of the two income family with higher levels of discretionary spending. Australia is now exporting a range of services, including tourism, educational, financial, legal, marketing and management consultancy services. But we still import more services than we export.

Other areas where employment growth and wealth generation may be expected to occur include a number of industrial sectors such as construction, mining and value added manufacturing, together with agriculture—especially value added horticultural exports—information technology, knowledge related information services, health related services and tourism. The unprecedented growth of the information and quasi-domestic services sectors of the economy has led to the displacement of one group of workers and its replacement by another group. There is now a relatively high demand for skilled and professional workers and a relatively low demand for unskilled workers.

Across a wide variety of white-collar occupations, new computer technology enables some workers to attempt more creative or intellectually demanding tasks. There are now fewer opportunities for process related and middle management white-collar workers. During the 1980s, for example, many traditional clerical jobs have been lost in the banking and financial sectors, but now new financial products are creating employment downstream.

There has been high growth in the low skilled part-time hospitality and tourism sectors of the economy. Structural award conditions in these industries have resulted in substantial cost advantages for the employment of part-time labour. In 1993 nearly 80 per cent of all part-time workers were employed in services.

The changes outlined in the committee's report have caused substantial dislocation in the lives of many workers. The challenge for any government is to ease the impact of the process. As we said in paragraph 1.21, recognising that outsourcing will be a major contribution to employment, the committee recommends the government examine measures which may facilitate tendencies to outsource work from the home, government administration and industry, including primary industry.There is general agreement on the part of political parties, employer groups, trade unions and industrial tribunals on the basic objectives of work force change, but not the same degree of consensus on the range of measures needed to improve Australia's penetration of global markets.

As we wrote in paragraph 2.31, one of Australia's greatest economic problems, although insufficiently recognised, is the inventory problem. This is the conspicuous lack of an inventory of brand name goods for which there is international recognition and demand, leading to a willingness to pay a premium price. Canada also lacks such an inventory, which is in significant contrast to Sweden, with Volvo, Saab, SKL and L. M. Ericsson; Finland, with Kone and Nokia; the Netherlands, with Philips and Shell; and the Republic of Korea, with Hyundai, Gold Star and Daewoo. All of those countries have such an inventory.

I have already pointed to the tendency towards labour force demarcation between high skilled jobs with high pay and low skilled jobs often with low pay. High skilled jobs require an educated work force that is adaptable and flexible and which can acquire new knowledge quickly. Not all workers can possess those qualities. Governments must ensure that those who do not are not marginalised and are provided with opportunities to participate in the economy in a productive way.

Access to information technology for all is essential if Australia is not to be divided into the information rich and the information poor. The committee repeats its 1991 recommendation that the government adopt a national information policy which sets out a series of principles which anticipates the social, economic and cultural implications of the information revolution rather than having decisions made piecemeal, on the run, responding to situations such as the adoption of new technologies or changes in ownership suddenly arising.

The committee notes that those countries which have moved to a high-tech knowledge based economy have also been most successful in creating employment. According to EPAC and the Hilmer report, at present Australia's efficiency levels in the business sector are 10 to 15 per cent below the average for OECD countries, and the average Australian enterprise operates at 30 per cent below world best practice. It is recognised that the priority for industry must be to improve competitiveness and productivity in order to succeed. At the same time, Australia must stimulate market demand for its goods and services by building up a high value added inventory.

The cover of the report reproduces a famous photograph of Charlie Chaplin on the wheels of a huge machine, wielding a spanner, and is taken from his film Modern Times. As one of the committee members thoughtfully observed, the cover should not be taken as evidence of a weakened commitment to work safety.

I take this opportunity to thank members of the committee, especially the deputy chairman, the member for Cook (Mr Dobie), for their contributions to understanding this vital subject. I also thank all those who made written submissions, gave evidence or took part in workshops, and especially the admirable but depleted staff of the committee—Dr Margot Kerley and Ms Helen Collins. We owe them a great debt for their professionalism and dedication.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Perhaps this is the last report that I will help to present to this parliament. It is fitting that it should be a report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, which has maintained its independence since Prime Minister Hawke created the committee in June 1990 with the proviso that the chairman would have to be the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). PARA.TAB: Because of the valedictory nature and atmosphere for me after—I might tell the chairman—42 1/2 years in the work force, I would like to pay a tribute to the chairman of the committee. At all times, since the committee was created five years ago this month, the chairman has sought, and I believe has always obtained, a parliamentary attitude to whatever subject we were studying. This may not mean much to new people in the parliament but, before the present government assumed office, all parliamentary committees decided by themselves what they would report upon.

Prime Minister Hawke allowed this committee to be independent, and we have chosen our own references in the last five years. I believe that the quality of our reports reflects this. I believe that, in the next parliament, whoever wins—I will not be here—will come back to the position that parliamentary committees should always report on what they believe is significant, not what has to be referred to them by this chamber, therefore the government, or by a minister in charge of a subject, which we have had in other committees I have served on—with disastrous effects, I must say. I hope there is a change in committee attitudes in the next parliament. No government can survive if it determines what parliamentary committees shall talk about. I commend to the House this committee report, which has this splendid cover that the chairman has referred to. I will not go over the issues he has raised. There are just a few he has not. Recommendation 2.35 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee acknowledges the increasing importance of service employment to the future economic development of the nation . . .

PARA.TAB: The recommendation that impressed me, though I had nothing to do with the writing of this particular one, is recommendation 6.25, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the concept of mandatory retirement (with its implications of `statutory senility'—
which I do not have—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's debatable.
—We have never spoken in all the years you have been in this parliament. Isn't that strange? Now you make a comment which is insulting in a speech. Recommendation 6.25 states:

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today, I spoke to a motion moved by the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). In the course of my speech I detailed the extraordinary difficulty I was having in getting any information at all with respect to a particular government program operating in my electorate. I said that the trail of trying to find out what was happening in my electorate—a perfectly reasonable request for information—ended with the office of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), where I had been directed by the department.

PARA.TAB: When, as I had been told to, I asked a certain person for this information, I was told that person was on three weeks leave and that the minister's office would follow up and let me have the information. That request was made some time prior to 10 o'clock. As at 11 o'clock when I came to the House to speak, no call had been received from the minister's office.

I subsequently received a message, taken in my office, at 3 o'clock this afternoon, from a Ms Susan Smith, who I understand works in the office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). I was informed that my request for information, for details about new work opportunities programs in Moncrieff, had to be put in writing to the minister and then I would get an answer. Put in the context of the speech I gave today, people will see just how extraordinary that request is.

There is another subject I feel a little diffidence about raising but, since this is probably the last adjournment debate before the parliamentary recess, I would like to put the record straight on—a personal matter. I emphasise, for the record, that I am not saying this in a `heavy' way.

I have been aware for some weeks now that there has been a story circulating in my electorate that I have a serious health problem. The story, put simply, is that I have a terminal disease and it is expected that I will resign from parliament in a certain period of time. I want to assure my constituents that that story contains absolutely no truth whatsoever.

I treated it as a joke for some time. However, I was rather disturbed today to hear the story from someone who lives in Victoria and to discover that this story has apparently spread well past my electorate. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) laughs, and that is certainly my reaction too. The only comment I make is that, when I told my husband, he did not laugh. He was very angry indeed, because one could ascribe some quite evil motives to a story like that. When I was told the story and I laughed, I said, `They are going to be disappointed when I don't die, aren't they?' That was my reaction to it. I say that just to make the point that I am not being heavy about this.
However, when I realised the story had a widespread currency, I thought it was time to reassure my constituents that I am in excellent health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Full voice.

—Full voice, as has been commented by the member for Cowan. I have never been in better health and, contrary to this rumour, I am not `returning to hospital' this recess. I have not been to hospital, so I cannot return. I look forward to many more years representing the very worthy residents of Moncrieff—in government.
